ARTICLE A. POLICE PENSION SYSTEM
§2-701 POLICE PENSION SYSTEM.
   It is hereby declared to be the purpose and intention of the city to adopt
the police pension and retirement system as provided by the laws of the state.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. §§ 50-101 et seq., 50-106.3, 50-109 and 50-
110
ARTICLE B. FIREFIGHTERS’ PENSION FUND
§2-710 FIREFIGHTERS’ PENSION AND RETIREMENT SYSTEM.
   (A)   There is hereby created a local Firefighters’ Pension and Retirement
Board composed of the Mayor, the Clerk, the Treasurer and three members from
the Fire Department. The Board shall have the membership, organization, powers,
duties and functions as prescribed by 11 O.S. §§ 49-103 et seq.
   (B)   It is hereby declared to be the purpose and intention of the city, by
this article, to adopt the firefighters’ pension system as provided by the laws
of the state.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. §§ 50-101 et seq., 50-106.3, 50-109 and 50-
110
ARTICLE C. EMPLOYEE RETIREMENT SYSTEM
§2-720 SYSTEM ESTABLISHED.
   Pursuant to the authority conferred by the laws of the state, and for the
purpose of encouraging continuity and meritorious service on the part of city
employees and thereby promote public efficiency, there is hereby authorized,
created, established, approved and adopted, effective January 1, 1963, the
pension plan designated “employee retirement system” of the city (hereinafter
called “system”) and all amendments thereto. The provisions of the employee
retirement system, as adopted by ordinance, and all amendments thereto, are
hereby adopted and incorporated herein by reference.
§2-721 ADMINISTRATION, TRUSTEES.
   (A)   For the purpose of managing and administering the employee retirement
system, there is hereby created a Board of Trustees which shall be known as the
Board of Trustees of the employee retirement system.
   (B)   The Board of Trustees shall be composed of five members, of which two
department heads or employees shall be appointed by the City Council from the
various departments, and the members may be removed at any time by the City
Council. The City Clerk and Treasurer shall be a member of the Board and act as
Treasurer of the retirement system. The two other Board of Trustees members
shall be two other employees of the city who shall be elected in the manner
hereinafter provided.

2-815   Minutes
   
2-816   Special committee
   
2-817   When public hearing required
   
2-818   Items previously voted on by Council
§2-801 RULES OR ORDER OF PROCEDURE.
   (A)   The rules or order of procedure herein contained shall govern
deliberations and meetings of the City Council and additionally shall govern
deliberations and meetings of the Public Utilities Authority.
   (B)   In all sections contained hereunder where it appears that where
procedures apply to the City Council all rules and regulations shall also apply
to the Public Utilities Authority.
§2-802 REGULAR MEETINGS.
   Regular meetings of the Council/Board of Trustees shall be held at 5:15 p.m.
at the City Council chambers, 18 South 7th Street on the second and fourth
Tuesdays of the month; except when the fourth Tuesday is on December 23 through
26, the Council/Board of Trustees may, by resolution, reschedule, upon majority
vote of those members of the Council/Board of Trustees present. Any meeting of
the Council/Board of Trustees may extend until 12:00 a.m. of the day of the
meeting.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-803 SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   Special meetings may be held at the call of the Mayor or any three Council
members/Trustees on notice given at least 48 hours prior to the special
meeting. In the case of an emergency, an emergency meeting may be held on such
notice as may be reasonable and possible under the circumstances.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-804 QUORUM.
   A quorum authorized to conduct business shall consist of a majority of all
members elected to and constituting the Council. Less than a quorum may adjourn
from day to day.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-805 PRESIDING OFFICER.
   (A)   The presiding officer for each meeting shall be the Mayor, or in his
or her absence, the Vice Mayor.
   (B)   If both the Mayor and Vice Mayor be absent, the Council/Board of
Trustees member most senior in service on the Council shall initially preside
for the purpose of calling the meeting to order the electing a presiding
officer who shall then preside over the remainder of the meeting.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-806 MEETINGS OPEN TO PUBLIC.
   (A)   All meetings, regular and special, shall be open to the public, and no
person shall be barred unless he or she is disorderly or refuses to obey the
order of the Mayor, who may order the Chief of Police or any attending police
officer to eject any such person.
   (B)   The Police Department shall have at least one officer present at each
Council meeting. The Council may meet in executive sessions only as authorized
by the City Charter and state statutes.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-807 AGENDA SCHEDULE.
   An agenda schedule for each meeting of the Council shall be prepared by the
City Manager to ensure that city business is conducted in an efficient manner.
This policy is designed to respect the time of those persons who come before
the Council through the normal procedure of placing items on the agenda. The
State Open Meeting Law, being 25 O.S. §§ 301 et seq., shall be strictly adhered
to in conduct of the meetings and the agenda schedule. No item shall be voted
on by the Council without having been placed on the Council agenda unless it is
of an emergency nature and could not have been foreseen. To provide for timely
preparation and distribution of the agenda, all items must be submitted to the
City Manager’s office no later than 1:00 p.m. on the Thursday immediately
preceding the next Tuesday’s Council meeting.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-808 ORDER OF BUSINESS.
   The order of business shall be as follows:
   (A)   Call to order;
   (B)   Invocation;
   (C)   Roll call;
   (D)   From the office of the Mayor. Items in this section shall include, but
not be limited to, the following:
      (1)   Recognition of city employees for awards or honors;
      (2)   Recognition of distinguished visitors or groups such as Boy Scouts,
Allied Officers, DeMolays and the like; or
      (3)   Expression of condolence to families on demise of prominent
citizens, civic leaders and the like.
   (E)   Consent agenda:
      (1)   The Council/Board of Trustees shall act on all items in this
section by a single motion and roll call vote, subject to questions, discussion
or the right of any member to delete any item for individual action;
      (2)   Items on the consent agenda shall include, but not be limited to,
consideration of the following:
         (a)   Preliminary plans and authorization for preparation of final
plans and specifications;
         (b)   Change orders;
         (c)   Final plans and authorization for advertisement of bids;
         (d)   Acceptance of final plats and improvements;
         (e)   Easements, acceptance or dedication;
         (f)   Set dates for public hearings;
         (g)   Internal fund transfers requiring excise board approval or
supplemental appropriations;
         (h)   Acceptance of annual audit reports (various);
         (i)   Annual lease agreements;
         (j)   Acknowledge receipt of State Health Department permits
(various);
         (k)   Award bids and authorize contract execution;
         (l)   Reject bids and authorize readvertisement;
         (m)   Mayor’s appointments;
         (n)   Basic claims, payroll claims, longevity claims; or
         (o)   Council/Board of Trustees minutes.
   (F)   Council’s and citizens’ scheduled presentations:
      (1)   When a citizen contacts the Mayor or Council and requests to be on
the agenda for a specific presentation, the request must be relayed to the
Mayor’s or City Manager’s office prior to agenda deadline with citizen’s name,
address, subject of presentation and available background information.
      (2)   The Council shall have the option of voting on the item or
referring it to staff for additional information.
      (3)   Each presentation shall be listed on the agenda in this section by
name, address and subject. Time limits set out for audience participation will
apply;
   (G)   New business:
      (1)   In setting the order of items requiring individual action, the
Mayor shall give priority to:
         (a)   Public hearings;
         (b)   Matters that may attract a large number of interested citizens
to the meeting; or
         (c)   Other matters that may attract interested parties such as claims
recommended for denial.
   (H)   Audience participation:
      (1)   In compliance with the State Open Meeting Law, being 25 O.S. §§ 301
et seq., the Council/Board of Trustees shall not vote on items presented during
this section of the meeting;
      (2)   Each person shall have a maximum of three minutes to state his or
her business;
      (3)   Each subject shall have a maximum of 12 minutes; and
      (4)   After such time as the individual or the discussion of a particular
subject is completed, the Council/Board of Trustees shall recommend to the
individual or group as to what action they should take, i.e., refer the
situation to a particular department or person at the city offices or suggest
they place the item on a Council agenda;
   (I)   Executive session;
   (J)   Reports: Mayor, City Manager, Council/Board of Trustees:
      (1)   Reports by the Council/Board of Trustees should be limited to those
matters of general interest to the whole Council; or
      (2)   Routine reports that concern the interest of only the ward or an
isolated situation that does not affect other Council members/Trustees or areas
of the city should be processed through normal channels.
   (K)   Adjournment.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-809 ORDER OF DISCUSSION OF EACH AGENDA ITEM.
   Discussion of each agenda item shall be in the following order.
   (A)   City Manager or city staff. After the Mayor calls the particular
agenda item for consideration, the City Manager or staff shall present any
matters in addition to the printed agenda commentary which may be pertinent to
the item.
   (B)   Public participation.
      (1)   During public hearings, citizens and interested parties may address
the Council/Board of Trustees as a matter of “right” subject to reasonable time
limitations to expedite Council business.
      (2)   On all other matters, public participation shall be at the
discretion of the Council.
   (C)   Council members. After the staff and public have presented their
views, the City Manager, Mayor and Council/Board of Trustees shall proceed to
discuss the merits of the issue; this portion of the discussion shall be
limited to the City Manager, Mayor and Council/Board of Trustees unless the
Mayor or Council/Board of Trustees determines additional information is needed
from the staff or public at that time.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-810 RULES OF DISCUSSION.
   Rules of discussion shall be as follows.
   (A)   No Council/Board of Trustees member shall speak without recognition
from the Mayor, and no member shall speak more than twice on a specific item
without permission of the Mayor.
   (B)   A person who is not a member of the Council shall not be allowed to
address the same without permission of the Mayor.
   (C)   Each person addressing the Council/Board of Trustees shall address his
or her remarks to the Council/Board of Trustees generally rather than to a
specific member.
   (D)   Discussions shall be limited to the matter presently before the
Council/Board of Trustees. Speakers shall confine their remarks to the merits
of the particular measure and avoid comments which would tend to embarrass
other persons or attack their motives.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-811 MOTIONS.
   After preliminary discussion of an agenda item, the Mayor shall call the
matter for determination by the Council/Board of Trustees.
   (A)   Main motion. Any member of the Council desiring to offer a motion on a
particular agenda item shall so indicate by raising his or her hand to obtain
the Mayor’s recognition.
   (B)   Seconding the motions. Members desiring to second motions shall so
indicate to the Mayor by raising their hands.
   (C)   Recognition for motions and seconds. To the extent reasonably
possible, the Mayor shall recognize Council/Board of Trustees members for the
offering and seconding of motions on an alternating basis so that all Council/
Board of Trustees members have an opportunity to offer and second main motions
during a meeting.
   (D)   Special courtesy. Where a matter is of special concern to a particular
Council/Board of Trustees member, he or she may prior to the beginning of the
meeting advise the Mayor of his or her desire to offer or second the motion on
that particular agenda item. Absent conflicting requests, the Mayor shall so
recognize the requesting member for the purpose of submitting the motion or
seconding. In the event of conflicting requests, the Mayor may recognize any
one of the requesting Council members if they are unable to resolve the
conflict among themselves.
   (E)   Typical motions.
      (1)   Main motion: “I move....”;
      (2)   Amendments:
         (a)   “I move to amend the motion by inserting between ... and ...”;
         (b)   “I move to amend the motion by adding after...”;
         (c)   “I move to amend the motion by striking out...”;
         (d)   “I move to amend the motion by striking out... and
inserting...”; and
         (e)   “I move to amend by striking out the motion and substituting the
following...”
      (3)   Committee: “I move that this motion be referred to a committee of
the Council/Board of Trustees for further consideration and report back to the
Council/Board of Trustees no later than.....”;
      (4)   Call for questions: “I move the previous question two-thirds vote
required; stops debate and order an immediate vote”;
      (5)   Table: “I move that this item be tabled indefinitely” (or to a date
certain);
      (6)   Award of contracts: “I move that the bid of ... be approved for
award, pending the signing of the contract and furnishing of required bonds,
and that the Mayor be authorized and directed to sign the contract for and on
behalf of the city”;
      (7)   Adoption of ordinance: “I move the adoption of ordinance no.      
entitled ... and that the reading of the ordinance be waived”;
      (8)   Adoption of resolution: “I move the adoption of a resolution
entitled...”;
      (9)   Claims: “I move that the Council/Board of Trustees approve/reject
the claim of ... (in the amount of ... )”; and
      (10)   Consent agenda: “I move the approval of the consent agenda items”.
   (F)   Lack of motion or second. If no member offers a motion on an agenda
item, the Mayor shall again call for motions; if no motion is presented after
the second calling, the Mayor shall declare the item fails for lack of motion.
Similarly, if no one seconds another member’s motion, the Mayor shall declare
that the motion fails for lack of a second;
   (G)   Debate of motions. Upon a motion having been offered and seconded, the
Mayor shall state the motion and submit it for further debate by the Council/
Board of Trustees if desired. Debate shall be limited to the merits of the
agenda item and addressed to the Mayor;
   (H)   Amendments to motions.
      (1)   Any time prior to the Mayor’s calling for vote of the Council/Board
of Trustees, a member may move to amend the motion, which shall require a
second. An amendment must be germane to the main motion;
      (2)   Two amendments can be made to any main motion, a primary amendment
and a secondary amendment. In order to avoid confusion, a third amendment shall
not be permitted. A Council/Board of Trustees member may, in the course of
debate on the secondary amendment announce that if the secondary amendment
fails, he or she intends to introduce another secondary amendment and may
briefly state the nature and content thereof.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-812 VOTING.
   (A)   (1)   After allowing a reasonable but not unduly lengthy time for
debate of the motion, the Mayor shall put the question to a vote. The Clerk
shall call the roll of Council members present and record each vote. Council
members may vote “yes,” “no” or “abstain.”
      (2)   Where a Council/Board of Trustees member has withdrawn from
consideration of an issue because of conflict of interest, he or she shall
“abstain.” The Mayor will announce the vote or he or she shall request the
Clerk to announce the vote.
      (3)   A Council/Board of Trustees member may change his or her vote only
before the results of the vote are announced by the Mayor.
   (B)   Amendments shall be voted on prior to the main motion, with secondary
amendments voted on prior to primary amendments.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-813 ROBERT’S RULES OF ORDER TO GOVERN.
   The latest revision of Robert’s Rule Of Order is incorporated into these
rules and shall govern all matters not specifically addressed in these rules.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-814 ATTENDANCE.
   The City Manager, Clerk, Attorney and Finance Director (or their assistants)
shall attend all regular and special meetings of the Council/Board of Trustees.
Attendance of other city personnel shall be required only when there are agenda
items which affect their particular responsibility.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-815 MINUTES.
   (A)   Minutes of each meeting of the Council/Board of Trustees shall be
prepared by the Clerk and submitted to a subsequent Council meeting for
approval.
   (B)   The minutes shall summarize the Council’s deliberations and record the
action of the Council on each item. The Clerk shall maintain a record of the
approved minutes.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-816 SPECIAL COMMITTEE.
   On his or her own determination, or on vote of the Council/Board of
Trustees, the Mayor may from time to time appoint a special committee, two
members (if more than two, must comply with Open Meeting Act, being 25 O.S.
§§ 301 et seq.,) of the Council, to investigate and study a particular matter
in depth and report to the Council/Board of Trustees its findings and
recommendations. Each committee shall consist of two members. If requested by
the special committee of the Council/Board of Trustees, the City Manager shall
appoint a member of the city’s staff to serve in a nonvoting capacity in order
to assist the committee. The committee’s report shall be submitted for such
actions as may be appropriate.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-817 WHEN PUBLIC HEARING REQUIRED.
   (A)   When an item appears on the City Council/Board of Trustees agenda
which requires three (four for bond issues) or more affirmative votes for
passage, and one or more members of the City Council/Board of Trustees are
absent from the meeting where the item is originally considered, if not
approved, such item shall be continued or rescheduled for a vote thereon at the
next regular meeting of the City Council.
   (B)   When the agenda item requires a public hearing, the Mayor shall recess
the public hearing and take a vote of the City Council/Board of Trustees.
Should the vote decide the issue, the Mayor shall close the public hearing and
announce the vote. Should the vote not decide the issue and the results be such
that the issue is to be continued, the Mayor shall continue the public hearing
to the next regular meeting of the City Council/Board of Trustees.
   (C)   An exception to the procedures established in this section shall be
allowed when an absent Council/Board of Trustees member requests that the
agenda item be returned to the Council/Board of Trustees agenda, with
concurrence of the Mayor, when the vote of the absent Council/Board of Trustees
member could alter the outcome of the issue.
   (D)   When the Mayor is absent and the question requires three affirmative
votes for passage and the vote is two to two, the item will be continued or
rescheduled for the next regular meeting of the City Council/Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987)
§2-818 ITEMS PREVIOUSLY VOTED ON BY COUNCIL.
   (A)   An item previously decided by the City Council may be placed on the
agenda as a new item of business under the following circumstances:
      (1)   The item is placed on the agenda by two or more Council members who
voted with the prevailing side by providing a signed letter to the City
Manager, if proposed for the next regularly scheduled meeting as provided in
division (A)(1)(b) below:
         (a)   In order to be reconsidered at the City Council meeting, a
motion and second to the motion must be made by members who voted with the
prevailing side. For the purpose of this division (A)(1)(a), PREVAILING SIDE is
defined as one who voted “aye” if the motion involved was adopted and “no” if
the motion was defeated; and
         (b)   A reconsideration can only be made at the same meeting of the
original adoption or defeat of the item, or the next following regularly
scheduled meeting. Special meetings are not included.
      (2)   Annually, when Council members have been sworn into office and the
item was voted on by the previous administration.
   (B)   This section shall not be applicable to the initiation, prosecution,
defense or settlement of litigation brought by or against the city, its
employees or agencies.
(Ord. 1267, passed 2-10-1987; Ord. 1662, passed 10-23-2007)
CHAPTER 9: AUDIT COMMITTEE
Section
   
2-901   Establishment
   
2-902   Approval of nominees
   
2-903   Term and replacement of members
   
2-904   Renomination
   
2-905   Functions
   
2-906   Meetings
   
2-907   Interference with fiscal responsibilities
§2-901 ESTABLISHMENT.
   The Mayor shall nominate two individuals to serve on the City Audit
Committee. The Audit Committee, as appointed by the Mayor, shall consist of two
seated Council members. The Audit Committee shall elect an individual who will
act as Chairperson of the Committee and perform such administrative duties as
provided by ordinance.
(Ord. 1484, passed 4-26-1999)
§2-902 APPROVAL OF NOMINEES.
   Said nominees, as appointed by the Mayor, in accordance with §
2-901, shall be approved by a majority vote of the City Council.
(Ord. 1484, passed 4-26-1999)
§2-903 TERM AND REPLACEMENT OF MEMBERS.
   (A)   The members of the Audit Committee shall serve a term of two years
from the date of appointment or until such sooner time when said Council member
leaves office.
   (B)   Upon the occurrence of a Council member leaving office, the Mayor
shall immediately appoint a seated Council person to serve the remainder of the
term.
(Ord. 1484, passed 4-26-1999)
§2-904 RENOMINATION.
   The Mayor, at his or her discretion, at the expiration of the term of any
Audit Committee member, may re-nominate a serving committee member for an
additional two-year term.
(Ord. 1484, passed 4-26-1999)
§2-905 FUNCTIONS.
   The Audit Committee shall be established in order to provide the following
functions:
   (A)   To review applications submitted to the city by those individuals
desiring to conduct the annual audit for the city;
   (B)   To make recommendations to the Council in selection of qualified
certified public accountant or accountants who shall conduct an independent
audit of the accounts and evidence of financial transactions of the Department
of Finance and all other departments, offices and agencies, keeping separate or
subordinate accounts or making financial transactions as of the end of every
fiscal year;
   (C)   To act as a liaison between the selected auditor and the city;
   (D)   To review all audit results with the auditor, the City Manager and the
City Treasurer; and
   (E)   To make recommendations to the auditor which may provide for a more
expedient and efficient audit procedure.
(Ord. 1484, passed 4-26-1999)
§2-906 MEETINGS.
   The Audit Committee will meet when deemed necessary or at the request of the
Chairperson of the Committee.
(Ord. 1484, passed 4-26-1999)
§2-907 INTERFERENCE WITH FISCAL RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Audit Committee may not direct any action which shall interfere with the
fiscal responsibilities of the City Manager or City Treasurer as dictated by
Charter, statute or city ordinance.
(Ord. 1484, passed 4-26-1999)
CHAPTER 10: TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION
Section
   
2-1001   Commission established
   
2-1002   Appointment and terms
   
2-1003   Duties
§2-1001 COMMISSION ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby established a Telecommunications Commission consisting of
five members to be recommended by the Mayor. The City Council shall confirm the
Mayor’s recommendations. The Commissioners shall be appointed for overlapping
three-year terms and shall serve until their respective successors have been
appointed and qualified.
(Ord. 1330, passed - -1992)
§2-1002 APPOINTMENT AND TERMS.
   (A)   The Commissioners shall assume their duties upon appointment. However,
at the time of initial appointment, the Mayor shall identify those Commission
seats which will first become vacant. The successor term of two Commissioners
first appointed shall begin at 7:30 p.m. on the first Monday in May 1993, the
successor terms of two Commissioners first appointed shall begin at 7:30 p.m.
on the first Monday in May 1994, and the successor term of one Commissioner
first appointed shall begin at 7:30 p.m. on the first Monday in May 1995:
   (B)   Each Commissioner shall then serve a term of three years;
   (C)   Every year, at a time prescribed for the beginning of the term of a
new member or members or as soon thereafter as practicable, the Commission
shall elect a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. The Commission shall determine
the time and place of its regular meeting. The Mayor, the Chairperson or any
three members may call a special meeting;
   (D)   The manner of conducting business shall be determined by the members.
However, the Commission shall at all times comply with the guidelines of the
Open Meeting Act, being 25 O.S. §§ 301 et seq., even if not required by state
law;
   (E)   The Mayor may remove members for the good of the city and fill
vacancies for unexpired terms; and
   (F)   The City Clerk or his or her designated representative will take the
minutes of all meetings.
(Ord. 1330, passed - -1992)
§2-1003 DUTIES.
   The Telecommunications Commission shall identify, review and assess the
telecommunication needs for the city. The Commission shall become familiar with
federal and state rules, regulations and laws which govern telecommunications.
In addition, the Commission shall monitor those individuals, companies,
partnerships or corporations which are grantees named in a nonexclusive cable
franchise or permit to ensure compliance with the franchise or permit. The
Commission shall make recommendations to the City Council on all matters
dealing with telecommunications such as, but not limited to, control,
maintenance, improvements, operations, compliance with permits, rates as
permitted by law and renewal of existing permits.
(Ord. 1330, passed - -1992)
CHAPTER 11: GRANT ADMINISTRATION
Section
   
2-1101   CDBG-EDIF job tracking
§2-1101 CDBG-EDIF JOB TRACKING.
   If the city is at any time a recipient of funds, either as a grant, loan or
combination of grant and loan, from the program available through the State
Department of Commerce and identified as the community development block grant/
economic development infrastructure financing (CDBG-EDIF) program, the city
shall require that any entity or beneficiary using the CDBG-EDIF funded
infrastructure improvements must agree to provide job tracking data as a
condition of using the improvements. The job tracking data must be provided for
a period of time starting with the date the state awards the CDBG-EDIF funds to
the city and will end one year after the physical completion of the public
improvements.
(Ord. 1482, passed 3-23-1999)
   Duncan - Alcoholic Beverages

§3-101 PURPOSES OF CHAPTER.
   This chapter is enacted as an exercise of the police power of the city to
preserve the public peace, safety, health and good order thereof, and to aid
the enforcement of the policy of the state as established by the State
Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, 37 O.S. §§ 501 et seq., and to establish annual
license fees upon all licenses issued to persons engaged in the manufacture,
sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages.
§3-102 TERMS AND PHRASES.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions, and those
defined by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, shall apply unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BOTTLE CLUB. Any establishment in a county which has not authorized the
retail sale of alcoholic beverages by the individual drink, which is required
to be licensed to keep, mix and serve alcoholic beverages belonging to club
members on club premises.
   MINOR. A person who, in accordance with state law, has not yet attained the
age at which consumption of alcoholic beverages is permitted.
   PACKAGE STORE. Any sole proprietor or partnership that qualifies to sell
wine, beer and/or spirits for off-premises consumption and that is not a
grocery store, convenience store or drug store, or other retail outlet that is
not permitted to sell wine or beer for off-premises consumption.
   STATE LICENSEE. Any person who holds a license issued under authority of the
State Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, being 37A O.S. §§ 1-101 et seq.
(Ord. 1875, passed 4-22-2025)
§3-103 LICENSE FEES.
   (A)   There is hereby imposed an annual fee not to exceed the amounts
indicated below upon the occupations named. Said licenses shall entitle the
holder of same to all the rights and privileges provided by municipal ordinance
as well as the state.
Beer distributor (effective October 1, 2018) per year $500
Beer and wine                                         $500 initial
                                                      $450 renewal
Bottle club                                           $1,000 initial
                                                      $900 renewal
Brewer, per year                                      $1,250
Brewpub, if licensee also holds a mixed beverage or   $50
wine and beer permit, per year
Brewpub, per year                                     $1,000
Caterer                                               $1,005 initial
                                                      $900 renewal
Class B wholesaler                                    $625
Class I beer license (available and effective only    $20
through September 30, 2018)

   (B)   The fees prescribed herein shall be reduced or prorated to the extent
necessary to conform to applicable laws respecting the applicants or holders of
state licenses.
   (C)   The license fee for those service organizations which are exempt under
I.R.C. § 501(c)(19) for mixed beverage or bottle club licenses shall be $500
per year.
   (D)   The holder of a valid certificate for a bottle club may convert such
certificate to a mixed beverage certificate at any time prior to its expiration
upon presentation of a state license to operate a mixed beverage business in
the same location as the previously licensed and taxed bottle club.
(Ord. 1259, passed 9-23-1986; Ord. 1782, passed 7-24-2018)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 37 O.S. § 518
§3-104 WHEN DUE AND POSTING.
   (A)   Any state licensee originally entering upon any occupation herein
listed shall pay the license fee therefor at the office of the City Treasurer
on or before the date upon which he or she enters upon such occupation. The
licensee shall provide a copy of his or her current state license before
payment of a license fee will be accepted. All license fees shall expire on
June 30 of each year.
   (B)   Any state licensee carrying on his or her occupation in more than one
location within the city limits shall be subject to the fee set out for each
such location.
   (C)   Upon payment of the license fee as set out, the City Treasurer shall
issue a receipt to the state licensee which licensee shall post in a
conspicuous place on the premises wherein he or she carries on his or her
occupation. The City Treasurer shall also record the name of such licensee and
the address where he or she engages in his or her occupation and such records
shall be duly filed and kept in the permanent files of that office for at least
three years. Thereafter, upon approval of the City Council, the records may be
destroyed.
   (D)   The City Treasurer shall make and transmit to the State Alcoholic
Beverage Laws Enforcement (ABLE) Commission an annual report covering the
fiscal year showing the number and class of businesses upon which license fees
were imposed and the amount of money collected from such fees.
§3-105 PAYMENT REQUIRED.
   Any person who engages in any of the licensed activities regulated by this
chapter without first paying the license fee imposed therefor in advance of
such operation is guilty of an offense against the city and, upon conviction
thereof, shall be punished as provided in §
1-108. A penalty may be levied upon any person not paying the fee within 15
days after it is due.
§3-106 CIVIL PENALTY.
   All sums due from any person, firm or corporation by reason of licensing
fees imposed by this chapter shall be recoverable at the suit of the city
brought against such person in any court of competent jurisdiction. In such
suit, in addition to the fee, the city shall be allowed to recover interest at
the maximum allowable rate permitted by state law upon all sums due by way of
fee, from the date of accrual thereof, any penalty, and all costs of
collection, judicial or otherwise, including reasonable attorneys’ fees.
Prosecution for an offense against the city arising out of the failure to pay a
fee levied by this chapter, regardless of the outcome or its continued
pendency, shall not constitute a defense or a bar in any manner to the
collection of any fees and penalties, if any are due, as herein provided.
§3-107 APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE; INVESTIGATIONS.
   (A)   Every applicant for a certificate of compliance with the zoning, fire,
health and safety codes of the city required by 37 O.S. shall apply at the
office of the Clerk by:
      (1)   Filing a written application on forms prescribed by that office;
and
      (2)   Paying a verification and certification fee in the amount as set by
the Council at the time of filing.
   (B)   Upon receipt of an application for a certificate of compliance, the
city shall cause an investigation to be made to determine whether the premises
proposed for licensed operations comply with the provisions of the zoning
ordinance and any health, fire, building and other safety codes applicable to
it.
   (C)   The city shall act on all such applications within 20 days of receipt
thereof.
§3-108 ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATE OF ZONING AND CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE.
   (A)   Upon finding that the premises of an applicant for a certificate is in
compliance with all applicable zoning ordinances, a certificate of zoning shall
be issued to the ABLE Commission.
   (B)   Upon finding that the premises of an applicant for a certificate is in
compliance with all applicable fire, safety and health codes, a certificate of
compliance shall be issued to the ABLE Commission.
   (C)   The above certificates of compliance shall be signed by the City
Manager.
   (D)   A conditional certificate may be granted if construction, modification
or alteration of the premises proposed for licensed operations is not
completed. The conditional certificate shall indicate that the proposed
premises will comply with city zoning, fire, safety and health codes. A
certificate in accordance with divisions (A) and (B) above shall be issued
within ten days after all final inspections are complete.
§3-109 CONDITION OF SALE.
   (A)   No person shall sell or deliver alcoholic beverages out of any retail
alcoholic beverage store other than:
      (1)   In retail containers;
      (2)   At ordinary room temperatures;
      (3)   In the original package; and
      (4)   For consumption off the premises.
   (B)   No person owning, employed in or in any manner assisting in the
maintenance and operation of such a store shall suffer or permit any alcoholic
beverage to be consumed, or any retail container of such beverage to be opened
on the premises of such a store.
§3-110 CONSUMPTION PROHIBITED, WHERE.
   No person shall drink or consume in any manner any alcoholic beverage on the
premises of a retail alcoholic beverage package store, nor in any other public
place. Neither shall a person open or break the seal of any original package or
retail container containing alcoholic beverages on the premises of any such
retail beverage store.
§3-111 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No person shall sell at retail or otherwise, and no person shall deliver, in
consequence of or in completion of such a sale, any alcoholic beverages at any
place in the city except at a retail alcoholic beverage store in strict
conformity with this chapter and the laws of the state.
§3-112 COMPLIANCE WITH ZONING REGULATIONS REQUIRED.
   (A)   No retail alcoholic beverage package store, no bottle club and no
wholesale alcoholic beverage store, warehouse, brewery, distillery, winery or
any other place, however described, and for the manufacture or production or
bottling of alcoholic beverages of any kind, shall be located, maintained or
operated by any person, at any place within the boundaries of the city except
at a location at which such an establishment is permitted or authorized by the
zoning ordinances of the city.
   (B)   No person shall own, operate, maintain or be interested in any retail
alcoholic beverage store which is located at a place within the city limits
which is in violation of or forbidden as a location by the city or under the
laws of the state.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 37 O.S. § 534
§3-113 PROHIBITED LOCATION.
   The location of a retail package store, mixed beverage establishment or
bottle club is specifically prohibited within three hundred feet (300) feet
from any church property primarily and regularly used for worship services and
religious activities, or public school. If any such church or school, shall be
established within 300 feet of any licensed premises after such premises have
been licensed, this shall not be a bar to the renewal of such license so long
as there has not been a lapse of more than sixty (60) days. The distance
indicated in this section shall be measured from the nearest property line of
such church or school to the nearest perimeter wall of the premises of such
package store, mixed beverage establishment or bottle club. A church may waive
the three hundred foot (300') requirement by providing written notice to the
establishment seeking the license and to the ABLE commission. Provided a church
prior to waiving the three hundred foot (300') requirement found in this
subsection shall publish a notice of its intention to waive such requirement in
a legal newspaper of general circulation within the state at least thirty (30)
days but no more than forty (40) days prior to providing any written notice,
waiving the three hundred foot (300') requirement, to the establishment seeking
the license or the ABLE commission.
(Ord. 1875, passed 4-22-2025)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 37 O.S. § 518.3
§3-114 PROHIBITED SALES.
   (A)   No person shall knowingly sell, deliver or furnish alcoholic
beverages, at any place within the city limits to any person who is a minor.
Neither shall any minor misrepresent his or her age verbally or in writing, or
present false documentation of age or otherwise for the purpose of inducing any
other person to sell him or her alcoholic beverages.
   (B)   No person shall sell, deliver or knowingly furnish alcoholic beverage
or beverages within the city to an intoxicated person or to any person who has
been adjudged insane or mentally deficient.
§3-115 TRANSPORTING BEVERAGES.
   No person shall knowingly transport in any vehicle upon a public highway,
street or alley any alcoholic beverage except in the original container which
shall not have been opened and the seal upon which shall not have been broken
and from which the original cap or cork shall not have been removed, unless the
opened container be in the rear trunk or rear compartment, which shall include
the spare tire compartment in a vehicle commonly known as a station wagon and
panel truck, or any outside compartment which is not accessible to the driver
or any other person in the vehicle while it is in motion.
§3-116 PROHIBITED EMPLOYMENT.
   No minor shall be employed in the selling, manufacture, distribution or
other handling of alcoholic beverages at any place within the city. No person
shall employ or assist or aid in causing the employment of any minor at any
place within the city in the selling, manufacture, distribution or other
handling of alcoholic beverages. No minor shall be permitted to remain within
or to loiter about the premises of a retail alcoholic beverage store. Violation
of this provision shall subject the owner or proprietor, as well as the
underage person, to prosecution.
§3-117 HOURS FOR SELLING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.
   (A)   Retail spirits stores.
      (1)   Now and through September 30, 2018, no person shall open or operate
a retail spirits store except between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m.
Effective October 1, 2018, retail spirits stores will be permitted to remain
open and operational from 8:00 a.m. through 12:00 a.m.
      (2)   Further, no person shall open or operate a retail spirits store at
any time on Sunday of any week, on New Year’s Day, Thanksgiving Day or
Christmas Day.
   (B)   Wholesale dealers. No wholesale dealer in alcoholic beverages, and no
officer, agent or employee of such a dealer shall sell or deliver to any retail
alcoholic beverage store within the city any amount of spirits or wines on
Sunday of any week, on New Year’s Day, Thanksgiving Day or Christmas Day.
   (C)   Retail beer or retail wine stores. Effective October 1, 2018, a retail
wine or retail beer establishment may offer wine or beer for retail sale on
Monday through Sunday between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m. the
following day.
(Ord. 1782, passed 7-24-2018)
§3-118 INTOXICATION IN PUBLIC PLACE PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person shall be in any public place in a state of intoxication.
   (B)   For the purpose of this section, a STATE OF INTOXICATION means the
condition in which a person is under the influence of drugs, intoxicating
liquors or low point beer to such an extent as to deprive the person of his or
her full mental or physical power or be unable to exercise care for his or her
own safety or the safety of others.
§3-119 NOT TO PERMIT INTOXICATED PERSON IN CAFÉ, CLUB.
   No person operating a café, restaurant, club or any place of recreation
within this city, and no employee engaged in connection with the operation of
such a café, restaurant, club or place of recreation shall permit any person to
be drunk or intoxicated in the place of business.
§3-120 PENALTY.
   Any and each violation of any of the provisions of this chapter is an
offense against the city and, upon conviction of such an offense, the violator
shall be punished as provided in §
1-108.
§3-121 GATHERINGS WHERE MINORS ARE CONSUMING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.
   (A)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      ALCOHOL. Ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, from
whatever source or by whatever process produced.
      ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE.
         (a)   Includes alcohol, spirits, liquor, wine, beer and every liquid
or solid containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer and which contains 0.5% or
more of alcohol by volume and which is fit for beverage purposes either alone
or when diluted, mixed or combined with other substances.
         (b)   This term includes intoxicating beverages and LOW POINT BEER as
defined herein.
      GATHERING. A party, gathering or event, where a group of three or more
persons have assembled or are assembling for a social occasion or social
activity.
      INTOXICATING BEVERAGE. Includes beverages containing more than 3.2%
alcohol by weight.
      LEGAL GUARDIAN.
         (a)   A person who, by court order, is the guardian of the person of a
minor; or
         (b)   A public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by
the court.
      LOW POINT BEER. Includes beverages containing more than 0.5% of alcohol
by volume, and not more than 3.2% alcohol by weight, including, but not limited
to, beer or cereal malt beverages obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of an
infusion of barley or other grain, malt or similar products.
      MINOR. Any person under 21 years of age.
      PARENT. A person who is a natural parent, adoptive parent, foster parent
or stepparent of another person.
      PREMISES. Any residence or other private property, place or premises,
including any commercial or business premises.
      RESPONSE COSTS. The costs associated with responses by law enforcement,
fire and other emergency response providers to a gathering, including, but not
limited to:
         (a)   Salaries and benefits of law enforcement, code enforcement, fire
or other emergency response personnel for the amount of time spent responding
to, remaining at or otherwise dealing with a gathering, and the administrative
costs attributable to such response(s);
         (b)   The cost of any medical treatment for any law enforcement, code
enforcement, fire or other emergency response personnel injured responding to,
remaining at or leaving the scene of a gathering;
         (c)   The cost of repairing any city equipment or property damaged,
and the cost of the use of any such equipment, in responding to, remaining at
or leaving the scene of a gathering; and
         (d)   Any other allowable costs related to the enforcement of this
section.
   (B)   Consumption of alcohol by minor. Except as permitted by state law, it
is unlawful for any minor to consume at any public place or any place open to
the public any alcoholic beverage; or consume at any place not open to the
public any alcoholic beverage, unless in connection with the consumption of the
alcoholic beverage that minor is being supervised by his or her parent or legal
guardian.
   (C)   Hosting, permitting or allowing a gathering prohibited.
      (1)   (a)   It is the duty of any person having control of any premises,
who knowingly hosts, permits or allows a gathering at said premises to take all
reasonable steps to prevent the consumption of alcoholic beverages by any minor
at the gathering.
         (b)   Reasonable steps are controlling access to alcoholic beverages
at the gathering; controlling the quantity of alcoholic beverages present at
the gathering; verifying the age of persons attending the gathering by
inspecting drivers’ licenses or other government issued identification cards to
ensure that minors do not consume alcoholic beverages while at the gathering;
and supervising the activities of minors at the gathering.
         (c)   It is unlawful for any person having control of any premises to
knowingly host, permit or allow a gathering to take place at said premises
where at least one minor consumes an alcoholic beverage, whenever the person
having control of the premises either knows a minor has consumed an alcoholic
beverage or reasonably should have known that a minor consumed an alcoholic
beverage had the person taken all reasonable steps to prevent the consumption
of an alcoholic beverage by a minor as set forth in division (C)(1)(a) above.
      (2)   This section shall not apply to conduct involving the use of
alcoholic beverages that occurs exclusively between a minor and his or her
parent or legal guardian.
      (3)   Nothing in this section should be interpreted to prohibit any
family activity held in the confines of the family home from providing the use
of alcohol to immediate family members within the supervision of parents and
guardians. However, if a minor leaves such a family gathering intoxicated and
is found in public then said providers of alcohol will be held responsible in
the same manner as a non-family gathering.
      (4)   Nothing in this section should be interpreted to prohibit any
religious practice which includes the use of alcohol. However, if a minor
leaves such a religious gathering intoxicated and is found to be in public,
then said providers of alcohol will be held responsible in the same manner as a
nonreligious gathering.
      (5)   This section shall not apply to any premises licensed by the state
to dispense alcoholic beverages.
   (D)   Penalty. Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section
shall be deemed guilty of an offense against the city and, upon conviction
thereof, shall be punished for violation of an offense, with fine not to exceed
$500, or by imprisonment not exceeding 60 days, or by both such fine and
imprisonment, plus all court costs and statutory penalties, as set forth in §
1-108 (B).
   (E)   Reservation of legal options. Violations of this section may be
prosecuted by the city criminally, civilly and/or administratively as provided
by this code.
      (1)   The city may seek administrative fees and response costs associated
with enforcement of this section through all remedies or procedures provided by
statute, ordinance or law.
      (2)   This section shall not limit the authority of peace officers or
private citizens to make arrests for any criminal offense arising out of
conduct regulated by this section, nor shall they limit the city’s ability to
initiate and prosecute any criminal offense arising out of the same
circumstances necessitating the application of this section.
   (F)   Local authority. This section shall not apply where prohibited or
preempted by state or federal law.
(Ord. 1661, passed 10-23-2007)
§3-122 ALCOHOL OCCUPATIONAL TAX.
   (A)   No person shall operate or maintain a brewery or brewpub without
having previously paid the occupational tax as provided in this chapter.
   (B)   No person shall operate or maintain any business serving mixed
beverages or beer or wine without having previously paid the occupational tax
as provided in this chapter.
(Ord. 1782, passed 7-24-2018)
§3-123 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BREWER. Any person who manufacturers for human consumption by the use of raw
materials or other ingredients any beer upon which an occupational tax is
imposed.
   BREWPUB. A licensed establishment operated on the premises of, or on
premises located contiguous to, a small brewery, which prepares and serves food
and beverages, including alcoholic beverages, for on-premises consumption.
   CLASS I BEER LICENSE.
      (1)   A license for the retail sale of a beverage containing more than
0.5% alcohol by volume and not more than 3.2% alcohol by weight, sold for
consumption on the premises, or sold not in the original containers for
consumption on or off the premises.
      (2)   CLASS I BEER LICENSES are only available and effective through
September 30, 2018.
   CLASS II BEER LICENSE.
      (1)   A license for the retail sale of a beverage containing more than
0.5% alcohol by volume and not more than 3.2% alcohol by weight, sold in the
original containers for consumption off the premises.
      (2)   CLASS II BEER LICENSES are only available and effective through
September 30, 2018.
   MIXED BEVERAGE/CATERER. An occupational tax permit for sale of mixed
beverages as specifically provided by state law for the holder of a mixed
beverage license or a caterer license.
   ON-PREMISES BEER AND WINE. An occupational tax permit for the retail sale of
beer containing more than 3.2% of alcohol by weight and wine which means and
includes any beverage containing more than 0.5% of alcohol by volume and not
more than 24% alcohol by volume. Effective October 1, 2018, this occupational
tax permit will apply to the sale of both low point and strong beer, as those
terms are defined in 37A O.S. § 1-103.
(Ord. 1782, passed 7-24-2018)
§3-124 BREWERY OR BREWPUB HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No brewery or brewpub to which the brewery or brewpub occupational tax is
applicable, nor any agent, servant or employee of such establishment shall
sell, dispense, serve or allow to be consumed any beer on the premises between
the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m.
(Ord. 1782, passed 7-24-2018)
§3-125 MIXED BEVERAGE, BEER OR WINE HOURS OF OPERATION.
   (A)   No establishment to which the mixed beverage or on-premises beer and
wine occupational tax is applicable, nor any agent, servant or employee of such
establishment shall sell, dispense, serve or allow to be consumed any mixed
beverages, beer or wine on the premises between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 8:00
a.m.
   (B)   Elective through September 30, 2018, no person who holds a Class I
beer license, nor any agent, servant or employee of said licensee, shall sell,
dispense, serve or allow to be consumed any low-point beer on the premises
between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m., Monday through Saturday, and
between 2:00 a.m. and 12:00 p.m. on Sunday.
   (C)   Effective through September 30, 2018, and except as herein provided,
no person who owns, manages or operates any business serving mixed beverages,
beer or wine or a Class I establishment zones as a bar, club or tavern licensed
under the authority of this chapter shall permit any person to remain on the
premises past the applicable closing time; provided, that a maximum of eight
persons shall be permitted to remain for two hours past the applicable closing
time, so long as they are employed by the business serving mixed beverages,
beer or wine or the Class I establishment and are involved in cleaning, closing
or otherwise securing the premises.
(Ord. 1782, passed 7-24-2018)
§3-126 EMPLOYMENT.
   No person shall employ any person under 18 years of age in the selling of
beer or wine or employ any person under 21 years of age in the selling of
spirits. Provided:
   (A)   A mixed beverage, beer and wine, caterer, public event, special event,
bottle club, retail wine or retail beer licensee may employ servers or
salesclerks who are at least 18 years of age, except persons under 21 years of
age may not serve in designated bar or lounge areas; and
   (B)   A mixed beverage, beer and wine, caterer, public event, special event
or bottle club licensee may employ or hire musical bands who have musicians who
are under 18 years of age if each such musician is either accompanied by a
parent or legal guardian or has on his or her person, to be made available for
inspection upon demand by any employee of the ABLE Commission or law
enforcement officer, a written, notarized affidavit from the parent or legal
guardian giving the underage musician permission to perform in designated bar
or lounge areas.
(Ord. 1782, passed 7-24-2018)
§3-127 MIXED BEVERAGE OR BEER AND WINE CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE.
   (A)   A mixed beverage or beer and wine certificate of compliance, on forms
furnished by the city, shall be completed by every applicant for an original
license pursuant to the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, being 37A O.S. §§
1-101 et seq.
   (B)   This certificate shall be reviewed and approved by the following city
departments.
      (1)   The applicant’s proposed location and use thereof must comply with
all municipal zoning ordinances, verified by the Director of Planning and
Community Development, or his or her designee.
      (2)   The applicant’s proposed site and structure must comply with all
Building Codes as required by this code, verified by the Director of Planning
and Community Development, or his or her designee.
      (3)   The applicant’s proposed site, structure and location must comply
with all Fire Code requirements required by this code, verified by the fire
inspector for the city or his or her designee.
      (4)   The applicant’s proposed location and use thereof must comply with
all provisions regarding food service requirements as required by this code,
verified by the County Health Department inspector or his or her designee.
(Ord. 1782, passed 7-24-2018)
§3-128 RETAIL ESTABLISHMENT OCCUPATIONAL TAX.
   No person shall operate, manage or work in any retail establishment that
sells, for off-premises consumption only, any type of alcoholic beverage, as
that term is found in 37 O.S. § 506 through September 30, 2018, and as found in
37A O.S. § 1-103 thereafter without having previously obtained an occupational
tax permit for that store as provided in this chapter.
(Ord. 1782, passed 7-24-2018)
§3-129 RETAIL SPIRITS, RETAIL BEER AND RETAIL WINE CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE.
   (A)   A retail spirits, retail beer and retail wine certificate of
compliance, on forms furnished by the city, shall be completed by every
applicant for an original license pursuant to the State Alcoholic Beverage
Control Act, being 37A O.S. §§ 1-101 et seq.
   (B)   This certificate shall be reviewed and approved by the following city
departments.
      (1)   The applicant’s proposed location and use thereof must comply with
all municipal zoning ordinances, verified by the Director of Planning and
Community Development, or his or her designee.
      (2)   The applicant’s proposed site and structure must comply with all
Building Codes as required by this code, verified by the Director of Planning
and Community Development, or his or her designee.
      (3)   The applicant’s proposed site, structure and location must comply
with all Fire Code requirements required by this code, verified by the fire
inspector for the city or his or her designee.
      (4)   The applicant’s proposed location and use thereof must comply with
all provisions regarding food service requirements as required by this code,
verified by the County Health Department inspector or his or her designee.
(Ord. 1782, passed 7-24-2018)

§3-201 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   LOW POINT BEER. All beverages containing more than 0.5% alcohol by volume
and less than 3.2% alcohol by weight.
   MINOR. A person who, according to state law, has not yet attained the age at
which consumption of low point beer is permitted under state law.
   PLACE OF BUSINESS. Each separate location or service unit in which or from
which low point beer is sold, delivered or otherwise furnished.
   RETAIL DEALER. Any person who sells any “low point beer” as defined herein
for consumption or use and not for resale.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 37 O.S. §§ 163.1 et seq.
§3-202 HOURS OF SALE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person licensed to sell beverages containing
more than 0.5% of alcohol by volume and not more than 3.2% of alcohol by weight
to sell, dispense or serve such beverages for consumption on the premises
between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. or allow such beverages to be
consumed on the premises between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. excepting
Saturday nights when such beverages may not be sold, dispensed, served or
consumed on the premises between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 12:00 p.m. on
Sundays.
(Ord. 1249, passed - -)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 37 O.S. § 213
§3-203 LICENSE FEES.
   There is hereby levied on each retail dealer in low point beer within the
city selling such low point beer for consumption on or off the premises of the
dealer’s place of business, a license fee of $20 per annum, and on each retail
dealer selling such low point beer exclusively in original packages (of not
less than case lots) and not for consumption on his or her premises, a license
fee of $10 per annum. A separate license fee shall be paid for each place of
business, as herein defined, operated and conducted by the retail dealer.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 37 O.S. § 163.7
§3-204 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (A)   It is unlawful and an offense for any person to sell, distribute or
dispense within the city any low point beer to the public for consumption or
use without first having obtained a license therefor from the City Treasurer.
Every person desiring to engage in business as a retail dealer in low point
beer or to continue in the business within the city shall make application to
the City Treasurer on forms to be provided, setting forth the locations of the
business, together with the applicant’s address, and if a corporation, the name
of the president and managing officer. The application shall show the date and
permit number of the permits issued by the district court judge and the State
Tax Commission as required by law.
   (B)   (1)   Upon a showing that the applicant has obtained his or her
permits from the district court judge and the State Tax Commission and after
payment of the license fee to the city such license shall be issued forthwith.
      (2)   All licenses shall expire on June 30 of each year. Licenses issued
hereunder shall not be assignable or transferable, and the fee shall not be
prorated for part of the year.
      (3)   The city license shall be displayed in the licensee’s place of
business. The license may be canceled for any violation of the laws of the
state for which the licensee’s county or state license may be canceled, and in
a similar manner.
§3-205 NOT TO SELL TO MINORS.
   It is unlawful for any person to sell, offer, give away, procure for,
furnish, barter or otherwise dispense to any minor any low point beer, or for
any minor to purchase, receive or procure any low point beer.
(Ord. 1211, passed 9-27-1983)
§3-206 POSSESSION, CONSUMPTION BY MINORS.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, POSSESSION shall consist of actual
physical possession and shall further include any low point beer accessible or
within the range of reach of hands of any such person.
   (B)   It is unlawful for a minor to consume or be in possession of any low
point beer while such person is upon any public street, avenue, alley, road,
highway or public building or place or on any city owned property.
(Ord. 1211, passed 9-27-1983)
§3-207 PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN NOT TO BE EMPLOYED.
   (A)   (1)   It is unlawful for any owner, manager, operator or employee of a
place where low point beer is sold for consumption on the premises to employ a
person under 18 years of age to work in such place; or for any person under 18
years of age to work in such place.
      (2)   This division (A) shall not apply to any licensed premises where
sales of low point beer do not exceed 25% of the gross sales of the licensee.
   (B)   (1)   It is unlawful for any minor to be employed or permitted to work
in any capacity whatsoever in the separate or enclosed bar area of a place
where the main purpose of the area is the sale or consumption of low point
beer.
      (2)   This division (B) shall not apply to any area which has as its main
purpose some objective other than the sale or serving of low point beer, in
which sales or serving of low point beer is incidental to the main purpose.
(Ord. 1211, passed 9-27-1983)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 37 O.S. § 243
§3-208 NOT TO PERMIT MINORS TO FREQUENT BARS, EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   The owner of any bar, beer hall, tavern or other place wherein any low
point beer is dispensed for consumption on the premises shall not permit any
minor to be admitted to, enter or to remain in a separate enclosed bar area of
the licensed premises which has as its main purpose the selling or serving of
low point beer for consumption on the premises unless the person’s legal
guardian or parent is present, nor shall any minor enter or remain about such
separate or enclosed bar area.
   (B)   This section shall not prohibit minors from being admitted to,
entering or remaining in an area which has as its main purpose some objective
other than the sale or serving of low point beer, in which sales or serving of
low point beer is incidental to the main purpose, if the minors are not sold or
served or do not consume low point beer.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 37 O.S. §§ 241 and 246
§3-209 MISREPRESENTING AGE.
   It is unlawful for any person to misrepresent his or her age to any retail
dealer, as herein defined, for the purpose of obtaining, or attempting to
obtain any low point beer, as herein defined, for consumption upon the premises
of such retail dealers.
§3-210 NOT TO FURNISH OR SELL TO INTOXICATED PERSONS.
   No holder of a retail license or permit to sell low point beer, or an
employee or agent of a holder of such a license or permit, shall knowingly,
willfully and wantonly sell, deliver or furnish low point beer or any other
alcohol to an intoxicated person.
§3-211 INTOXICATING LIQUORS NOT ALLOWED ON PREMISES.
   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation engaged in the retail
sale of any low point beer to allow any person or persons to drink on the
premises where such beverages are sold or offered for sale, any wine, whiskey,
brandy or other alcoholic beverages.
§3-212 UNLAWFUL TRANSPORTATION OF LOW POINT BEER.
   It is unlawful for any person knowingly to transport in any moving vehicle
upon a public street or alley, or any public way within this city any low point
beer unless it is:
   (A)   In the original container, which shall not have been opened and from
which the original cap or seal shall not have been removed; or
   (B)   If it is in an opened container, the opened container is in the rear
trunk or rear compartment, which shall include the spare tire compartment in a
station wagon or panel truck, or any outside compartment which is not
accessible to the driver or to any other person in the vehicle while it is in
motion.
§3-213 PROHIBITED LOCATION.
   (A)   (1)   It shall be unlawful for any place which has received a permit
or which has been licensed to sell low point beer and which has as its main
purpose the selling or serving of low point beer for consumption on the
premises to be located within 300 feet of any public or private school or
church property primarily and regularly used for worship services and religious
activities.
      (2)   The distance indicated in this division (A) shall be measured from
the nearest property line of the public or private school or church to the
nearest perimeter wall of the premises of the place which has received a permit
or which has been licensed to sell low point beer. These restrictions shall not
apply to places which have received a permit previously.
   (B)   If any school or church shall be established within 300 feet of any
place subject to the provisions of division (A) above after the place has
received a permit or been licensed, the provisions herein shall not be a
deterrent to the renewal of the permit or license if there has not been a lapse
of more than 60 days.
   (C)   When any place subject to the provisions of this section which has a
permit or license to sell low point beer for on-premises consumption changes
ownership or the operator thereof is changed, and the change results in the
same type of business being conducted on the premises, the provisions of this
section shall not be a deterrent to the issuance of a license or permit to the
new owner or operator if he or she is otherwise qualified.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 37 O.S. § 163-24
§3-214 PENALTY.
   Any and each violation of any of the provisions of this chapter is an
offense against the city and, upon conviction of such an offense, the violator
shall be punished as provided in §
1-108.
PART 4: ANIMAL REGULATIONS
Chapter
   
1.    GENERAL PROVISIONS

4.    DOGS AND CATS
