§5-401 ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR AND QUALIFICATIONS.
   The office of Electrical Inspector is hereby created. He or she may be the
Building Official unless another person is appointed by the City Manager.
Pursuant to 59 O.S. § 40A, he or she shall have at least three years of active
experience in the electrical industry and shall have no interest, direct or
indirect, in any firm or corporation engaged in the electrical industry.
Pursuant to O.A.C. Title 158, Chapter 60, he or she shall be properly licensed
with the State Construction Industry Board.
(Ord. 1863, passed 10-8-2024)
§5-402 DUTIES.
   It is the duty of the Electrical Inspector to inspect all electrical
installations withing 48 hours after having been notified that work is ready
for inspection, Fridays, Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays are not
included. It is the duty of the Electrical Inspector to keep a daily record of
all his or her work, including all notices and applications received, permits
and certificates granted, and all violations of this chapter and other matters
which may pertain thereto.
(Ord. 1863, passed 10-8-2024)
§5-403 WORK NOT TO BE CONCEALED BEFORE INSPECTION.
   It is unlawful for any persons to conceal or cause to be concealed any
electrical conductors used for electric light, heat or power, until such work
has been approved and a certificate of completion or tag properly signed and
dated, so stating, has been issued by the Electrical Inspector.
(Ord. 1863, passed 10-8-2024)
§5-404 PAYMENT OF INSPECTION FEES.
   (A)   (1)   Inspection fee charges shall be made and collected in such
amounts as set out by the Council by motion or resolution.
      (2)   For failed and after-hour/holiday inspections (see §
5-402), the minimum fee charged shall be one and one-half times the minimum fee
or the schedule of inspection fees, whichever is greater.
      (3)   For reinspection or return trips to reexamine and inspect
electrical work, the minimum fee or the schedule of inspection fees, whichever
is greater, shall be charged. In no event shall the Electrical Inspector allow
or permit electrical installations to be connected to service lines until such
time as all fees for inspection and reinspection have been paid in full.
   (B)   All inspection fees required to be paid under and by virtue of this
chapter shall be paid to the City Treasurer and be placed in the General Fund
in and for the city.
(Ord. 1863, passed 10-8-2024)
§5-405 CONTRACTORS NOT TO CONNECT UNTIL WORK APPROVED.
   It is unlawful for any person, firm, partnership, corporation or individual
to conceal or cause to be concealed any electrical conductors used for electric
light, heat or power, until such time as they know work has been approved and a
certificate of completion or tag properly signed and dated, so stating, has
been issued by the Electrical Inspector.
(Ord. 1863, passed 10-8-2024)
§5-406 EXEMPTIONS.
   For the installation of telephone or signal systems not using over 12 volts,
no registration or bond will be required as set out hereinafter, but the
installation of same must comply with the Electrical Code adopted by the city.
(Ord. 1863, passed 10-8-2024)
§5-407 RIGHT OF INGRESS.
   The Electrical Inspector, while in the discharge of his or her duty, shall
have the authority to enter any building or premises at any reasonable hour,
and any person interfering with the Electrical Inspector while performing his
or her duty shall be guilty of a public offense.
(Ord. 1863, passed 10-8-2024)
§5-408 APPEAL PROCESS.
   The Electrical Inspector shall interpret and enforce the electrical codes as
adopted by the city. Any appeals filed with the Building Official shall be
based on a claim that the true intent of this code or the rules legally adopted
thereunder have been incorrectly interpreted, the provisions of this code do
not fully apply or an equally good or better form of construction is proposed.
The Board shall not have authority to waive the requirements of this code as
adopted by the city.
(Ord. 1863, passed 10-8-2024)
§5-409 NATIONAL ELECTRICAL CODE ADOPTED.
   The state-wide minimum electrical codes as adopted codes by the State
Uniform Building Code Commission (O.A.C. § 748:20, Subchapter 10) known as the
National Electrical Code, NFPA 70, and/or NEC latest edition (2023), with such
changes and additions amendments, as may be made from time to time, are hereby
made a part of this chapter, and adopted and incorporated herein by reference
as if set out in full herein. At least one copy of the code and list are on
file in the office of the Department of Community Development.
(Ord. 1862, passed 10-8-2024; Ord. 1863, passed 10-8-2024)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 59 O.S. § 1000.23
§5-410 REGISTRATION REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS.
   (A)   All persons, firms, partnerships, corporations or individuals, engaged
or hereafter engaging in the business of installing electrical fixtures, wiring
or apparatus in or on any building within the corporate limits of the city
(except central power station, powerhouses and substations belonging to the
electric light company) shall procure from the city a certificate of
registration. Upon payment of a fee as set by the City Council and showing
proof of possession of the appropriate and current state license, the
certificate shall entitle the holder to install electrical conductors, fixtures
or apparatus, within the corporate limits of the city until the birth date of
the licensee next succeeding after all provisions of this chapter have been
complied with. An electrical contractor shall pay to the City Treasurer the sum
for registration annually in such amount as set by the Council which shall
entitle the electrical contractor to engage in his or her trade within the
city. Registrations shall be renewed prior to the anniversary date of initial
registration of each year to be considered a renewal and shall expire on the
end of the birth month of the licensee or registrant. Any request for renewal
of a certificate must be received by the city within 30 days after the
expiration date of the certificate, along with the required fees and proof of
state license. No prorating of the license is allowed. Electrical contractors
are responsible for the registration of all licensed journeyman and registered
apprentices working under his or her license.
   (B)   Exempt from the provisions of this registration requirement are owners
of property and minor repairs as defined specifically in State Electrical
License Act, 59 O.S. §§ 1624 through 1641, or the National Electrical Code as
adopted by State Uniform Building Code Commission.
(Ord. 1863, passed 10-8-2024)
Cross-reference:
    See also
Chapter 17  of this part
§5-411 PERMIT NECESSARY FOR ELECTRICAL WORK.
   No person, firm or corporation, or officer, receiver, representative or
employee of any corporation shall do, or cause to be done, any interior or
exterior wiring or any construction, installation or alteration of any
electrical wiring apparatus or fixtures within the city without first having
complied with the provisions of this chapter and without first having obtained
a permit for the particular work as required by the Electrical Code from the
Department of Community Development. The Electrical Inspector shall not issue a
stamp of approval or otherwise authorize current connected until the provisions
of this chapter and the Electrical Code of the city have been fully complied
with.
(Ord. 1863, passed 10-8-2024)
§5-412 TEMPORARY SERVICE PERMITS.
   The Electrical Inspector may grant temporary electrical service permits for
a period of 90 days with the privilege of extending same at the discretion of
the Electrical Inspector upon the payment of a fee as set by the Council for
each 90 days plus inspection fees.
§5-413 TEMPORARY POLE METER SERVICE PERMITS.
   The Electrical Inspector may grant a permit for temporary pole meter service
for a period not to exceed 180 days with the privilege of extending same at the
discretion of the Electrical Inspector. A fee as set by the Council shall be
paid for each 180 days or less period and for every extension of same, plus
inspection fees.
(Ord. 1863, passed 10-8-2024)
§5-414 PENALTY.
   Any person found violating any provision of this chapter or any code adopted
herein shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in §
1-108.
(Ord. 1863, passed 10-8-2024)

§5-501 RESIDENTIAL CODE ADOPTED.
   The International Residential Code (IRC), the latest edition thereof, and
any amendments thereto, as recommended by the International Code Council, is
hereby adopted as the Housing Code of the city for the control of buildings and
structures as therein provided. Each and all of the regulations of the
Residential Code are hereby referred to, adopted, incorporated and made a part
of this code by reference, as if fully set out in this code, with the
additions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in this chapter. At least
one copy of the code is kept on file in the office of the City Clerk.
(Ord. 1799, passed 12-10-2019)
§5-502 ADDITIONS AND CHANGES.
   The following sections of the Residential Code are hereby revised as
follows:
   (A)   The City of Duncan shall be inserted for the name of the jurisdiction;
and
   (B)   The penalty for violation of the code shall be as provided in §
1-108 in the city’s code of ordinances.
CHAPTER 6: MECHANICAL CODE

§5-601 MECHANICAL OFFICIAL.
   The office of Mechanical Official is hereby created. The Mechanical Official
may be the Building Official or other person appointed by the City Manager
meeting the applicable qualifications of state law.
(Ord. 1404, passed 7-31-1996)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 59 O.S. §§ 1850.1 et seq.
§5-602 DUTIES OF MECHANICAL OFFICIAL.
   (A)   It is the duty of the Mechanical Official to inspect all mechanical
work performed in the city.
   (B)   The Mechanical Official may, as far as necessary in the performance of
his or her duties, enter in the daytime, any building or premises inside the
corporate limits of the city.
   (C)   It is the duty of the Mechanical Official to keep a daily record of
all his or her work, including all notices and applications received, permits
and certificates granted, and all violations of this chapter and other matters
which may pertain thereto.
(Ord. 1404, passed 7-31-1996)
§5-603 REGISTRATION REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS.
   (A)   Every person, firm or corporation, before engaging in the mechanical
trade in the city shall pay to the City Treasurer a registration fee for the
purpose of regulating the business, the sums as set by Council by motion or
resolution for mechanical contractors, journeymen and apprentices, payable in
advance to be deposited in the General Fund of the city. The registration fee
herein assessed shall be construed to be exacted from each establishment or
place of business in the city, and not from the individual employees of
mechanical contractors, firms or establishments. The city shall issue
certificates and receipts for all sums of money collected under this provision
to the person, firm or corporation paying the same. No certificate or receipt
may be issued until the applicant shows proof of possession of the appropriate
state license. No certificate shall extend beyond the birth date of the
licensee of any year. Any request for renewal of a certificate must be received
by the city within 30 days after the expiration date of the certificate, along
with the required fees and proof of state license. No prorating of the license
is allowed.
   (B)   Exempt from the provisions of this registration requirement are owners
of property and minor repairs as defined specifically in the State Mechanical
License Law, 59 O.S. §§ 1850.1 et seq.
(Ord. 1404, passed 7-31-1996; Ord. 1596, passed 1-25-2005)
Cross-reference:
    See also
Chapter 17  of this part
§5-604 ADOPTION OF MECHANICAL CODE.
   A certain document, at least one copy of which is on file in the office of
the City Clerk, being marked and designated as the International Mechanical
Code, the latest edition thereof, and any appendices, revisions or amendments
thereto, as published by the Building Officials and Code Administrators
International and the International Conference of Building Officials, is hereby
adopted as the Mechanical Code of the city regulating the design, construction,
quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location,
relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of the mechanical
systems. Each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and
terms of the Mechanical Code are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part
hereof, as if fully set out in this code, with additions, insertions and
changes, if any, prescribed in this chapter.
(Ord. 1404, passed 7-31-1996; Ord. 1801, passed 12-10-2019)
§5-605 ADDITIONS, INSERTIONS AND CHANGES TO MECHANICAL CODE.
   The following sections are hereby revised as follows:
   (A)   Section 101.1 (page 1), insert: the City of Duncan;
   (B)   Section 106.5.2 (page 4), insert: as set by the city;
   (C)   Section 106.5.3 (page 4), insert: as determined by the Mechanical
Official;
   (D)   Section 108.4 (page 5), insert: offense and punished as provided in §
1-108 of the city’s code of ordinances; and
   (E)   Section 108.5 (page 5), insert: as provided in §
1-108 of the city’s code of ordinances.
(Ord. 1404, passed 7-31-1996)
§5-606 INSPECTION.
   All mechanical work and installations inside of private property lines in
the city must be done or installed in accordance with the provisions of the
adopted Mechanical Code and must be inspected by the Mechanical Official and a
certificate of inspection issued therefor, before the same may be used. The
fees shall be as set by the Council by motion or resolution.
(Ord. 1404, passed 7-31-1996)
§5-607 FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH MECHANICAL RULES.
   Should the Mechanical Official refuse to issue a certificate of approval on
any work due to failure to comply with the mechanical rules and regulations the
official shall notify the person(s) doing the work to make such changes and
revisions as are required to comply with the mechanical rules and regulations.
Such notice shall provide that the required changes and revisions be
accomplished within not more than three days of the date of notice of failure
to comply.
(Ord. 1404, passed 7-31-1996)
§5-608 RECOURSE TO MECHANICAL SURETY AND PENALTY.
   (A)   In the instance of failure or refusal on the part of a mechanical
contractor to rectify or change such mechanical work so as to cause same to
comply with the mechanical rules and regulations, then, after three days from
the time notice was given, the owner of any house or premises may have recourse
against the principal and sureties on the bond required to be kept on file with
the State Department of Health.
   (B)   In the instance of failure of any person(s) to comply with a notice to
correct, rectify or change mechanical work so as to cause same to comply with
the mechanical rules and regulations, following notice from the Mechanical
Official, or in the instance of violation of any provision of the Mechanical
Code or the provisions of this chapter, the Mechanical Official may initiate
action for violation of the mechanical rules and regulations in municipal
court. Each day that such failure to comply or violation is permitted to
continue may constitute a separate offense. Any person found guilty of a
violation of the mechanical rules and regulations may be punished in accordance
with the provisions of §
1-108.
(Ord. 1404, passed 7-31-1996)
CHAPTER 7: MOVING BUILDINGS
Section
   
5-701   Permit required; fee
   
5-702   Application and fees for permit
   
5-703   Bond required for permit
   
5-704   Caution signs
   
5-705   Protection of trees and overhead structures
   
5-706   Guards against danger
   
5-707   Limit to size of building
   
5-708   Time limit
   
5-709   No permit issued, when
   
5-710   Notice to Fire, Police Departments

§5-701 PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, partnership or
individual to move or cause to be moved on the streets or alleys of the city
any house or building, or part thereof, or any similar structure, without
having first obtained from the Building Official a permit therefor. The
applicant for a permit shall pay the City Treasurer a sum as set by the City
Council for each such permit and shall deposit with the City Treasurer of the
city a good and sufficient bond as required in this chapter.
   (B)   It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, partnership or
individual to move or cause to be moved any house or building, or part thereof,
or any similar structure, on the streets or alleys of the city without having
first obtained such permit, paid such permit fee and deposited such bond with
the city.
§5-702 APPLICATION AND FEES FOR PERMIT.
   The permit shall be obtained by making application therefor in writing. The
written application shall recite the character of the thing or object to be
moved and transported along or through and upon the streets and avenues, the
proposed route of such transportation and the place where any equipment used in
effecting such transportation shall be placed and secured.
§5-703 BOND REQUIRED FOR PERMIT.
   No permit shall be issued as by the terms of this chapter until such time as
the applicant shall have deposited with the officer issuing such permit a cash
bond in such sum as may be reasonably necessary to protect the city and cover
all loss from damage accruing to it or its citizens by reason of any negligence
or improper occupancy of the streets, sidewalks and any and all property
therein. Any negligence or improper occupancy of the streets, sidewalks or
other public places shall be provided against in the bond and such bond shall
be deposited upon the understanding that it is to cover all of the conditions
as set forth in this section. All such persons as described herein, engaged as
principals in the business herein described, shall file a surety bond to be
approved by the city in the sum of $1,000 conditioned, that such person shall
save, indemnify and keep harmless the city against any and all liabilities,
judgments, damages, costs and expenses which may in any way accrue against the
city, in consequence of the granting of such permit or while acting under the
same, and will under all circumstances strictly comply with the terms of such
license and permit. Any such surety bond shall not be in any manner affected by
the fact of the cash deposit and bond required hereunder. Any such person as
referred to herein or his or her laborer, servant or agent or employee, shall
cause a sufficient passageway to be kept open for vehicles to pass on one side
or both sides of any building, structure, edifice, object or thing, while the
same is being moved upon any street, avenue or alley, and when possible, the
same shall be kept moving each day unless the actual elements render this
impossible.
§5-704 CAUTION SIGNS.
   It is the duty of the permittee to place warning lights plainly visible for
not less than 200 feet on each and every side of the building or structure
which is being moved at the close of day and to keep same on throughout the
entire night and until one hour after sunrise on the morning following. Such
lights shall be so placed and maintained that the view of same will not be in
any sense obstructed. If necessary, as many additional lights as may be
necessary shall be placed at such other points on the building or structure as
will enable any person of reasonable and ordinary prudence to take notice of
the obstruction.
§5-705 PROTECTION OF TREES AND OVERHEAD STRUCTURES.
   The person who may have a permit to move a building or structure over any
street within the city shall by virtue of such permit and license derive no
right to injure or impair the condition or usefulness of any shade tree,
electric light, telephone or telegraph poles or lines. No tree of any kind
shall be cut, bruised, scarred under any circumstances, without the expressed
permission in writing of the owner of the same and with the permission of the
Building Official or Public Works Director. In all cases where necessary to
remove any electric light, telephone or telegraph construction, it shall be the
duty of the person moving such building or structure to give not less than 24
hours’ notice to the public utility company or person owning or operating the
same, which notice shall state the place, the construction which it is
necessary to be removed, or temporarily changed or altered and the day on which
it is desired to have such clearance made as well as the amount of time it will
be necessary to keep such space clear. It is the duty of the person moving the
building or structure to deposit an amount of money estimated necessary to
cover the cost of the changing or moving of public utility overhead
construction and replacing the same in its former condition in a sum as set by
the city with the City Treasurer. Upon such deposit being made with the City
Treasurer, and such notice being delivered to the owner or operator of the
telephone or telegraph and line construction, it is the duty of the person
owning or operating the overhead construction to make such temporary changes as
are reasonably necessary to comply with the representations set forth in the
notice made and delivered to him or her.
§5-706 GUARDS AGAINST DANGER.
   It is the duty of the house mover to station sufficient persons on guard and
to establish such notices by placards or boards in the immediate vicinity of
the moving activities as will be necessary to apprise any reasonable person of
any potential danger that might be incurred by coming closer to the moving
operations or buildings being moved or the instruments or agencies used in the
moving of the same.
§5-707 LIMIT TO SIZE OF BUILDING.
   No permit shall be issued to move any building which in the judgment of the
Building Official or Public Works Director might by any chance result in an
injury to the pavements, bridges, conduits or other street improvements within
the city.
§5-708 TIME LIMIT.
   At the time of application for a permit, it is the duty of the mover of any
building or structure to estimate the reasonable time required for the moving
of the building from its present location to its proposed location and shall
state in his or her application for permit what he or she deems to be such
reasonable time. The mover shall bind himself or herself to pay a sum as set by
the city per day for each and every day, all or any part of which the building
or structure remains on the street in excess of the number of days allowed in
the permit, and his or her cash deposit in addition to his or her bond shall be
made liable for the payment of the amount. Nothing but an act of God shall be a
defense against the payment of the sums.
§5-709 NO PERMIT ISSUED, WHEN.
   The city shall not issue any permit on any day, which according to the
estimated number of days required to move the building or structure, shall when
counted from the date of the permit include a Sunday or legal holiday; provided
that this shall apply where the permit includes and provides that the persons
moving such house shall begin on the day of the permit. When a day is set on
which the person moving the building shall begin to move the same and the day
is different from the date of issuing the permit, then no permit shall be
issued in such a way to include a Sunday or holiday within the time allowed for
moving the building. Where the number of days shall exceed five, the provisions
of this section shall not apply.
§5-710 NOTICE TO FIRE, POLICE DEPARTMENTS.
   Any person desiring to move any building shall show his or her permit to the
Chiefs of the Fire and Police Departments. If for any reason any delay is
occasioned by any unforeseen contingency, it is his or her duty to inform the
Fire and Police Chiefs, of such facts, to the end that the Fire and Police
Chiefs may keep accurate and recent information on the true conditions of the
streets and alleys for fire prevention purposes.
§5-711 LIABILITY.
   No provision or condition of this chapter shall be construed so as to limit
the liability civilly of any person moving any house on or over the city
streets, avenues and alleys from any and all damages which may result as the
proximate cause of such acts to any person or his or her property or to the
city.
CHAPTER 8: DILAPIDATED BUILDINGS
Section
   
5-801   Nuisance declared; report to be made
   
5-802   Definitions
   
5-803   Removal; boarding and securing; adoption of state law
   
5-804   Method of abatement
   
5-805   Collection of costs
   
5-806   Clearing premises from which buildings have been removed
   
5-807   Penalty
§5-801 NUISANCE DECLARED; REPORT TO BE MADE.
   (A)   It is hereby declared to be a public nuisance for any person to suffer
or permit on premises within the city any dilapidated or unsecured buildings as
defined herein.
   (B)   Any officer or employee of the city who discovers or receives a report
or complaint of a dilapidated or unsecured building shall report such
conditions to the Building Official or such other department or official as the
City Manager may designate. Upon receiving and verifying the report or
equivalent information from any reliable source, said official shall abate such
conditions as provided in this chapter or in any other manner as this code
provides.
(Ord. 1503, passed 4-25-2000)
§5-802 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DILAPIDATED BUILDING.
      (1)   A structure which through neglect or injury lacks necessary repairs
or otherwise is in a state of decay or partial ruin to such an extent that the
structure is a hazard to the health, safety or welfare of the general public;
      (2)   A structure which is unfit for human occupancy due to the lack of
necessary repairs and is considered uninhabitable or is a hazard to the health,
safety and welfare of the general public;
      (3)   A structure which is determined by the administrative officer of
the City Council to be an unsecured building, as defined herein, more than
three times within any 12-month period;
      (4)   A structure which has been boarded and secured, as defined herein,
for more than 36 consecutive months; or
      (5)   A structure otherwise declared by the City Council to constitute a
public nuisance.
   UNSECURED BUILDING. Any structure which is not occupied by a legal or
equitable owner thereof, or by a lessee of a legal or equitable owner, and into
which there are one or more unsecured openings such as broken windows, unlocked
windows, broken doors, unlocked doors, holes in exterior walls, holes in the
roof, broken basement or cellar hatchways, unlocked basement or cellar
hatchways or other similar unsecured openings which would facilitate an
unauthorized entry into the structure.
(Ord. 1503, passed 4-25-2000)
§5-803 REMOVAL; BOARDING AND SECURING; ADOPTION OF STATE LAW.
   (A)   The provisions of 11 O.S. § 22-112, and all subsequent amendments
thereto, are hereby adopted for the removal and dismantling of dilapidated
buildings. Notice of the hearing to determine whether a building is dilapidated
shall be given concurrently by posting a copy of the notice on the property
affected and by mail to the property owner and mortgage holder, if any, without
necessity for publication.
   (B)   The provisions of 11 O.S. § 22-112.1 and all subsequent amendments
thereto are hereby adopted for the boarding and securing of unsecured
buildings. Notice of the hearing to determine whether an unsecured building
should be boarded and secured shall be given in the same manner as for the
removal of dilapidated buildings. Said notice may be given concurrently with
notice of other hearings on the condition of the property or dilapidated
buildings thereon and may include additional notice of summary abatement, if
anticipated.
   (C)   The City Manager or his or her designee is hereby authorized to carry
out the duties of the City Council for the removal, dismantling or boarding and
securing of dilapidated or unsecured buildings, and for the assessment of costs
incurred in the abatement thereof. The City Manager may continue a hearing from
time to time for the convenience of the parties. An appeal from any order of
the City Manager may be taken by filing written notice of appeal with the City
Clerk within ten days after the order is rendered.
(Ord. 1503, passed 4-25-2000)
§5-804 METHOD OF ABATEMENT.
   (A)   The City Manager may accomplish the removal, dismantling or boarding
and securing of buildings by force account or private contract, and he or she
is authorized to execute contracts in furtherance of the same.
   (B)   If done on a private contract basis, the contract shall be awarded to
the lowest and best bidder according to such rules and regulations as the City
Council may prescribe.
(Ord. 1503, passed 4-25-2000)
§5-805 COLLECTION OF COSTS.
   (A)   At any time prior to the collection of costs for removal, dismantling
or boarding and securing as provided by law, the city may pursue any civil
remedy for collection of the amount owing and interest thereon, including an
action in personam against the owner and an action in rem to foreclose the
city’s lien against the property.
   (B)   Upon receiving payment, if any, the City Clerk shall forward to the
County Treasurer a notice of such payment and directing discharge of the lien.
(Ord. 1503, passed 4-25-2000)
§5-806 CLEARING PREMISES FROM WHICH BUILDINGS HAVE BEEN REMOVED.
   In all cases in which a house or building has been completely or partially
removed, dismantled or demolished upon the volition of the owner, or pursuant
to this code, or as otherwise provided by state law, then the owner or owners
of the premises shall have the premises cleaned up and left entirely free from
trash, including, but not limited to:
   (A)   The removal of all lumber, brick, concrete, cement, plaster, nails,
wire and other materials;
   (B)   Filling in any cellar space and excavations;
   (C)   Filling in or safely and securely closing any cistern or well, and
plugging all openings to the sanitary sewer according to the requirements of
the plumbing inspector; and
   (D)   Leveling the premises.
(Ord. 1503, passed 4-25-2000)
§5-807 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm or corporation that maintains a public nuisance as provided
herein, or that fails or refuses to comply with the requirements of this
chapter, shall be guilty of an offense against the city and, upon conviction
thereof, shall be punished as provided in §
1-108.
(Ord. 1503, passed 4-25-2000)
CHAPTER 9: HOUSE NUMBERING
Section
   (Reserved by Ord. 1826, passed 3-8-2022)
CHAPTER 10: FAIR HOUSING
Section
   
5-1001   Purposes and construction
   
5-1002   Housing discrimination acts prohibited
   
5-1003   Exemptions
   
5-1004   Fair Housing Board created
   
5-1005   Duties of Fair Housing Board
   
5-1006   Procedure for complaints
   
5-1007   Notices
   
5-1008   Penalty
§5-1001 PURPOSES AND CONSTRUCTION.
   The general purposes of this chapter are:
   (A)   To secure for all people equal access to housing in all neighborhoods;
and
   (B)   To preserve the public safety, health and welfare.
§5-1002 HOUSING DISCRIMINATION ACTS PROHIBITED.
   It is unlawful for any person, real estate broker, real estate salesperson
or corporation:
   (A)   To refuse to sell, lease, rent, assign or otherwise transfer the title
or other interest in any housing, or real property upon which residential
housing is to be constructed to any person, or to discriminate in the terms or
conditions of the sale, rental or leasing of any residential housing unit,
because of race, color, religion, gender, national origin, age, familial status
or disability;
   (B)   To refuse to negotiate with any person for the sale, rental or leasing
of any residential property, or to represent that such property is not
available for inspection, sale, rental or lease when in fact it is so
available, because of such person’s race, color, religion, gender, national
origin, age, familial status or disability;
   (C)   To solicit or induce, or attempt to solicit or induce, any person
owning any interest in any residential housing to sell, rent or lease, or not
to sell, rent or lease such housing to any person on the grounds of loss of
value due to the present or prospective entry into the neighborhood of a person
or persons of another race, color, religion, gender, national origin, age,
familial status or disability, either by direct solicitation or inducement or
by the purchase of other property in the neighborhood for the purpose of such
inducement, or to distribute, or cause to be distributed, material or making
statements designed to induce a residential property owner to sell or lease his
or her property due to such change in neighborhood; or
   (D)   To file a complaint alleging a violation of this chapter, with
knowledge that such complaint is false in any material respect, or to file such
complaint for the sole purpose of harassment.
§5-1003 EXEMPTIONS.
   Nothing herein shall apply to:
   (A)   Prohibit persons from giving preference to prospective buyers or
tenants for any reason other than race, color, religion, gender, national
origin, age, familial status or disability;
   (B)   The sale of a dwelling which is, or was at the time when first offered
for sale, the residence of its owner;
   (C)   The rental of rooms in an owner occupied residence or in a dwelling
used exclusively as a rooming house;
   (D)   The rental or leasing of a housing unit in a building containing no
more than eight housing units; or
   (E)   The rental or leasing of a dwelling or housing unit owned by any
religious or fraternal organization or private club used and occupied for such
organizational purposes.
§5-1004 FAIR HOUSING BOARD CREATED.
   There is hereby created a Fair Housing Board of the city, hereinafter
referred to as “Board,” which shall be the City Council.
§5-1005 DUTIES OF FAIR HOUSING BOARD.
   It is the duty of the Fair Housing Board to:
   (A)   Initiate, receive and investigate complaints charging unlawful housing
practices;
   (B)   Seek conciliation of such complaints, hold hearings, make findings of
fact and publish its findings of fact; and
   (C)   Adopt such rules and regulations as may be necessary within the limits
of this chapter and carry out the purposes and provisions of this chapter.
§5-1006 PROCEDURE FOR COMPLAINTS.
   (A)   Any person aggrieved by discriminatory practice prohibited by this
chapter may file with the Fair Housing Board a complaint in writing, under
oath. The complaint shall be signed by the person claiming to be aggrieved and
shall state the name and address of the person alleged to have violated the
provisions of this chapter, and shall further set forth the particulars of the
violation, and may include such other information as may be required by the
Board. Complaints filed under this section must be filed within 30 days after
the alleged violation, and failure to file within the time shall be considered
a waiver of the application of this chapter. The Board may issue a complaint on
its own initiative, at any time it is within the knowledge of the Board that a
person has violated any of the provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   The Board shall investigate each complaint filed with the Board and
shall attempt an adjustment of the complaint by means of conference and
conciliation. Sixty days shall be allowed for the purpose of investigation,
conference and conciliation. Upon determination that a complaint is not well
founded, the Board shall dismiss the complaint and notify the complainant and
respondent in writing of the dismissal. If the Board takes no action within 90
days of the filing of the complaint, it shall be considered as dismissed.
   (C)   If conference or conciliation does not result in compliance with this
chapter, the Board shall cause to be issued and served in the name of the city
a written notice, together with a copy of the complaint, requiring the person
named in the complaint, hereinafter referred to as respondent, to answer
charges of the complaint at a hearing before the Board at a time and place to
be specified in the notice.
   (D)   (1)   At the hearing, provided for in division (C) above, the
complaint shall be heard by the Board. At the hearing, the complainant or
person aggrieved may appear in person or by counsel, and the respondent may
file a written answer to the complaint and may appear in person or by legal
counsel. The Board, when conducting any hearing pursuant to this section, may
permit amendments to any complaint or answer, and the testimony taken at the
hearing shall be under oath, and shall be transcribed at the request of either
party, or at the direction of the Board. If the Board finds at the hearing that
the respondent has engaged in any discriminatory practice or practices
prohibited by this chapter, it shall state its findings of fact, and shall so
certify the matter to the City Attorney for appropriate action. No prosecution
shall be brought under this chapter except upon such certification.
      (2)   If the Board, upon hearing, finds that respondent has not engaged
in any discriminatory practice, it shall state its findings of fact and shall
issue and file an order dismissing the complaint. The Board shall establish
rules and regulations to govern and expedite and effectuate the foregoing
procedure and shall maintain the files provided for herein.
§5-1007 NOTICES.
   Any and all notices required under the provisions of this chapter to be
served upon any person may be served personally on such person, or by mailing a
copy thereof by certified or registered mail, with return receipt requested, to
the most current business or residence address of such person.
§5-1008 PENALTY.
   It is unlawful and an offense for any person to violate any of the
provisions of this chapter. Any person found guilty of violating any provisions
shall be deemed guilty of an offense and is subject, upon conviction, to
punishment as provided in §
1-108.
CHAPTER 11: OIL AND GAS DRILLING AND PRODUCTION
Section
   
5-1101   Definitions
   
5-1102   Public nuisance
   
5-1103   Permits required
   
5-1104   Location of wells
   
5-1105   Permit fees
   
5-1106   Drilling permits
   
5-1107   Production permits
   
5-1108   Completion and plugging reports
   
5-1109   Permit amendment or conversion
   
5-1110   Application review
   
5-1111   Permit issuance
   
5-1112   Compliance bond
   
5-1113   Liability insurance
   
5-1114   Drilling and production regulations
   
5-1115   Premises to be maintained and enclosed
   
5-1116   Emergency actions
   
5-1117   Appeals
   
5-1118   Penalty and enforcement
§5-1101 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ABANDONED WELL.
      (1)   A well in which no production casing has been run and for which
drilling or testing operations have ceased for 30 consecutive days; or
      (2)   Any other well for which there is no current production or drilling
permit.
   CITY. Duncan, Oklahoma, a municipal corporation.
   CITY MANAGER. The person currently serving in the capacity of City Manager
for the city, or such person or persons as the City Manager may designate to
perform the duties assigned to the City Manager under the provisions of this
chapter.
   CORPORATION COMMISSION. The Corporation Commission of the state.
   DELETERIOUS SUBSTANCE. Any chemical, salt water, oil field brine, oil,
gasoline or other oil product, waste oil, waste emulsified oil, basic sediment,
drilling or rotary mud or injurious substances produced or used in the
drilling, development, producing, transportation, refining and process of oil,
gas or condensate.
   OIL OR GAS WELL, WELL. Any well, hole or bore, of any depth for the purpose
of production or disposal of oil, gas, casing head gas or liquefied matter or
any byproducts thereof, or for the injection or disposal of any of the
foregoing.
   PERMIT HOLDER (PERMITTEE). Any person to whom is issued a permit under the
terms of this chapter.
   PERSON. Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or association, trust,
cooperative or other similar organization.
   POLLUTION. The contamination or other alteration of the physical, chemical
or biological properties of any natural waters of the city, or such discharge
of any liquid, gaseous or solid substance into any water of the city as will,
or is likely to, create a nuisance or render such waters harmful or detrimental
or injurious to:
      (1)   Public health, safety or welfare;
      (2)   Domestic, commercial, industrial, agricultural, recreational or
other beneficial uses; or
      (3)   Livestock, animals or aquatic life.
   STATE. The State of Oklahoma, its branches, departments, agencies, boards
and commissions, or the officers thereof.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1102 PUBLIC NUISANCE.
   (A)   Whereas the imprudent operation of an oil or gas well and related
production facilities can constitute a menace to the public health, safety and
welfare of the city, it is the intent and purpose of this chapter that oil and
gas production operations be reasonably regulated for the public good.
   (B)   Therefore, the drilling, mining or production of oil, gas or other
minerals within the corporate limits, except in compliance with the provisions
of this chapter, is hereby declared a nuisance against the public health,
safety and welfare of the city.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1103 PERMITS REQUIRED.
   (A)   It is unlawful and an offense for any person to engage in any work
incident to the drilling of an oil or gas well, opening or reentry of an
abandoned oil or gas well unless a permit for drilling, opening or reentry
shall have been first obtained as provided by the terms of this chapter.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to maintain or
operate an oil and gas well or related production facilities or to engage in
the work incident to the maintenance and operation of the same without a valid
production permit therefor as provided by the terms of this chapter.
   (C)   (1)   Operators of producing wells within the corporate limits of the
city on the effective date of this chapter, or upon the effective date of any
subsequent annexation, shall be notified of the production permit requirements
of this chapter and shall apply for a production permit therefor within 60 days
of such notice.
      (2)   Approval of such permit shall be conditioned upon compliance with
the provisions of this chapter within 90 days of permit approval.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1104 LOCATION OF WELLS.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to drill, mine or produce or cause to be
drilled, mined or produced, any oil, gas or other minerals within the corporate
limits of the city, except where permitted under the zoning ordinance of the
city, and in compliance with the terms in this chapter.
   (B)   No permit shall be issued for the drilling of a well or reentry of an
abandoned well at any location which is within 150 feet of a surface property
boundary line other than a street right-of-way or within 400 feet of any
residence, commercial building, church, school, building intended for human
occupancy or freshwater well. Distances prescribed shall be measured from the
proposed permanent enclosure of the facility.
   (C)   No permit shall be issued for the drilling of a well or reentry of an
abandoned well within the right-of-way of a public street or within the
projected right-of-way or within a building setback line of any existing or
proposed street as identified in the major street plan of the city or other
plan, ordinance or document establishing the same.
   (D)   The provisions of this section shall not be construed to prohibit the
maintenance, operation or reworking of a well for which a production permit has
been maintained in compliance with the terms of this chapter.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1105 PERMIT FEES.
   (A)   (1)   The permit fee for drilling, opening or reentry of a well shall
be as set by Council for each well. Permit fees shall be payable upon permit
application.
      (2)   No action in review of a permit application shall be taken without
the payment of such fee to the City Treasurer. Should an application for permit
for drilling, opening or reentry of a well be denied or withdrawn the City
Treasurer shall refund the permit fee less $100 held for application processing
fee.
   (B)   There shall be no fee for production permits.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1106 DRILLING PERMITS.
   Applications for permits to drill an original well or reenter an abandoned
well shall be submitted in the form and shall include such information as the
City Manager shall require to assure compliance with the provisions of this
chapter. Applications shall include, but not necessarily be limited to, the
following information:
   (A)   Site surveys and plot maps showing the location of the well and
surrounding surface property lines and buildings and existing oil, gas and
freshwater wells within 400 feet of the site;
   (B)   Plot maps indicating the proposed location of enclosures to be
provided should a producing well be established;
   (C)   A complete copy of the notice of intent to drill as submitted to the
State Corporation Commission, including a drilling prognosis to specify in
detail the amount, weight and size of conductor pipe and surface pipe and the
procedures to be used for cementing such and plugging procedures to be used in
the event production is not established; and
   (D)   Affidavit identifying the name, title, address and phone number of the
service agent for the applicant.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1107 PRODUCTION PERMITS.
   (A)   Initial applications for production permits shall be submitted in a
form prescribed by the City Manager. Applications shall describe each lease
maintained by the applicant within the city and the surface facilities
associated with such lease, including each well thereon and any associated
surface facilities. To the extent practical, the information requested shall be
provided in the form of spill prevention control and countermeasure plans and
Superfund Amendment and Reauthorization Act (SARA Title III) reports.
   (B)   Production permit renewals shall be issued upon verification that the
information of record is current and accurate and receipt of insurance and bond
renewals. Notice of renewal and request for verification of information shall
be provided to the permit holder not less than 30 days prior to the expiration
of the production permit.
   (C)   Production permits shall expire on the expiration or anniversary date
of the liability insurance policy required in §
5-1113.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1108 COMPLETION AND PLUGGING REPORTS.
   (A)   The holder of any permit under the provisions of this chapter shall
provide the city with copies of all reports and documentation required by the
State Corporation Commission in relation to the completion or plugging of a
well, excluding well logs. Information provided to the State Corporation
Commission shall be provided to the city within 48 hours of filing with the
Commission.
   (B)   Surface casing shall be set in accordance with the rules and
regulations of the State Corporation Commission or Water Resources Board in all
respects. The permittee shall furnish evidence of compliance, casing logs, upon
request by the city. Such request for casing logs may be made a condition of
drilling permit approval.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1109 PERMIT AMENDMENT OR CONVERSION.
   (A)   Upon receipt of a completion or plugging report, as required in §
5-1108, the City Manager shall cause the inspection of the permitted facility
in question for compliance with the terms of this chapter.
   (B)   In the instance of a completed well, the drilling permit shall remain
in force and effect until the site shall be in compliance with the applicable
production permit provisions of this chapter, or the permit term expires. Upon
compliance with the terms of this chapter, the City Manager shall approve the
conversion of the drilling permit to a production permit.
   (C)   In the instance of a plugging report, the permitted facility shall be
removed from those maintained under the permit holder’s production permit,
provided that the site has been appropriately abandoned.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1110 APPLICATION REVIEW.
   (A)   Applications for permits required by this chapter shall be reviewed by
the City Manager for compliance with the terms and conditions of this chapter
and approved or denied based upon such review.
   (B)   (1)   Should the City Manager find deficiencies or violations of the
provisions of this chapter in review of an application for production permits,
the applicant shall be notified of such deficiencies and advised that the
permit application shall be held in abeyance until such deficiencies are
corrected
      (2)    Such notice shall provide that production from such sites shall
not continue beyond the expiration date of the previous production permit.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1111 PERMIT ISSUANCE.
   (A)   Permits approved in accordance with the provisions of this chapter
shall be issued by the City Manager and shall:
      (1)   Be issued only after submission of such bonds and certificates of
insurance in amounts as provided for elsewhere in this chapter;
      (2)   Incorporate by reference all provisions of this chapter with the
same force and effect as if reproduced verbatim therein;
      (3)   Incorporate by reference all provisions of applicable law and the
rules, regulations and standards adopted in accordance therewith relating to
the protection of human beings, animals and natural resources, including those
of the State Corporation Commission, Water Resources Board, Department of
Environmental Quality and Environmental Protection Agency; and
      (4)   Specify that the term of the permit shall be for a period of one
year from the anniversary date of liability insurance required herein and shall
be renewed for like periods thereafter upon application and successful
inspection of the permitted facility as provided in this chapter or until such
time as the facility is properly plugged and abandoned in accordance with the
terms of this chapter.
   (B)   Permits shall be issued in two originals signed by the City Manager
and the applicant, one of which shall be maintained by each signatory.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1112 COMPLIANCE BOND.
   (A)   The provisions of this section shall apply to any holder or applicant
for a drilling or production permit:
      (1)   Required to post or maintain a similar surety for plugging and site
remediation with the State Corporation Commission; or
      (2)   Found in violation of the provisions of this chapter within the
past three consecutive production permit terms.
   (B)   Prior to the issuance of any permit as required in this chapter, the
applicant shall provide a bond, executed by a reliable insurance company
authorized to do business in the state, with the issuing company as surety and
the applicant as principal, running to the city for the benefit of the city and
all persons concerned, conditioned that the principal shall:
      (1)   Comply with the terms and conditions of this chapter;
      (2)   Promptly pay fines, penalties and other assessments imposed upon
the permit holder by reason of breach of any provisions and conditions of this
chapter;
      (3)   Promptly restore streets, sidewalks and other public property of
the city which may be disturbed or damaged in the permittee’s operations to
their former conditions;
      (4)   Upon completion of drilling, opening and reentry operations, or
plugging operations, grade level and restore the property to the same surface
conditions as existed prior to commencing operations, as practicably as
possible, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter;
      (5)   Maintain the site free of litter, trash, waste and other substances
or material not essential to the maintenance and operation of facility; and
      (6)   Hold harmless the city from any liability attributable to granting
the permit.
   (C)   The compliance bond required in this section shall become effective on
or before the date filed with the city and remain in force and effect for at
least 12 months after the expiration of permit term.
   (D)   The amount of the compliance bond required in this section shall be in
a principal amount of $15,000 with respect to any holder of a drilling permit.
   (E)   The amount of the compliance bond required in this section shall be in
a principal amount of $5,000 for such period as the permit holder maintains the
production permit.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1113 LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   (A)   Each holder of a permit under the terms of this chapter shall carry a
policy or policies of standard comprehensive public liability insurance,
including contractual liability, covering bodily injuries and property damage,
naming the permit holder and the city, issued by an insurer authorized to do
business within the state. The policy or policies shall in the aggregate
provide the following minimum coverage:
      (1)   Bodily injuries: $100,000 per person and $1,000,000 per accident;
and
      (2)   Property damage: $500,000.
   (B)   Certificates of insurance submitted in compliance with the provisions
of this section shall provide that the policy shall not be canceled without
notice to the city at least 15 days prior to the effective date of such
cancellation.
   (C)   In the event the policy is canceled, the permit or permits held in
conjunction therewith shall immediately thereupon terminate without any action
on the part of the city and the permittee’s rights to operation under such
permits shall cease until permit holder files additional insurance bonds or
surety as required herein.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1114 DRILLING AND PRODUCTION REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Persons drilling, operating or maintaining any oil and gas well shall
use all necessary care and take all precautions which shall be reasonably
necessary under the circumstances to protect the public. The provisions of this
section shall be deemed to be the minimum requirements for the preservation of
the public health, safety and welfare, and compliance with the terms hereof
shall not be deemed to relieve any person of any additional duty or liability
imposed by law.
   (B)   The drilling, operation or maintenance of any oil or gas well and
related facilities shall be subject to the following regulations, and
violations thereof are hereby declared unlawful and an offense.
      (1)   No deleterious substance shall be disposed of by draining or
diverting the same into or upon any public highway, street or alley, drainage
ditch, storm sewer, sanitary sewer, gutter or paving; nor shall any of such
substance be permitted to escape from the property owned, leased or controlled
by the person conducting such operations by seepage or overflow.
      (2)   No steam engine, gasoline, natural gas, diesel or other internal
combustion engine shall be operated without being muffled.
      (3)   All permits for drilling, opening or reentry of a well shall
prescribe the use of blowout prevention unless specifically exempted by the
City Council.
      (4)   No earthen pits shall be permitted without the review and approval
of the City Council. All metal pits or other pits and their contents shall be
removed from the premises within 60 days after completion of the well.
      (5)   (a)   All storage tanks or other tanks intended to contain
inflammable substances shall be protected by earthen embankments constructed in
compliance with the provisions of the spill prevention containment and
countermeasure plan requirements as promulgated by the environmental protection
agency.
         (b)   No such tanks shall be erected or installed nearer to any
surface property boundary or structure than permitted in accordance with §
5-1104.
      (6)   Approved equipment, devices and methods for the safety of life and
property, such as are commonly known in the oil drill and producing business,
must be used in the city in the carrying on of all the operations covered by
this chapter, and the failure to use any such equipment, devices or methods in
any substantially important question shall be a grounds for immediately
stopping further work until such failure has been corrected.
      (7)   Derricks, metal pits and other equipment not necessary to
production shall be removed from a permitted well site within 60 days of the
cessation of drilling.
      (8)   No pipeline, power transmission system, communications system or
other facility shall be erected or installed upon, within or under any public
right-of-way except in accordance with such permits as may be required by the
city.
      (9)   Permits for drilling or reentry of wells may include provisions
requiring compliance with adopted standards for driveway improvements.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1115 PREMISES TO BE MAINTAINED AND ENCLOSED.
   (A)   The premises of any well and associated surface facilities shall be
kept free from accumulations of rubbish, litter, tall weeds and grass, unused
materials or equipment, excessive rotary mud and waste oil or oily substances
or other deleterious substance, as far as such premises may be reasonably kept
free of the same in the carrying on of operations.
   (B)   (1)   All surface facilities associated with oil and gas production
shall be secured by a fence of not less than six feet in height provided with
three strands of barbed wire affixed to the top thereof.
      (2)   Such fence shall be constructed and maintained so as to ordinarily
keep persons and animals out of the enclosure in accordance with the following.
         (a)   Such fence shall be of nine-gauge wire mesh material or such
other material as may be approved within the terms and conditions of the
permit.
         (b)   The enclosure shall provide no openings of greater than four
inches in any dimension, including any separation between the bottom of the
fence and adjacent grade.
         (c)   Fences and gates shall be kept locked when the permit holder or
his or her employees are not within the enclosure.
         (d)   The provisions of this section may be complied with by the
provision of a single enclosure of multiple surface facilities or individual
enclosures for each surface facility in accordance with plans submitted and
approved in conjunction with permit review and approval procedures.
   (C)   All lease equipment shall be painted and maintained in a good state of
condition, operation and appearance.
   (D)   Each enclosure, as required above, shall have posted in a prominent
place a metal sign of no less than two square feet in area upon which the
following information shall be conspicuous:
      (1)   Name of operator;
      (2)   Lease name;
      (3)   Location of site by reference to the United States survey;
      (4)   Identify number of permits issued by the city; and
      (5)   A current emergency response phone number.
   (E)   Each enclosure, as required above, shall have hazard warning signs
prominently posted so as to be clearly visible from all approaches to the
enclosure. Such signs shall be not less than two square feet in area.
   (F)   All tanks or vessels equipped with thief or similar hatches shall be
fitted with mechanisms permitting the locking thereof and shall be maintained
locked except in the presence of the operator’s employees or agents.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1116 EMERGENCY ACTIONS.
   (A)   The City Manager or his or her appointee shall have the authority to
require the immediate shutting in or closing of any well if it is found that
there exists within a 100-foot radius of the enclosure of any facility or well,
any flammable or explosive vapor in a quantity sufficient to constitute, in his
or her judgment or the judgment of the Fire Marshal, a fire hazard or health
hazard.
   (B)   If the city finds that a hazard to life or natural resources exists,
the City Manager or his or her appointee shall order immediate rectification of
the cause. If the permit holder takes no immediate action to reduce a hazard,
or if the situation be so perilous as to constitute an imminent threat to
safety, then the City Manager or his or her appointee may order the prompt
cessation of activity and, if necessary, the clearing of the premises.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1117 APPEALS.
   Applicants aggrieved by any order, directive or ruling by the City Manager
or his or her appointee under the provisions of this chapter may appeal the
same to the City Council, which shall hear the matter at its next scheduled
meeting, provided that the aggrieved party has submitted a written appeal to
the City Manager not less than five workdays prior to such meeting. The lodging
of such an appeal shall not stay the enforcement of any provision of this
chapter. Any appeal of the provisions of this chapter involving a request for
variation of the provisions of this chapter relating to the location of wells
shall require not less than 15 days’ notice of hearing to all surface owners of
property within 600 feet of the site in question.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
§5-1118 PENALTY AND ENFORCEMENT.
   (A)   Any person found in violation of the provisions of this chapter may be
punished as provided in §
1-108. Each day in which a violation continues may constitute a separate
offense.
   (B)   In addition to any penalty prescribed above, the city may, upon
direction of the City Council, seek compliance with the provisions of this
chapter through action in a court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. 1383, passed 10-24-1995)
CHAPTER 12: SEWER LINE CONNECTION REGULATIONS
Section
   
5-1201   Definitions
   
5-1202   Defective and prohibited connections
   
5-1203   Administrative procedure
   
5-1204   Corrective action
§5-1201 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DEFECTIVE SERVICE LINE. A line transporting wastewater from a user facility
to the public wastewater collection system that in addition allows the entrance
of infiltration or inflow.
   INFILTRATION. Water entering the publicly owned treatment works at any
location, public or private, by permeation through the ground and subsequent
entry through defective pipes, pipe joints, connections, manhole walls or
similar such means of passage.
   INFLOW. Water entering the publicly owned treatment works at any location,
public or private, by means of surface stormwater or irrigation runoff, or
piped transportation of such waters.
   PROHIBITED CONNECTION. Any piping arrangement or transportation system that
conveys groundwater, stormwater or irrigation runoff, or any condensate to the
public wastewater collection system.
(Ord. 1326, passed 3-24-1992)
§5-1202 DEFECTIVE AND PROHIBITED CONNECTIONS.
   (A)   To minimize groundwater infiltration and surface water inflow to the
public wastewater system that overloads pipelines and inhibits wastewater
treatment, the city hereby requires the owner of any property on which a
defective sewer line or a prohibited connection is located to repair the
service line or remove the prohibited connection at the owner’s expense.
   (B)   The city will investigate and determine if a service line is
defective. Cracked, broken, crushed or similarly damaged lines, lines with
separated joints or lines with any condition that allows infiltration of
groundwater shall be considered defective.
   (C)   The city will investigate and determine if a connection to the public
sewer is a prohibited connection. Prohibited connections may be direct to the
public sewer or indirect through the property service line. Roof drains, yard
drains, driveway and parking area drains, foundation drains, exterior stairwell
drains, uncapped cleanouts, sumps or any other system that conveys groundwater
or surface runoff to a public wastewater system may be considered a prohibited
connection, even though such connection may not have been prohibited under
existing ordinances, regulations or standards at the time of construction.
(Ord. 1326, passed 3-24-1992)
§5-1203 ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURE.
   The code enforcement officer will provide written notice to the property
owner by certified mail that corrective action is required. The written notice
will specify the action that is needed such as partial repair, replacement or
disconnection. The property owner shall have 60 days from the date of the
notice to complete the work. If the property owner fails to complete the work,
the code enforcement officer will file appropriate damages in municipal court
for violation of this code. In addition to prosecution in municipal court, the
city may pursue a civil action by injunction in any court of competent
jurisdiction to temporarily or permanently enjoin the continuation of
wastewater collection service because of a public health nuisance. Further, the
city may suspend water service to property until the violations are corrected.
(Ord. 1326, passed 3-24-1992)
§5-1204 CORRECTIVE ACTION.
   Plumbing work shall be done in accordance with all city, state and federal
codes, regulations and standards. The city in no way whatsoever assumes any
responsibility or liability for corrective action undertaken by the property
owner or plumbing contractor. All prohibited connections shall be disconnected
immediately at the public sewer or sanitary service line and capped with a
watertight seal. Any repairs to the service tap fitting shall be made by a
licensed plumbing contractor registered with the city. Any repairs to a public
sewer shall be made by a licensed plumbing contractor registered with the city,
or by city personnel. All corrective work shall be inspected and approved by
the city prior to being covered and returned to service. Connection of
terminated service shall be at the owner’s expense. Any person damaging a
public sewer main shall be responsible for reasonable repair costs for such
damage, as determined by the city.
(Ord. 1326, passed 3-24-1992; Ord. 1351, passed 6-14-1994)
CHAPTER 13: BUILDING DEMOLITION
Section
   
5-1301   Permit required
   
5-1302   Conditions of permit
   
5-1303   Time of performance
   
5-1304   Penalty
§5-1301 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Any person demolishing any building or structure shall first obtain a permit
therefor as required in this chapter. Application for a demolition permit shall
be in the form prescribed by the Building Official.
(Ord. 1331, passed 12-8-1992)
§5-1302 CONDITIONS OF PERMIT.
   In addition to compliance with city codes and ordinances, the conditions set
forth below shall apply to demolition permits.
   (A)   Asbestos survey. Application for a permit to demolish a commercial or
industrial building shall be accompanied by the results of an asbestos survey
performed by an inspector licensed to perform such work by the State Department
of Labor. Should the results of the survey indicate the presence of asbestos
subject to special handling, a licensed asbestos removal contractor shall be
employed to perform such work.
   (B)   Site clearance. It shall be a condition of the demolition permit that:
      (1)   The site be cleared of all building material, rubble and debris;
and
      (2)   Any cellars, cisterns or other open excavations be filled and that
foundations, slabs, porches or similar improvements be removed to grade and the
site graded to prevent standing water.
   (C)   Sanitary sewer connections. All connections to a public sanitary sewer
shall be exposed and sealed or closed in a manner approved by the plumbing
inspector of the city.
(Ord. 1331, passed 12-8-1992)
§5-1303 TIME OF PERFORMANCE.
   The conditions of the permit shall be met within 60 days of the date of
issuance, unless the application for permit includes an alternative schedule
for performance which is approved by the Building Official. Failure to comply
with all conditions of the permit within the specified period shall constitute
violation of the demolition permit.
(Ord. 1331, passed 12-8-1992)
§5-1304 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of
an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in §
1-108. The owner or owners of any premises or part thereof where anything in
violation of this chapter shall exist, and any builder, contractor, agent,
person, firm or corporation employed in connection therewith, and who may have
participated or aided in such violation, shall be guilty of a separate offense
and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in §
1-108.
(Ord. 1331, passed 12-8-1992)
CHAPTER 14: PENALTY AND JUDICIAL RELIEF
Section
   
5-1401   Penalty
   
5-1402   Relief in the courts
§5-1401 PENALTY.
   Any person who shall engage in any business, trade or vocation for which a
license, permit, certificate or registration is required by this part without
having a valid license, permit, certificate or certificate of registration as
required, or who shall fail to do anything required by this chapter or by any
code adopted by this part, or who shall otherwise violate any provision of this
chapter or of any code adopted by this part, or who shall violate any lawful
regulation or order made by any of the officers provided for in this part,
shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished
as provided in §
1-108.
§5-1402 RELIEF IN THE COURTS.
   No penalty imposed by and pursuant to this chapter shall interfere with the
right of the city also to apply to the proper courts of the state for a
mandamus, an injunction or other appropriate action against such person.
CHAPTER 15: TELECOMMUNICATIONS TOWERS AND ANTENNAS
Section
   
5-1501   Purpose
   
5-1502   Definitions
   
5-1503   Permit required
   
5-1504   Collocation requirements
   
5-1505   Telecommunications facility standards
   
5-1506   Alternative structures standards
   
5-1507   Specific standards
   
5-1508   Permit conditions
   
5-1509   Permit approval process
§5-1501 PURPOSE.
   The purposes of these regulations for telecommunications facilities are:
   (A)   To facilitate the provision of telecommunications services throughout
the city;
   (B)   To enhance the ability to provide telecommunications services to the
community quickly, effectively and efficiently;
   (C)   To encourage the location of towers in nonresidential zone districts;
   (D)   To minimize the total number of towers in the community;
   (E)   To encourage the joint use of new and existing tower locations;
   (F)   To ensure that towers are located in areas that minimize adverse
impacts;
   (G)   To ensure towers and antennas are configured in a way that minimizes
adverse visual impacts by careful design, appropriate siting and landscape
screening;
   (H)   To encourage the attachment of antennas on existing structures;
   (I)   To consider public health and safety;
   (J)   To avoid damage to adjacent properties from tower failure through
careful engineering and locating of tower structures; and
   (K)   To protect residential areas and lands by minimizing adverse impacts
of towers.
(Ord. 1514, passed 10-24-2000)
§5-1502 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ANSI. American National Standards Institute.
   ACCESSORY SUPPORT FACILITIES. Support buildings, tower base, anchor, guywire
attachment, structures and equipment cabinets for telecommunications facilities
containing electrical and mechanical equipment and devices used for the
reception of or transmission of voice, data, image, graphic and video
programming information between or among points by wire, cable, fiber optics,
laser, microwave, radio, satellite or similar facilities.
   ALTERNATIVE TOWER STRUCTURE. Clock towers, bell steeples, building
structures or building equipment normally maintained above the roofline of a
structure, light poles, flagpoles and similar alternative design mounting
structures for the purpose of supporting one or more antennas. This term also
includes any antenna or antenna array attached to the alternative tower
structure.
   ANTENNA. Any exterior transmitting or receiving devices mounted on a tower,
building or structure and used in communications that radiate or capture
electromagnetic waves, digital signals, analog signals, radio frequencies
(excluding radar signals), wireless telecommunications signals or other
communication signals.
   BOCA. Building Officials and Code Administrators.
   EIA. Electronics Industry Association.
   FAA. Federal Aviation Administration.
   FCC. Federal Communications Commission.
   RF. Radio frequency.
   TELECOMMUNICATIONS FACILITIES. The plant, equipment and property, including,
but not limited to, cables, wires, conduits, ducts, pedestals, antennas,
towers, alternative tower structures, electronics and other appurtenances used
to transmit, receive, distribute, provide or offer telecommunications services.
   TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICE. The providing or offering for rent, sale or
lease, or in exchange for other value received, of the transmittal of voice,
data, image, graphic and video programming information between or among points
by wire, cable, fiber optics, laser, microwave, radio, satellite or similar
facilities, with or without benefit or any closed transmission medium.
   TOWER. Any structure designed and constructed primarily for the purpose of
supporting one or more antennas, including self-supporting lattice towers,
guyed towers or monopole towers. The term includes radio and television
transmission towers, microwave towers, common carrier towers, cellular
telephone towers and other similar structures. This term also includes any
antenna or antenna array attached to the tower structure.
   TOWER HEIGHT. When referring to a tower or other alternative tower
structure, the distance measured from the lowest point within ten feet of the
structure to the highest point on the tower or other alternative tower
structure, including the base pad and any antenna.
(Ord. 1514, passed 10-24-2000)
§5-1503 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Telecommunications facilities shall be regulated and permitted pursuant to
this chapter and the zoning ordinances of the city.
   (A)   A telecommunications facility shall obtain a permit as a condition for
the siting, construction or operation of the telecommunications facility.
   (B)   These regulations shall apply to all towers and antennas as defined,
except:
      (1)   Any tower, or antenna, not more than 70 feet in height, owned and
operated by a federally licensed amateur radio station operator;
      (2)   Any antenna collocated on an existing telecommunications facility,
except as expressly provided in this chapter;
      (3)   A telecommunications facility located or collocated on property
that is owned by the city and designated by the city as a site suitable for
location of a telecommunications facility;
      (4)   FCC exempted antennas;
      (5)   Antennas one meter (39.4 inches) or less in diameter; or
      (6)   Antennas on existing structures that do not extend above 20 feet in
height above the structure.
   (C)   Any violation of this chapter is hereby declared to be a nuisance. In
addition to any other relief or penalty provided by law, the city may apply to
district court for an injunction to prohibit the continuation of any violation
of this chapter.
(Ord. 1514, passed 10-24-2000)
§5-1504 COLLOCATION REQUIREMENTS.
   The following will apply on towers built for collocation.
   (A)   All applicants for a telecommunications facility permit shall
collocate on an existing facility if it is feasible to do so. An existing
facility shall be deemed to be available to the applicant for collocation if:
the facility is within the search ring of the applicant or within a reasonable
distance so as to fit into the applicant’s design, space is available on the
facility and the facility owner will lease space to applicant at a reasonable
market rate.
      (1)   If the applicant finds collocation is not feasible, it shall submit
to the city a written statement of the reasons for the infeasibility. The city
may retain a technical expert in the field of RF engineering to determine
whether collocation at the site is feasible. The cost for such a technical
expert will be at the expense of the applicant.
      (2)   Should collocation not be feasible, applicant must consider city
owned property for construction of any new tower. If the applicant determines
that city owned property is not feasible, it shall submit to the city a written
statement of the reasons for the infeasibility. The city may retain a technical
expert in the field of RF engineering to determine whether the site is
feasible. The cost for such a technical expert will be at the expense of the
applicant.
      (3)   The city may deny the permit unless the applicant demonstrates to
the city by substantial evidence that existing telecommunications facilities or
city owned property cannot accommodate the applicant’s proposed antenna.
   (B)   A telecommunications tower shall not be permitted unless the owner of
the proposed tower certifies to the city that the tower is available for use by
other telecommunications service providers on a reasonable and
nondiscriminatory basis. Towers and accessory support facilities shall be
designed and built to accommodate a minimum of three telecommunications
services.
   (C)   To facilitate collocation and coordination of telecommunications
sites, all telecommunications service providers shall, within 90 days of the
passage of this chapter, provide the city with their respective master plans.
Said plans shall include detailed maps, showing the locations of all
telecommunications towers serving any portion of the city and indicating their
coverage areas.
   (D)   Telecommunications service providers shall also provide the city with
any updates to the above documents within 90 days of their creation.
(Ord. 1514, passed 10-24-2000)
§5-1505 TELECOMMUNICATIONS FACILITY STANDARDS.
   (A)   The exterior of equipment buildings and/or equipment cabinets visible
from residential areas or public rights-of-way must have a neutral aggregate
finish or be painted to reflect the color and character of adjoining structures
or blend with adjacent landscaping and other surroundings.
   (B)   At the telecommunications facility, the design of the buildings and
related structures used in conjunction with telecommunications facilities
shall, to the extent possible, use materials, colors, textures, screening and
landscaping that will blend the telecommunications facilities to the natural
setting and the built environment.
   (C)   (1)   All telecommunications facilities must have a buffer of
landscaping outside the perimeter of the accessory support facility.
      (2)   The base of the tower and any accessory support facilities such as
anchored locations of guywires shall be screened from view with a sightproof
fence, which shall be a minimum of six feet in height.
   (D)   Guywires must be anchored no closer than ten feet from any property
