ARTICLE A. MEDICAL MARIJUANA
§8-701 LEGISLATIVE INTENT AND PURPOSE.
   The intent of this chapter is to ensure the health and safety of the
citizens of the city, and all Oklahomans, and provide reasonable and orderly
regulation of medical marijuana as authorized by the passage of State Question
788. Only the powers enumerated under this chapter shall be proper. Any power
not specifically enumerated is prohibited.
   (A)   Any person, persons or entity violating any provisions of this
article, either by doing anything which is prohibited or by failing to do
anything which is commanded, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon
conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not exceeding $500, plus court
costs. Each separate violation of this article shall constitute a separate
offense. Where a lesser fine is mandated by state law, then the lesser amount
of fine shall be applicable.
   (B)   These regulations are intended to apply to all medical marijuana for
personal use or any medical marijuana business permitted under the State
Question 788. The chapter is intended to provide regulations to limit the
impact that medical marijuana cultivation and production will have on the
health, safety and community resources of the city.
   (C)   This chapter is to be construed to protect the public over medical
marijuana business interests. Operation of a medical marijuana business in the
city is a revocable privilege and not a right in the city. There is no property
right for an individual or business to have medical marijuana in the city.
   (D)   Medical marijuana is a regulated industry in the city, and all medical
marijuana business owners, operators and employees are assumed to be fully
aware of the applicable law and regulations.
   (E)   The purpose of this chapter is to:
      (1)   Protect the public health, safety and welfare of the residents and
medical marijuana patients of the city by prescribing the manner medical
marijuana businesses are to be conducted within the city;
      (2)   Provide for a means of cultivation, production and distribution of
medical marijuana to patients who quality to obtain, possess and use marijuana
for medical purposes under the State Question 788;
      (3)   Protect public health and safety through reasonable limitations on
business operations as they relate to noise, air and water quality, food
safety, neighborhood and patient safety, security for the business and its
personnel and other health and safety concerns;
      (4)   Impose fees to cover the cost to the city of permitting medical
marijuana businesses in an amount sufficient for the city to recover its costs
of the permitting program;
      (5)   Adopt a mechanism for monitoring compliance with the provisions of
this chapter; and
      (6)   Issue medical marijuana business permits only to individuals and
entities that have demonstrated an intent and ability to comply with this
chapter without monitoring by city officials.
   (F)   In order to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the
residents, and the medical marijuana patients, of the city and to the extent
permitted by law, it is the intent of the city that
Chapter 7 of Part 8 of this code shall have retroactive application.
   (G)   Any ordinance now in effect that conflicts with any of the provisions
of this chapter shall be held to be invalid and to no effect insofar as it
shall conflict with the provisions herein contained.
   (H)   The provisions of this chapter are hereby declared to be severable,
and if any section, paragraph, sentence or clause of this article is for any
reason held invalid or inoperative by any court of competent jurisdictions,
such decision shall not affect any other section, paragraph, sentence or clause
hereof.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-702 STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH REGULATIONS ADOPTED BY REFERENCE.
   State Department of Health Regulations, Title 310, Chapter 681, Medical
Marijuana Control Program, as it may from time to time be amended, is adopted
by reference and is made a part of the ordinances of the city, as if fully set
forth in this code. The provisions of these regulations shall take effect and
be controlling within the city limits so that a violation of the provisions of
the regulations will be a violation of this code.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-703 STATE STATUTES ADOPTED BY REFERENCE.
   (A)   63 O.S. §§ 420 through 430, relating to medical marijuana, the State
Medical Marijuana and Patient Protection Act, being 63 O.S. §§ 427.1 et seq.,
and the State Medical Marijuana Waste Management Act, being 63 O.S. §§ 428 et
seq., as it may from time to time be amended, is adopted by reference and is
made a part of the ordinances of the city, as if fully set forth in this code.
   (B)   The provisions of these regulations shall take effect and be
controlling within the city limits so that a violation of the provisions of the
regulations will be a violation of this code.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
ARTICLE B. COMMERCIAL MEDICAL MARIJUANA BUSINESS PERMIT
§8-710 MEDICAL MARIJUANA BUSINESS PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, persons or other business entity
to operate a commercial medical marijuana business within the corporate limits
of the city without first having obtained a medical marijuana business permit
as provided herein.
   (B)   The medical marijuana business permit requirement set forth in this
chapter shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other licensing and
permitting requirements imposed by any other federal, state or local law,
including, by way of example, any applicable building permit or certificate of
occupancy.
   (C)   A medical marijuana business permit does not provide nor create an
exception, defense or immunity to any person with regard to any potential
criminal liability the person may have for the production, distribution or
possession of marijuana.
   (D)   A separate medical marijuana business permit shall be required for
each premises from which a commercial medical marijuana business is operated.
Except as specifically provided in this chapter, no two or more different
commercial medical marijuana businesses may be treated as one premises.
   (E)   A medical marijuana business permit that has been issued by the city,
Department of Community Development for medical marijuana is nontransferable. A
permit is not transferable or assignable, including, without limitation, not
transferable or assignable to a different location, to a different type of
business, or to a different owner or permittee. A permit is valid only for the
owner named thereon, the type of business disclosed on the application for the
permit and the location for which the permit is issued. The named permittee of
a commercial medical marijuana business are only those persons disclosed in the
application or subsequently disclosed to the city in accordance with this
chapter. The provisions of this division (E) shall not apply to medical
marijuana businesses operating under a valid certificate of authority pursuant
to OMMA 442:10-1, as it may be amended from time to time.
   (F)   On the date of these ordinances being enacted, all existing medical
marijuana businesses located within the corporate limits of the city shall be
granted 60 days after enactment to obtain a medical marijuana business permit
from the city. The 60-day grace period shall not apply to any new medical
marijuana business formed from and after the date of enactment.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-711 BUILDING, FIRE AND LIFE SAFETY REQUIREMENTS.
   All commercial medical marijuana facilities shall comply with the building,
fire and life safety codes for the city, in addition to any state building,
fire and life safety codes, as the same may be amended from time to time.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
ARTICLE C. GENERAL PROVISIONS
§8-720 DEFENSE TO CRIMINAL PROSECUTIONS.
   Compliance with the requirements of this chapter shall not provide an
exception, immunity or defense to criminal prosecution under any applicable
law, except in the municipal court for the city.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-721 INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   Generally. Every commercial medical marijuana business shall permit
the local permitting authority, and any agent of the local permitting
authority, or anyone authorized, to inspect the premises of the business
pursuant to the city code, or State Question 788, and any of the rules and
regulations adopted pursuant thereto.
   (B)   Costs of inspection and clean-up. In the event the city incurs costs
in the inspection, clean-up, surrender of plants or any other requirements to
remove medical marijuana of any medical marijuana business, or any person
cultivating, producing, distributing or possessing marijuana, the business and
responsible person shall reimburse the city for all actual costs incurred by
the city for such inspection or clean-up, including administrative fees.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-722 FORFEITURE OF CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY.
   In the event that a commercial medical marijuana business does not commence
operations within 30 days of issuance of a city medical marijuana business
permit, the business permit shall be deemed forfeited, and the business may not
commence operations.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-723 LOCATIONS AND ZONING OF MEDICAL MARIJUANA BUSINESSES.
   (A)   Fixed location.
      (1)   A fixed location is required for any and all medical marijuana
businesses. Mobile medical marijuana sales of all types are prohibited within
the city; this includes, but is not limited to, trailers, recreational vehicles
and trucks.
      (2)   With the exception of a commercial grower, it shall be unlawful to
operate a medical marijuana business outside of an enclosed, fixed building.
All city medical marijuana business permits shall be issued only for a specific
fixed location within an enclosed building.
   (B)   Permitted use in zoning district. A city medical marijuana business
permit for a commercial medical marijuana business may be issued only in the
following locations:
      (1)   A medical marijuana dispensary shall only be located within one of
the following zoning classifications:
         (a)   C-1 Neighborhood Shopping District;
         (b)   C-2 Office Commercial District;
         (c)   C-3 Planned Shopping Center District; and
         (d)   C-4 General Commercial District.
      (2)   Commercial medical marijuana growing facilities shall only be
located within one of the following zoning classifications:
         (a)   An organic greenhouse utilizing natural light, with no gases or
chemicals, and single stack of plants:
            1.   A-1 or A-2 Agricultural District;
            2.   C-4 General Commercial District;
            3.   I-1 Restricted Manufacturing and Warehousing District;
            4.   I-2 Light Industrial District; and
            5.   1-3 General Industrial District.
         (b)   A medical marijuana growing facility utilizing artificial light,
fertilizer and pesticides, not exceeding maximum allowable quantity, and a
single stack of plants:
            1.   A-1 Agricultural District;
            2.   I-1 Restricted Manufacturing and Warehousing District;
            3.   I-2 Light Industrial District; and
            4.   I-3 General Industrial District.
         (c)   A medical marijuana growing facility utilizing artificial light
and flammable gas or flammable liquids, or industrial alcohol, or utilizing
fertilizer or pesticides which exceed maximum allowable quantity, or where
plants are double stacked: I-3 General Industrial District.
      (3)   Commercial medical marijuana processing facilities shall only be
located within one of the following zoning districts:
         (a)   A medical marijuana processor which engages in trimming and
packing, and/or pre-rolls medical marijuana, and/or engages in baking, and/or
utilizes water or ice:
            1.   C-1 Neighborhood Shopping District;
            2.   C-2 Office Commercial District;
            3.   C-3 Planned Shopping Center District;
            4.   C-4 General Commercial District;
            5.   I-1 Restricted Manufacturing and Warehousing District;
            6.   I-2 Light Industrial District; and
            7.   I-3 General Industrial District.
         (b)   A medical marijuana processor which engages in low hazard
extraction utilizing CO2:
            1.   I-1 Restricted Manufacturing and Warehousing District;
            2.   I-2 Light Industrial District; and
            3.   I-3 General Industrial District.
         (c)   A medical marijuana processor which engages in high hazard
extraction utilizing flammable gas or flammable liquids, or industrial alcohol:
I-3 General Industrial District.
      (4)   Commercial medical marijuana transport facilities shall only be
located within one of the following zoning districts:
         (a)   C-2, C-3, C-4 General Commercial District;
         (b)   I-1 Restricted Manufacturing and Warehousing District;
         (c)   I-2 Light Industrial District; and
         (d)   I-3 General Industrial District.
      (5)   A commercial medical marijuana laboratory shall only be located
within one of the following zoning districts:
         (a)   A commercial medical marijuana laboratory which utilizes
chemicals not exceeding the maximum allowable quantity:
            1.   C-1 Neighborhood Shopping District;
            2.   C-2 Office Commercial District;
            3.   C-3 Planned Shopping Center District;
            4.   C-4 General Commercial District;
            5.   I-1 Restricted Manufacturing and Warehousing District;
            6.   I-2 Light Industrial District; and
            7.   I-3 General Industrial District.
         (b)   A commercial medical marijuana laboratory which utilizes
chemicals exceeding the maximum allowable quantity: I-3 General Industrial
District.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-724 COMMERCIAL MEDICAL MARIJUANA BUSINESSES PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful to operate a commercial medical marijuana business in a
building which contains a residence, or within a dwelling unit within any
zoning district, or within a residential zoning district, or within a mixed-use
development that includes a residence.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-725 APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   (1)   An application for a city medical marijuana business permit for
a commercial medical marijuana business shall be made to the city on forms
provided by the Department of Community Development for that purpose.
      (2)   The applicant shall use the application to demonstrate its
compliance with this chapter and any other applicable law, rule or regulation.
   (B)   The application shall include the following information:
      (1)   The State Medical Marijuana Authority business license number if
business permit applicant is completing initial application (not renewal) a
license number is not required;
      (2)   Contact information for the owner or owners of the medical
marijuana business in whose name the permit is proposed to be issued:
         (a)   If an owner is a corporation, the name and address of any
officer, the director of the corporation and the service agent;
         (b)   If an owner is a partnership, association or company, the name
and address of any person holding an interest therein and the managing members.
If a managing member is an entity rather than an individual, the same
disclosure shall be required for each entity with an ownership interest until a
managing member that is a natural person is identified; and
         (c)   If an owner is not a natural person, the organizational
documents for all entities identified in the application, identification of the
natural person that is authorized to speak for the entity and contact
information for that person.
      (3)   An operating plan for the proposed medical marijuana business,
including the following information:
         (a)   A description of the products and services to be provided by the
medical marijuana business; and
         (b)   A dimensioned floor plan, clearly labeled, showing:
            1.   The layout of the structure, to include all mechanical,
electrical, plumbing, fire and life safety, as well as the floor plan in which
the medical marijuana business is to be located; and
            2.   Areas where any services other than the distribution of
medical marijuana are proposed to occur in the premises.
      (4)   For cultivation facilities, a plan that specifies the methods to be
used to prevent the growth of harmful mold, humidity and other related
problems;
      (5)   A lighting plan showing the lighting outside of the medical
marijuana business for security purposes and compliance with applicable city
requirements;
      (6)   A fire separation and/or fire suppression plan that meets city and
state fire codes; and
      (7)   A description of all toxic, flammable or other materials regulated
by a federal, state or local government that would have authority over the
business if it was not a marijuana business, that will be used or kept at the
medical marijuana business, the location of such materials and how such
materials will be stored.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-726 MEDICAL MARIJUANA BUSINESS PERMIT FEES.
   (A)   Medical marijuana dispensaries. The permit fee for medical marijuana
dispensaries is $500, and the annual renewal fee will be $250 if application is
made with the city 45 days prior to permit expiration.
   (B)   Commercial medical marijuana growing facilities.
      (1)   For an organic greenhouse, the permit fee is $1,000, and the annual
renewal fee will be $500 if application is made with the city 45 days prior to
permit expiration.
      (2)   For a medical marijuana growing facility utilizing artificial
light, fertilizer and pesticides, not exceeding maximum allowable quantity, and
a single stack of plants, the permit fee is $1,500, and the annual renewal fee
will be $750 if application is made with the city 45 days prior to permit
expiration.
      (3)   For a medical marijuana growing facility utilizing artificial light
and flammable gas or flammable liquids, or industrial alcohol, or utilizing
fertilizer or pesticides which exceed maximum allowable quantity, or where
plants are double stacked, the permit fee is $2,500, and the annual renewal fee
will be $1,250 if application is made with the city 45 days prior to permit
expiration.
   (C)   Commercial medical marijuana processing facilities. For a medical
marijuana processor which engages in trimming and packing, and/or pre-rolls
medical marijuana, and/or engages in baking, and/or utilizes water or ice, the
permit fee is $750, and the annual renewal fee will be $375 if application is
made with the city 45 days prior to permit expiration. For a medical marijuana
processor which engages in low hazard extraction, utilizing CO2, the permit fee
is $1,000, and the annual renewal fee will be $500 if application is made with
the city 45 days prior to permit expiration. For a medical marijuana processor
which engages in high hazard extraction utilizing flammable gas or flammable
liquids, or industrial alcohol, the permit fee is $2,500, and the annual
renewal fee will be $1,250 if application is made with the city 45 days prior
to permit expiration.
   (D)   Commercial medical marijuana transport facilities. The permit fee for
commercial medical marijuana transport facilities is $500, and the annual
renewal fee will be $250 if application is made with the city 45 days prior to
permit expiration.
   (E)   Commercial medical marijuana laboratory. For a commercial medical
marijuana laboratory which utilizes chemicals not exceeding the maximum
allowable quantity, the permit fee is $750, and the annual renewal fee will be
$375 if application is made with the city 45 days prior to permit expiration.
For a commercial medical marijuana laboratory which utilizes chemicals
exceeding the maximum allowable quantity, the permit fee is $2,500, and the
annual renewal fee will be $1,250 if application is made with the city 45 days
prior to permit expiration.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-727 INSPECTION.
   (A)   An inspection of the proposed medical marijuana business as required
by the State Medical Marijuana Authority for a certificate of compliance, as
well as for a city certificate of occupancy (which include inspections for
plumbing, electric, mechanical, fire and life safety), shall be required prior
to issuance of a city medical marijuana business permit. Such inspection shall
occur after the premises are ready for operation, but prior to the stocking of
the business with any medical marijuana, and prior to the opening of the
business to any patients or the public (for initial applicants).
   (B)   The inspection is to verity that the business facilities are
constructed and can be operated in accordance with the application submitted
and the applicable requirements of the code and any other applicable law, rule
or regulation.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-728 APPLICATION PROCESSING.
   The processing of the application by the Department of Community Development
is not complete until the Department has:
   (A)   Determined the application is complete;
   (B)   Determined the medical marijuana business is prepared and able to
operate in compliance with all applicable laws;
   (C)   Conducted an inspection of the business; and
   (D)   Prepared the documentation necessary to support the decision made by
the Department on the application.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-729 PERSONS PROHIBITED AS PERMITTEES.
   It shall be unlawful for any of the following persons to have an ownership
or a financial interest in a medical marijuana business, and no city medical
marijuana business permit provided by this chapter shall be issued to or held
by, and no medical marijuana business shall be managed by any person who
operates or manages a medical marijuana business contrary to the provisions of
this chapter, any other applicable law, rule or regulation or conditions
imposed on land use or city medical marijuana business permit approvals, or
contrary to the terms of the plans submitted with the city medical marijuana
business permit application, as such plans may be amended as provided in this
chapter.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
ARTICLE D. REQUIREMENTS RELATED TO THE OPERATION OF MEDICAL MARIJUANA
BUSINESSES
§8-740 ON-SITE USE PROHIBITED.
   No marijuana shall be smoked, eaten or otherwise consumed or ingested within
the medical marijuana business, as provided for in OMMA 442:10-5-6 as it may be
amended from time to time.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-741 DISPLAY OF CITY MEDICAL MARIJUANA BUSINESS PERMIT REQUIRED.
   A valid city medical marijuana business permit shall be conspicuously posted
in the business.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-742 BUSINESS CONDUCTED WITHIN BUILDING.
   Any and all cultivation, production, distribution, possession, storage,
display, sales or other distribution of marijuana shall not be visible from the
exterior of the business.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-743 USE OF METALS, BUTANE, PROPANE OR OTHER FLAMMABLE PRODUCTS.
   No medical marijuana business may use metals, butane, propane or other
flammable product, or produce flammable vapors, to process marijuana unless the
process used and the premises are verified as safe and in compliance with all
applicable zoning, fire and life safety codes.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-744 REVOCATION OF CITY MEDICAL MARIJUANA BUSINESS PERMIT UPON DENIAL OR
REVOCATION OF STATE LICENSE OR APPLICABLE FEDERAL PROHIBITION.
   If the state prohibits the cultivation, production, possession or other
distribution of marijuana through medical marijuana businesses, or if a medical
marijuana business permit is denied a commercial medical marijuana business
permit or has such permit revoked, or if a court of competent jurisdiction
determines that the federal government’s prohibition of the cultivation,
production, possession or other distribution of marijuana through medical
marijuana businesses supersedes state law, any city medical marijuana business
permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall be deemed to be immediately
revoked by operation of law, with no ground for appeal or other redress on
behalf of the permittee.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-745 REVOCABLE PRIVILEGE.
   A city medical marijuana business permit is a revocable privilege, and no
applicant therefor or holder thereof shall be deemed to have acquired any
property interest therein.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-746 PROHIBITED ACTS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any of the following acts:
   (A)   Cultivate, distribute or produce medical marijuana in plain view of or
in a place open to the general public;
   (B)   Smoke, use or ingest any medical marijuana on the premises of a
commercial medical marijuana business;
   (C)   Operate or be in physical control of any commercial medical marijuana
business, liquor establishment, vehicle, aircraft or motorboat while in a state
of intoxication;
   (D)   Possess medical marijuana that is not in a child-resistant package, as
defined by the State Medical Marijuana Authority, in a location where the
possessor is not authorized to possess or consume medical marijuana;
   (E)   Possess any form of medical marijuana in an amount exceeding the
limitations provided for in 63 O.S. § 420;
   (F)   Obtain medical marijuana from a person or entity that is not permitted
by the State Medical Marijuana Authority as a commercial medical marijuana
business;
   (G)   Possess or operate a commercial medical marijuana business in
violation of this chapter;
   (H)   Produce, distribute or possess more medical marijuana than allowed in
this chapter or than disclosed in the application to the state for a medical
marijuana business permit or other applicable law;
   (I)   Distribute medical marijuana without a commercial medical marijuana
business permit;
   (J)   Possess medical marijuana, own or manage a medical marijuana business,
or own or manage a building with a medical marijuana business, where there is
possession of medical marijuana by a person who is not a patient, caregiver or
a permittee of a medical marijuana business;
   (K)   Possess or operate a medical marijuana business in a location or in a
manner for which a medical marijuana business permit is prohibited by the terms
of this chapter;
   (L)   Operate a medical marijuana business without a commercial medical
marijuana business permit from the city;
   (M)   Operate a medical marijuana business in a manner that is not
consistent with the items disclosed in the application for the medical
marijuana business, or is in violation of any plan made part of the permit
application;
   (N)   Cultivate, manufacture, distribute or possess any medical marijuana at
a location without a commercial medical marijuana business permit prior to
passing the inspection required by this chapter;
   (O)   Make any changes, or for the permittee to allow any changes, to the
items included in the plans submitted with the permit application and approved
by the Department of Community Development, or the individuals identified in
the application, without prior approval of the Department of Community
Development;
   (P)   Use or attempt to use or display a medical marijuana business permit
at a different location or for a different business entity than the location
and business entity disclosed on the application for the issued permit;
   (Q)   Dispose of medical marijuana or any by-product of medical marijuana
containing marijuana in a manner contrary to this chapter;
   (R)   Deliver or transport medical marijuana between medical marijuana
businesses except in strict compliance with this chapter;
   (S)   Violate any provision of this code, or permit any other person to
violate any provision of this code, or any condition of an approval granted
pursuant to this code, or any law, rule or regulation applicable to the use of
medical marijuana or the operation of a medical marijuana business; and/or
   (T)   Lease any property to a medical marijuana business that has marijuana
on the property without a medical marijuana business permit that has been
issued by the Department of Community Development.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-747 SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF PERMIT; IMPOSITION OF FINES.
   (A)   A medical marijuana business permit may be suspended or revoked for
any of the following violations:
      (1)   Conviction of the business, a permittee or any owner, or primary
caregiver of any violation of this chapter or any other law, rule or regulation
applicable to the use of medical marijuana or operation of a medical marijuana
business;
      (2)   Misrepresentation or omission of any material fact, or false or
misleading information, on the application or any amendment thereto, or any
other information provided to the city related to the medical marijuana
business;
      (3)   Violation of any law by which, if occurring prior to submittal of
the application, could have been cause for denial of the permit application;
and/or
      (4)   Distribution of medical marijuana, including, without limitation,
transporting marijuana, in violation of this chapter or any other applicable
law, rule or regulation.
   (B)   In the event a business or permittee is charged with violation of any
law, upon which a final judgment would be grounds for suspension or revocation
of the permit, the city may suspend the permit pending the resolution of the
alleged violation.
   (C)   Fines for violations of this chapter may be imposed by the city
against the person or any permittee up to $500 per person and any permittee per
occurrence. Any person or permittee subjected to fines, revocation or
suspension of his, her or their permit shall be entitled to an administrative
hearing with the City Board of Adjustment.
   (D)   (1)   An appeal from any action, decision, ruling, judgment or order
of the Board of Adjustment may be taken by any person or persons, jointly or
severally, or any taxpayer, or any officer, department, board or bureau of the
city to the district court by filing notice of appeal with the City Clerk and
with the Board of Adjustment within ten days from the filing of the decision of
the Board of Adjustment which notice shall specify the grounds of such appeal.
      (2)   Upon filing of the notice of appeal as herein provided, the Board
of Adjustment shall forthwith transmit to the court clerk of the county the
original or certified copy of all the papers constituting the record in the
case, together with the order, decision or ruling of the Board of Adjustment.
   (E)   If the city revokes a permit, the business may not move any marijuana
from the premises except under the supervision of the City Police Department.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
§8-748 TERM OF PERMIT: RENEWALS, EXPIRATION OF PERMIT.
   (A)   Term of permit. A commercial medical marijuana business permit shall
be valid for one year. The permit shall expire on the last day of the month in
which the permit is issued of the year following issuance or renewal of the
permit.
   (B)   Renewal of permit. The permittee shall apply for renewal of the
commercial medical marijuana business permit at least 45 days before the
expiration of the permit. The permittee shall apply for renewal using forms
provided by the Department of Community Development.
      (1)   In the event any person who has an interest as described in the
disclosures made to the city pursuant to this chapter, or any agent as defined
herein, or employee has been charged with or accused of violations of any law
since such disclosure, the renewal application shall include the name of the
violator, the date of the violation, the court and case number where the
violation was filed and the disposition of the violation with the renewal
application.
      (2)   In the event the business permit has been suspended or revoked or a
permittee has received any notice of violation of any law that would impact
renewal, the renewal application shall include a copy of the notice, suspension
or revocation.
      (3)   The renewal application shall include verification that the
business has a valid state license and the state license is in good standing.
      (4)   The Department of Community Development shall not accept renewal
applications after the expiration of the permit, but instead shall require the
applicant to file a new permit application.
      (5)   In the event there have been allegations of violations of this code
by any of the permittees or the business submitting a renewal application, the
city may hold a hearing prior to approving the renewal application. The hearing
shall be to determine whether the application and proposed permittees comply
with this chapter and whether the operation of the business has been in
compliance with this code. If the city does not hold a hearing and the
application and the permittees do not meet the requirements of this chapter, or
the business has been operated in the past in violation of this code, the
renewal application may be denied or issued with conditions, and the decision
shall be final.
(Ord. 1813, passed 10-27-2020)
PART 9: LICENSING AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS
Chapter
   
1.    OCCUPATIONAL LICENSE TAX GENERALLY
   
2.    PEDDLERS, TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND CONTRIBUTION SOLICITORS

10.    GARAGE SALES
   
11.    PENALTY
   
12.    DONATION BOXES
CHAPTER 1: OCCUPATIONAL LICENSE TAX GENERALLY
Section
   
9-101   License tax levied on certain persons
§9-101 LICENSE TAX LEVIED ON CERTAIN PERSONS.
   A license tax is hereby levied on every person, firm, association or
corporation engaging in, exercising or pursuing any of the following
businesses, professions, trades, occupations or privileges in this city, in
such amounts as may be set by the City Council by motion or resolution:
   (A)   Book agents and canvassers taking orders of subscriptions;
   (B)   Junk dealers;
   (C)   Pawnbrokers;
   (D)   Auctioneers and vendors of medicine and other goods, wares or
merchandise upon the streets:
      (1)   Within the fire limits, as defined; or
      (2)   Outside fire limits.
   (E)   Electrical, plumbing, mechanical or building contractors; and
   (F)   House movers, only when in possession of a valid permit from the city
and appropriate state license.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. §§ 22-106 and 22-107
CHAPTER 2: PEDDLERS, TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND CONTRIBUTION SOLICITORS
Section
   
9-201   Permit and license required
   
9-202   Definitions
   
9-203   Exceptions
   
9-204   Application, transient merchant’s license
   
9-205   Application, peddler’s license
   
9-206   Application, contribution solicitation registration
   
9-207   Investigation, approval or disapproval
   
9-208   License fees
   
9-209   Bond for license
   
9-210   Service of process
   
9-211   Period of validity
   
9-212   Transfer
   
9-213   Prohibited acts
§9-201 PERMIT AND LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of peddler,
transient merchant or contribution solicitor as defined in §
9-202, within the corporate limits of the city, without first obtaining a
permit and license therefor or completing registration therefor as provided
therein.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. §§ 22-106 and 22-107
§9-202 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CONTRIBUTION SOLICITOR. Any person, group or organization which attempts, by
request or plea, to obtain money from a person, not a member of the same group
or organization for any cause or purpose when made at other than established
place of meetings, business, service or activity of the group or organization.
   PEDDLER. Door to door, street to street, place to place or temporary vendors
of sales or services without a fixed, determined and permanent location in the
city, at which he or she transacts his or her business, carries on his or her
occupation or practices his or her profession, including vendors who do not
sell from stock but exhibit samples only for the purpose of securing orders for
future delivery of sales or services.
   PERSON. Any person, firm or corporation, association, club, co-partnership
or society or any other organization.
   TRANSIENT MERCHANT. Includes an itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor, hawker
or huckster and is defined as any person, firm or corporation whether as owner,
agent, consignee or employee whether a resident of the city or not who engages
in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares or merchandise
within the city and who in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or
occupies any building, structure or shop for the exhibition and sale of such
goods, wares and merchandise, including a person, firm or corporation that,
while occupying a temporary location does not sell from stock, but exhibits
samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery.
§9-203 EXCEPTIONS.
   The regulations and licensing requirements of this chapter shall not apply
to:
   (A)   Any sales under court order;
   (B)   A bona fide auction sale;
   (C)   Traveling salespersons, commercial travelers or the like who
exclusively or primarily sell to retailers or solicit orders for future
delivery from retailers;
   (D)   The sale of farm, garden, artistic or hobby products by the person
producing or creating the same;
   (E)   The sale of a newspaper subscription in which the seller is a person
engaged in both the delivery and sale of the newspaper;
   (F)   Sales of items at less than $1.50 per item;
   (G)   Contribution solicitation where the person being solicited to
contribute personally knows the identity of the persons soliciting the
contribution or the name of the group or organization he or she represents and
the nature of the services performed or offered by the group or organization;
   (H)   The seasonal sale of Christmas trees; and
   (I)   The occasional sale of admission by school students to a function of
their school.
(Ord. 1431, passed 3-25-1997)
§9-204 APPLICATION, TRANSIENT MERCHANT’S LICENSE.
   Applicants for licenses for transient merchants shall file a written
application signed by the applicant if an individual, by all partners if a
partnership and by a corporation officer if a corporation, with the City
Treasurer showing:
   (A)   Name and address of person or persons having the management or
supervision of the applicant’s business during the time that it is proposed to
be carried on in the city; the location or address of such person or persons
when engaged in such business; the permanent address or addresses of such
person or persons; the capacity in which such person or persons will act; the
name and address of the person, firm or corporation for whose account the
business will be carried on, if any, and if a corporation, under the laws of
what state the same is incorporated;
   (B)   The place or places in the city where it is proposed to carry on
applicant’s business and the length of time during which it is proposed that
the business shall be conducted;
   (C)   Place or places, other than permanent place of business of the
applicant, within six months next preceding the date of the application where
the applicant has conducted a transient business; and
   (D)   A statement of the character of the goods, wares or merchandise to be
sold or offered for sale, by the applicant in the city, whether the same are
intended to be sold from stock in possession or from stock in possession and by
sample; such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of
the person or persons having management or supervision of applicant’s business
or the method or plan of doing business as the City Treasurer may deem proper
to fulfill the purpose of this chapter in the protection of the public good.
§9-205 APPLICATION, PEDDLER’S LICENSE.
   Applicants for a peddler’s license under this chapter, whether a person,
firm or corporation, shall file with the City Treasurer a written application
signed by the applicant, if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, or
by the president if a corporation, showing:
   (A)   Name and address of person or persons having the management or
supervision of the applicant’s business during the time that it is proposed to
be carried on in the city; the location or address of such person or persons
when engaged in such business; the permanent address or addresses of such
person or persons, the capacity in which such person or persons will act; the
name and address of the person, firm or corporation for whose account the
business will be carried on, if any, and if a corporation, under the laws of
what state the same is incorporated;
   (B)   The place or places in the city where it is proposed to carry on
applicant’s business and the length of time during which it is proposed that
the business shall be conducted;
   (C)   Place or places, other than permanent place of business of the
applicant, within six months next preceding the date of the application where
the applicant has conducted a transient business; and
   (D)   A statement of the character of the goods, wares or merchandise to be
sold or offered for sale by the applicant in the city, whether the same are
intended to be sold from stock in possession or from stock in possession and by
sample, such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of
the person or persons having management or supervision of applicant’s business
or the method or plan of doing business as the City Treasurer may deem proper
to fulfill the purpose of this chapter in the protection of the public good.
§9-206 APPLICATION, CONTRIBUTION SOLICITATION REGISTRATION.
   A fraternal, religious, veteran or other nonprofit organization not covered
by 18 O.S. § 552.4 may apply for registration as a contribution solicitor by
filing with the city a written application signed by an authorized
representative of such group, showing:
   (A)   The name of the organization, its purpose, its officers and directors,
period of solicitation and solicitor’s form of remuneration; and
   (B)   The applicant’s certification that the group is one of the persons or
organizations exempt from the licensing requirements of the State Solicitation
of Charitable Contributions Act, 18 O.S. §§ 552.1 through 552.16.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 18 O.S. §§ 552.1 et seq.
§9-207 INVESTIGATION, APPROVAL OR DISAPPROVAL.
   (A)   All applicants for licensing or registration shall be immediately
referred to the City Treasurer and by him or her or other persons acting in his
or her stead, investigated as to the truth thereof. The City Treasurer shall
have ten business days within which to investigate and take action thereon.
   (B)   If the City Treasurer finds no past history of the applicant
indicating violations of this section, and that the application is properly
made and truthful, he or she shall forthwith advise the applicant. The City
Treasurer shall issue a license, upon payment of the fee therefor, and the
filing of the required bond to the approved applicant, and shall approve the
completion of registration by a contribution solicitor.
   (C)   In all matters of denial by the City Treasurer of the license or
registration, the applicant shall be forthwith advised thereof and the
application shall be referred to the Council and considered by it at its next
regular meeting. The applicant shall be afforded an opportunity to be heard at
such meeting.
§9-208 LICENSE FEES.
   Fees for licenses granted herein shall be as set by the Council from time to
time by motion or resolution:
   (A)   Transient merchant’s license: annual and per day;
   (B)   Peddler’s license: annual or per day.
§9-209 BOND FOR LICENSE.
   Before any license as provided by this chapter shall be issued, such
applicant shall file with the city a bond running to the city as follows:
   (A)   A person engaging in business as a transient merchant, a bond in the
sum of $1,000 secured by the applicant, as principal and two sureties upon whom
service of process may be made in the state;
   (B)   A person engaging in business as a peddler, a bond in the sum of
$1,000 secured by the applicant, as principal and two sureties upon whom
service of process may be made in the state; and
   (C)   (1)   All such bonds shall be approved by the City Attorney and
conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all of the provisions of
the ordinances of the city, and the statutes of the state, regulating and
concerning the sale of goods, wares and merchandise and will pay all judgments
rendered against the applicant for any violation of the ordinance or statutes
or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered
against him or her by any person or persons for damage growing out of any
misrepresentation or deception practiced by any person transacting such
business with such applicant, whether such misrepresentation or deception were
made or practiced by the owners or by their service, agents or employees,
either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any
character whatsoever, printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares
and merchandise sold or any part thereof.
      (2)   Any action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city to
the use of the aggrieved person.
§9-210 SERVICE OF PROCESS.
   Before any license for a transient merchant or peddler as herein provided,
shall be issued, such applicant shall file with the city an instrument
nominating and appointing the City Treasurer, his or her true and lawful agent
with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for
and on behalf of the applicant in respect to any matters connected with or
arising out of the business transaction under the license and the bond given as
required by this chapter, or for the performance of the conditions of the bond
or for any breach thereof, which the instrument shall also contain recitals to
the effect that the applicant for the license consents and agrees to service of
any notices or process applying for the license under this chapter, according
to the laws of the state or any other state and waiving all claims or right of
error by reason of such acknowledgment of service or manner of service.
Immediately upon service of process upon the City Treasurer, the City Treasurer
shall send to the licensee at his or her last known address, by registered
mail, a copy of the notice.
§9-211 PERIOD OF VALIDITY.
   Licenses granted pursuant hereto shall be valid for a period of one year
from the date of issuance or approval.
§9-212 TRANSFER.
   No license shall be transferred without the consent of the City Manager as
evidenced by an endorsement on the face of the license by the City Treasurer
showing to whom the license is transferred and the date of the transfer.
§9-213 PROHIBITED ACTS.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any transient merchant, peddler or contribution
solicitor to engage in such business or activity for an unlawful business or
organizational purpose or activity.
   (B)   It is unlawful for any transient merchant, peddler or contribution
solicitor to practice harassment, nuisance, theft, deceit or menacing,
troublesome or otherwise unlawful activities during the course of such business
or activities.
   (C)   It is unlawful for any peddler or contribution solicitor to enter or
attempt to gain entrance on premises where a sign is posted with the words
“Peddlers and Solicitors Prohibited” or “Solicitors Prohibited.”
   (D)   It is unlawful for any peddler or contribution solicitor to refuse to
leave any premises when requested by the owner, lessee or person in charge or
possession thereof.
CHAPTER 3: PAWNBROKERS
Section
   
9-301   Definition
   
9-302   License required
   
9-303   Bond; conditions
   
9-304   Pawnbroker’s register; contents; how kept
   
9-305   Duty of pawnbroker to report to police
   
9-306   Register open to inspection
   
9-307   Receiving certain property forbidden
   
9-308   Selling pledge before default
§9-301 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definition shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PAWNBROKER. Any person who loans money on deposit of personal property, or
who deals in the purchase of personal property on condition of selling the same
back again at a stipulated price, or who makes a public display of his or her
business by a sign generally used by pawnbrokers to denote their business, such
as three yellow or gilt balls.
§9-302 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall carry on or engage in the business of a pawnbroker in the
city without first having obtained a license therefor in the city. The license
shall conform to those now provided or which may hereafter be provided by this
chapter.
§9-303 BOND; CONDITIONS.
   Every person hereafter applying for a license to engage in or carry on the
business of pawnbroker shall, before such license is issued to him or her,
enter into a bond with the city, with approved sureties, in the penal sum of
$1,000, conditioned that the applicant will strictly and faithfully observe all
ordinances, regulations and requirements of the city relating to pawnbrokers or
their businesses, and will pay all costs, fines and penalties incurred on the
account of his or her failure or neglect in that behalf, and will pay all
damages resulting to any person by reason of his or her wrongfully taking,
purchasing or receiving in pledge or on deposit any stolen property or the
property of any minor, which bond shall be filed with the City Treasurer and
may be sued upon by any person damaged, as aforesaid, in the name of the city,
for the use of such person, but in no event shall the city be liable for the
cost of such suit.
§9-304 PAWNBROKER’S REGISTER; CONTENTS; HOW KEPT.
   Every pawnbroker shall keep at his or her place of business a register in
which he or she shall enter in writing a minute description of all property
taken, purchased or received by him or her, including any number that may be in
or upon any article, together with the time, name and place of residence,
including street and number if within the city, of the person leaving the
property, also the amount loaned, interest charged and the time that the loan
falls due, which registry shall be kept clean and legible. He or she shall make
such entry immediately after the receipt or purchase of such property. Each
entry shall be made in ink and shall not in any manner be obliterated or
erased. He or she shall give a plainly written or printed ticket, having upon
it a full and complete copy of all entries required by ordinance to be kept in
such registry to the person leaving such property.
§9-305 DUTY OF PAWNBROKER TO REPORT TO POLICE.
   It is the duty of every pawnbroker to make out and deliver to the Chief of
Police, whenever required, a legible and correct copy from the registry of all
personal property or other valuable thing received, deposited or purchased at
any time.
§9-306 REGISTER OPEN TO INSPECTION.
   The register so kept by the pawnbroker shall be at all times kept open to
inspection by any police officer of the city or by any county or state peace
officer. The pawnbroker shall, upon request, show and exhibit to any officer
for inspection any article purchased, taken or received by him or her.
§9-307 RECEIVING CERTAIN PROPERTY FORBIDDEN.
   No pawnbroker shall take or receive in pledge or on deposit any article or
property of or from a minor or owned by any minor or any common drunkard, or
person under the influence of intoxicating liquor, or narcotic drugs, or any
stolen property, or property which for any reason he or she may have reason to
believe cannot be lawfully or rightfully pawned or pledged by the person
offering it.
§9-308 SELLING PLEDGE BEFORE DEFAULT.
   Any pawnbroker who shall sell any article received by him or her in pledge
before the time for redemption has expired, and every pawnbroker who willfully
refuses to disclose the name of the purchaser and the price received by him or
her for any article received by him or her in pledge, and subsequent sums, is
guilty of an offense and punishable as provided in §
1-108.
CHAPTER 4: JUNK DEALERS
Section
   
9-401   Licenses
   
9-402   Bond; condition
   
9-403   Registry of property
   
9-404   Duty to report to police
   
9-405   Registry open to inspection
   
9-406   Purchases forbidden
   
9-407   “Junk dealer” defined
   
9-408   Purchases forbidden at certain hours
§9-401 LICENSES.
   No person shall carry on or engage in business as a junk dealer, keeper of a
junk shop or dealer in secondhand goods in the city without first obtaining a
license therefor, and a secondhand dealer shall be construed as any person who
shall purchase any kind of previously used goods. All exhibitors at coin shows,
art shows or similar type shows, where sponsored by a local organization and,
upon obtaining approval of the Chief of Police of the city, are exempted from
the licensing requirement of this section and the requirement to retain
property purchased for 15 days as provided in §
9-403.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 59 O.S. §§ 1501 et seq.
§9-402 BOND; CONDITION.
   Every person applying for a license to engage in or carry on the business of
a junk dealer, keeper of a junk shop or dealer in secondhand goods, shall,
before such license is issued, enter into an approved bond with the city in the
penal sum of $1,000, conditioned that the applicant will strictly and
faithfully observe all ordinances, regulations and requirements of the city
relating to the conduct of a junk shop, business of a junk dealer or dealer in
secondhand goods, and will pay all costs, fines and penalties incurred on the
account of failure or neglect in that behalf, and pay all damages resulting to
any person by reason of any wrongful taking, purchasing or receiving of any
stolen property or the property of any minor, which bond shall be filed with
the City Treasurer and may be sued upon by any person damaged in the name of
the city for the use of such person, but in no event shall the city be liable
for the costs of such suit.
§9-403 REGISTRY OF PROPERTY.
   (A)   Every junk dealer, keeper of a junk shop or dealer in secondhand
goods, shall keep at his or her place of business a registry in which he or she
shall enter the following:
      (1)   The date of purchase of each item;
      (2)   The name and address of the seller or transferor;
      (3)   The items purchased or received;
      (4)   The price paid for each item; and
      (5)   The signature of the seller or transferor.
   (B)   All entries shall be made in ink and shall not in any manner be
obliterated or erased.
   (C)   All persons, firms or corporations carrying on such business shall
keep all property purchased in their place of business within the city, in the
same condition the property was in at the time of purchase or receipt for at
least 15 days after the date of purchase or receipt of such property and keep
same available for inspection during the 15-day period before disposing of such
property.
§9-404 DUTY TO REPORT TO POLICE.
   It is the duty of every junk dealer, keeper of a junk shop or dealer in
secondhand goods, to make out and deliver to the Chief of Police, upon request,
a legible and correct copy of any part or parts of the registry for any day or
days in which goods have been received or purchased; provided, that no junk
dealer, keeper of a junk shop or secondhand goods shall be required to keep a
registry or furnish such description of any property purchased from any person
having an established place of business in the city, nor of goods sold at
public sale; but such goods must be accompanied by a bill of sale or other
evidence of open and legitimate purchase and must be shown to any member of the
Police Department when required.
§9-405 REGISTRY OPEN TO INSPECTION.
   Any registry so kept shall, at all times, be kept open to inspection by any
police officer of the city or by any state or county officer. The dealer shall,
upon request, show and exhibit to any officer for inspection any article
purchased by him or her.
§9-406 PURCHASES FORBIDDEN.
   No junk dealer, keeper of a junk shop or dealer in secondhand goods shall
receive any article of property of or from a minor, or owned by any minor, or
from any drunkard or person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor
or narcotic drugs, or any stolen property or any property which, for any
reason, he or she may believe the same cannot be lawfully or rightfully sold by
the person offering it.
§9-407 “JUNK DEALER” DEFINED.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definition shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   JUNK DEALER. Any person who shall carry on the business of buying secondhand
brass, copper, iron, precious metals, precious stones, jewelry, leather
belting, plumbing or electrical fixtures, burlap bags, tools, machinery or
materials or supplies commonly used in the drilling, completing, operating or
repairing of oil and gas wells.
§9-408 PURCHASES FORBIDDEN AT CERTAIN HOURS.
   No junk dealer, keeper of a junk shop or dealer in secondhand goods shall
take or receive from any persons any articles of property between the hours of
9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.
CHAPTER 5: RECREATION CENTERS
Section
   
9-501   “Recreation centers” defined
   
9-502   License required
   
9-503   License requirements
   
9-504   Restrictions on location of and operation of recreation centers
   
9-505   Suspension or revocation of license
§9-501 “RECREATION CENTERS” DEFINED.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definition shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   RECREATION CENTER. Any place, business or premises which maintains more than
one pool table, snooker table or billiard table or one or more electronic or
video games, pinball machines, table games or other similar services, provided
that the following shall not be considered recreation centers:
   (A)   Private homes;
   (B)   Duly licensed bottle clubs, taverns, bars and dance hall;
   (C)   Churches and church recreation or activity centers;
   (D)   Businesses maintaining either:
      (1)   Not more than one table for pool, snooker or billiards;
      (2)   Not more than five or a combination of not more than five of any of
the following: electronic or video games, pinball machines, table games or
similar amusement games or devices; or
      (3)   Provided that the tables, games, machines or devices occupy a floor
space equivalent to less than 5% of the maximum occupancy of the business, as
established by the building code of the city.
§9-502 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, partnership or association
to operate or maintain a recreation center, as defined in §
9-501, without a valid annual license therefor issued by the City Treasurer.
§9-503 LICENSE REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Application for an annual license shall be made on forms provided by
the City Clerk.
   (B)   Licenses shall be issued on an annual basis and shall expire on April
30 of the year for which it is issued.
   (C)   The annual fee for the license for the operation of a recreation
center shall be as set by the City Council by motion or resolution, payable
upon the issuance of the annual license.
   (D)   Holders of recreation center licenses shall conspicuously display such
licenses on the premises of the licensed recreation center.
§9-504 RESTRICTIONS ON LOCATION OF AND OPERATION OF RECREATION CENTERS.
   It is unlawful for any person, firm, partnership or association to:
   (A)   Operate a recreation center at any location in violation of the city’s
zoning ordinance or the constitution and laws of the state;
   (B)   Operate a recreation center between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 7:00
a.m.; provided, however, that upon the close of business on Saturday, no
recreation center shall open before 1:00 p.m. on the following Sunday;
   (C)   Permit any intoxicated person whether by alcohol, drugs or other
substances to be in or about the premises; and
   (D)   Sell, barter, give away or permit the consumption of alcoholic
beverages or beer in or about the premises of such recreation center.
§9-505 SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   (A)   All complaints concerning recreation centers shall be submitted to the
Chief of Police for investigation. If the Chief of Police finds that a
violation of the provisions of this chapter has been committed, he or she shall
file a complaint with the city, setting forth the alleged acts constituting the
violation. Upon the filing of such a complaint, the city shall fix a date for
hearing of the complaint by the City Council and shall cause to be served upon
the licensee a copy of the complaint and notice of the time and place of the
hearing. The complaint and notice of hearing may be served upon the manager,
operator, partner or person shown on the application for the license as having
supervisory control over the premises of the recreation center or if such
person may not be found, by mailing the same by registered or certified mail
addressed to such person at the licensed premises. At the hearing thereon, the
complainant, the licensee or any interested person may be present and present
such evidence as may be relevant and material. If at the conclusion of such
hearing, the City Council finds that the licensee has violated any of the
provisions of this chapter, the City Council shall suspend for not more than 15
days or revoke the license issued hereunder. Upon suspension or revocation, the
licensee shall immediately cease operating as a recreation center.
   (B)   Following the revocation of any recreation center license, an
application for a license as a recreation center upon the same premises shall
not be accepted by the City Treasurer for a period of 30 days following the
revocation.
CHAPTER 6: COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES
Section
   
9-601   Definitions
   
9-602   License fee
   
9-603   Application for license
   
9-604   Display of license
   
9-605   Prohibited devices not legalized
§9-601 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES.
      (1)   Any and all mechanical devices which upon the payment or insertion
of a coin, script, token or similar object which causes, permits or is
incentive for, the propelling or motivating of any ball, marble, electronic
simulation or other gadget or object that produces or creates or makes possible
the production or creation of a game of skill, amusement, entertainment or test
of strength including, but not limited to, shuffleboards, coin-operated devices
utilizing tables, boards or cases of any size whatsoever, balls, sticks, cues,
pegs or marbles; and whether or not any motivating force involved is furnished
by the player or the device.
      (2)   COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES shall not include coin-operated
machines operated by penny coins only; or coin-operated vending machines used
exclusively for the purpose of selling tangible, personal property, such as
cold drinks, tobacco products, candies, postage stamps or other similar
merchandise; or services such as pay telephones, parking meters, gas or
electric meters or other distribution of needful services.
   POOL, BILLIARD OR SNOOKER TABLE. Any table specifically manufactured for the
purpose of playing pool, billiards or snooker, whether or not the tables are
coin-operated.
§9-602 LICENSE FEE.
   (A)   Every person who owns and has available to the public, or who permits
to be operated by the public in or on his or her place of business any coin-
operated amusement devices, pool tables, billiard tables or snooker tables,
shall pay for an annual license for each such device.
   (B)   There is levied an annual license fee on each amusement device in such
sum as set by the City Council by motion or resolution.
   (C)   For the purpose of this section, the term PUBLIC shall not include
churches and church recreation or activity centers.
§9-603 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   (A)   Application for an annual license on such devices shall be made to the
Treasurer.
   (B)   The application form shall contain the name of the applicant, a
description of the device, location of the device and such other information
deemed necessary by the Treasurer to identify the device.
   (C)   Any number of machines may be included in one application.
   (D)   Upon payment of the license fee and approval of the application, the
Treasurer shall issue a license for the device or devices covered by the
application.
§9-604 DISPLAY OF LICENSE.
   Before any coin-operated amusement device, pool table or snooker table is
put into operation or placed where the same may be operated by the public, and
at all times when the same is being operated, or is available to the public for
operation, a license, issued by the city, shall be firmly affixed to the device
covered thereby and plainly visible to and readable by the public.
§9-605 PROHIBITED DEVICES NOT LEGALIZED.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to legalize any device that may
be prohibited by the laws of this state or the ordinances of the city. The
Treasurer may assume that any device described in any application, and for
which a license fee is paid, is lawful; and no claim for a refund of any
license fee will be entertained based upon an owner’s or operator’s inability
to operate such devices because of any law of this state or city or for any
other reason.
CHAPTER 7: PRIVATE SECURITY OFFICERS
Section
   
9-701   Purpose
   
9-702   Definitions
   
9-703   Issuance of commissions and permits
   
9-704   Application
   
9-705   Contents
   
9-706   Physical examination
   
9-707   Investigation, interview, ineligibility for commission
   
9-708   Bond requirements
   
9-709   Appointment; action on application; temporary commission
   
9-710   Orientation
   
9-711   Annual application required for commissions and permits
   
9-712   Changes in service areas; processing fee; discontinuance of service
   
9-713   Badge and uniform
   
9-714   Time and place of permanent security service
   
9-715   Service restricted to authorized area
   
9-716   Authority to arrest
   
9-717   Rules and regulations
   
9-718   Suspension, revocation or inquiry regarding commission or permit;
public hearing
   
9-719   Nonliability of the city
§9-701 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to preserve the public health, safety, morals
and general welfare by regulation and control of the business of private
security officers.
§9-702 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BUSINESS DAY. Monday through Friday, inclusive, but excluding holidays.
   GUARD SERVICE. Stationary armed guards serving private citizens at a
particular and specified place or location.
   PATROL SERVICE. A motorized armed patrol serving private citizens or
companies in a specified geographical area, which area shall be established by
naming the streets forming the exterior boundaries of the area served.
   PERMANENT SECURITY SERVICE. Regularly armed schedule service furnished
hourly, daily, weekly, monthly or for any other period at a specified area,
place or location.
   PRIVATE SECURITY COMPANIES. Any organization or person offering services as
an independent contractor and employing armed private security officers who are
commissioned under the provisions of this chapter. A one-person operation shall
not be considered a PRIVATE SECURITY COMPANY.
   PRIVATE SECURITY OFFICER. Any officer commissioned to provide patrol or
guard service as an independent contractor and who shall be authorized to carry
firearms under the provision of this chapter.
   TEMPORARY SECURITY SERVICE. Service not offered on a regularly armed
scheduled basis.
§9-703 ISSUANCE OF COMMISSIONS AND PERMITS.
   The Chief of Police, subject to the provisions of this chapter, is hereby
authorized to grant commissions to private officers and permits to private
security companies.
§9-704 APPLICATION.
   (A)   To apply for a commission:
      (1)   Each person applying for appointment for commission shall make a
written application on forms provided by the Chief of Police; and
      (2)   A processing fee as set by the Council shall be charged for each
application and for each annual renewal.
   (B)   To apply for a permit:
      (1)   Each private security company applying for a permit shall make a
written application on forms provided by the Chief of Police; and
      (2)   A processing fee as set by the Council shall be charged for each
application and for each annual renewal.
§9-705 CONTENTS.
   Applications for commissions or permits shall contain the following
information:
   (A)   Private security officer commission for guard service:
      (1)   Company, if any, employing the applicant;
      (2)   A standard personal history statement completed on a form provided
by the Chief of Police; and
      (3)   Such other and additional information deemed necessary by the Chief
of Police or City Manager.
   (B)   Private security company permit for guard service:
      (1)   Names of the officers, principals or resident manager of the
company;
      (2)   A standard personal history and statement completed on a form
provided by the Chief of Police; and
      (3)   Such other and additional information deemed necessary by the Chief
of Police or City Manager relating to those persons.
   (C)   Private security officer commission for patrol service:
      (1)   The specific places or area where services would be rendered;
      (2)   Hours of the day when services would be rendered if the applicant
is self-employed;
      (3)   The company, if any, employing the applicant;
      (4)   A standard personal history statement completed on a form provided
by the Chief of Police; and
      (5)   Such other and additional information deemed necessary by the Chief
of Police or City Manager.
   (D)   Private security company permit for patrol service:
      (1)   The names of the officers, principals or resident manager of the
company;
      (2)   A standard personal history statement completed on a form provided
by the Chief of Police; and
      (3)   The specific area of properties where the service would be
furnished and the hours of the day that service would be furnished.
§9-706 PHYSICAL EXAMINATION.
   After application for commission is filed, the applicant shall submit a
report from a duly licensed physician, of a physical examination taken within
one year.
§9-707 INVESTIGATION, INTERVIEW, INELIGIBILITY FOR COMMISSION.
   (A)   Prior to the issuance of a commission, the Police Department shall
conduct a complete background inquiry of the applicant, and the applicant shall
be personally interviewed by the Chief of Police or his or her representative
and the applicant’s photograph and fingerprints shall be obtained.
   (B)   Each applicant will be interviewed as to his or her ability to safely
handle firearms.
   (C)   The Chief of Police shall refuse commissions to all persons who have
been convicted of a felony under the laws of the state or of any other state,
or of the United States, or any offense involving moral turpitude, and to all
minors, drug addicts, unnaturalized foreign born persons and such other persons
as he or she has reasonable cause to believe are not of sound mind.
§9-708 BOND REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Prior to the issuance of a commission, each individual applicant shall
file with the city a surety bond or certificate of insurance of general
liability in the amount of $10,000 written by a duly qualified bonding or
insurance company licensed to do business in the state.
   (B)   Prior to the issuance of a permit, each company applicant may file a
bond or certificate of insurance in the amount of $100,000 in lieu of the
individual bonds of its employees.
   (C)   The bond or certificate of insurance shall be renewed and filed
annually with the application for renewal of the commission or permit.
   (D)   The requirements of this section are satisfied if a copy of the
general liability bond or certificate of insurance is on file with the state.
§9-709 APPOINTMENT; ACTION ON APPLICATION; TEMPORARY COMMISSION.
   (A)   If the Chief of Police, subject to the requirements of this chapter
and approval of the City Manager, finds the applicant eligible for a
commission, the applicant shall be appointed as a private officer to service in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   The Chief of Police shall act on all applications within 15 business
days from the time of the filing of the applications.
   (C)   Pending action by the Chief of Police on applications, a temporary
commission may be issued in a case where the delay in granting it would cause
undue hardship on the applicant.
§9-710 ORIENTATION.
   A commissioned private officer shall attend those classes of orientation
reasonably appropriate to his or her service to be rendered as designated by
the Chief of Police and given as directed by the Chief of Police.
§9-711 ANNUAL APPLICATION REQUIRED FOR COMMISSIONS AND PERMITS.
   Reapplication shall be made annually for each commission and permit. The
application for renewal need not be reprocessed but shall be filed with the
Chief of Police by June 15. Unless the applications are received by June 30,
the commission or permit shall be terminated without further action on July 1.
§9-712 CHANGES IN SERVICE AREAS; PROCESSING FEE; DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE.
   (A)   Application for approval and the payment of a processing fee as set by
the Council shall be required:
      (1)   Before a private security officer or company performing patrol
service may service additional areas;
      (2)   Before a private security officer or company performing guard
service may furnish permanent security service at an additional area; and
      (3)   Before a private security officer or company shall furnish
temporary security service at an additional area.
   (B)   When permanent service is discontinued in an area or at a location,
written notification shall be sent to the Chief of Police.
§9-713 BADGE AND UNIFORM.
   A duly commissioned private officer, when on duty, shall have on his or her
person his or her commission and shall wear uniform, badge or other emblems of
authority as approved by the Chief of Police, which shall in any event be
clearly distinctive and different from that of regular city police officers and
shall designate the officer as private officer, security officer or security
service.
§9-714 TIME AND PLACE OF PERMANENT SECURITY SERVICE.
   The Chief of Police, with the approval of the City Manager, shall designate
the specific place or area and hours of the day that each private officer or
company may furnish permanent security patrol service.
§9-715 SERVICE RESTRICTED TO AUTHORIZED AREA.
   Duly commissioned private officers or private security companies shall at
all times service only the place or specifically defined geographical area
where they are authorized to serve under the provisions of this chapter.
§9-716 AUTHORITY TO ARREST.
   A duly commissioned private officer is not a member of the Police Department
and shall not have the authority of a police officer. He or she shall, while on
duty at his or her assigned place, have the right to carry a pistol or revolver
and make arrests only as a private citizen is granted authority by State
statutes.
§9-717 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Chief of Police shall promulgate and publish, with the approval of the
City Manager and Council, those additional rules and regulations consistent
with this chapter and as may be necessary to its implementation. Copies shall
be furnished applicants upon request.
§9-718 SUSPENSION, REVOCATION OR INQUIRY REGARDING COMMISSION OR PERMIT; PUBLIC
HEARING.
   (A)   The commission of any private security officer or permit of any
private security company may be suspended or revoked at any time by the Chief
of Police for violation of any of the requirements necessary for a commission
or permit or for violation of any rule or regulation established pursuant to
this chapter or during pendency of inquiry into the discharge of a firearm.
   (B)   Upon a violation occurring, the Chief of Police or his or her
representative shall give the private security officer or private security
company notice of any suspension or revocation hearing at least five days prior
to the date of public hearing, and such notice shall be furnished by mail. The
suspension or revocation hearings will be conducted by a three-member board
consisting of:
      (1)   The Chief of Police or his or her representative;
      (2)   The City Manager or his or her representative; and
      (3)   The City Attorney.
§9-719 NONLIABILITY OF THE CITY.
   Any commissioned private officer, while in the performance of his or her
duties as a private officer, shall not be deemed to be an agent, servant or
employee of the city and the city shall not be liable for his or her actions to
third parties or for any injury or damage he or she might suffer.
CHAPTER 8: PRIVATE INVESTIGATORS
Section
   
9-801   Definitions
   
9-802   Exemptions
   
9-803   License required
   
9-804   Application for license
   
9-805   Investigation of fingerprints by Chief of Police
   
9-806   Standards for issuance of license
   
9-807   Action on application
   
9-808   License fee
   
9-809   Employees
   
9-810   Identification cards
   
9-811   Conditions of licensing
   
9-812   Appeal from action by City Treasurer
   
9-813   Action to revoke or suspend license
   
9-814   Conduct of Committee hearings
   
9-815   Appeal procedure
   
9-816   Composition of the Private Investigator’s Review Committee
§9-801 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ASSISTANT PRIVATE INVESTIGATOR. Any person not eligible for a private
investigator’s license but who is engaged in the business of private
investigator under the direct supervision and control of a licensee hereunder.
   BUSINESS OF PRIVATE INVESTIGATOR. Shall consist of the business of making,
for hire or reward or any consideration whatsoever, an investigation or
investigations by a person or persons for the purpose of obtaining information
with reference to any of the following matters:
      (1)   Private or public crimes;
      (2)   Credibility of witnesses or other persons;
      (3)   Habits, conduct, movements, associations, transactions, reputation
or character of persons;
      (4)   The location or recovery of lost or stolen property;
      (5)   Securing of evidence to be used before investigating committees,
boards of award or arbitration or in the trial of civil or criminal cases and
proceedings;
      (6)   Wrongs to persons or property done or threatened; or
      (7)   Causes, origin or responsibility for fires or accidents or injuries
to real or personal property, strikes or labor disputes.
   COMMITTEE. The City Private Investigator’s Review Committee.
§9-802 EXEMPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any investigator or
