officer belonging to the police force of the federal, state, county or city
government appointed or elected by due authority of law while engaged in the
performance of his or her official duties; nor to any given person in the
employ of the police force or Police Department of the state or of the county
or city while engaged in the performance of his or her official duties; nor to
any attorneys at law or legal interns in the regular practice of their
profession; nor any person, firm or corporation legally and solely employed as
insurance adjusters who engage in investigative activities connected only with
adjustment of claims against an insurance company; nor any person, firm or
corporation whose sole business is the furnishing of information as to the
business and financial standing and credit of persons, firms or corporation;
nor to any person making any investigation of any matter in which such person
or his or her sole employer is involved or interested; nor to any investigator
employed exclusively for one employer in connection with the business of a
collection agency; nor to any person employed exclusively by private
investigators for secretarial purposes; nor to any person or persons employed
for, or in the business of furnishing for hire or reward, guard or guards,
watch person(s), patrols or other persons to protect or to prevent the theft or
the unlawful taking of goods, wares and merchandise.
§9-803 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate, advertise or otherwise hold himself or herself out
as a private investigator in the city without first obtaining a license as
hereinafter provided from the City Treasurer or his or her designee.
§9-804 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   (A)   Application for license issued hereunder shall be made upon blank
forms prepared and made available by the City Treasurer or his or her designee
and shall state:
      (1)   The full name, age, residence, telephone number and present and
previous employment record of the applicant;
      (2)   Applicant’s citizenship;
      (3)   The firm name and specific location of the place of business of
applicant;
      (4)   Number of years’ experience applicant has had as a private
detective, or in related fields;
      (5)   Length of time applicant has been a bona fide resident of the state
immediately preceding the filing of the application;
      (6)   Summary of military service, including date thereof and whether or
not applicant was honorably discharged;
      (7)   All convictions of applicant for felonies and misdemeanors
involving moral turpitude;
      (8)   Place and date of birth;
      (9)   Affidavits from at least three persons who have personally known
the applicant for a period of at least three years prior to the filing of such
application, as to the moral character of the applicant; provided such persons
be not related to the applicant by blood or marriage; and
      (10)   Affidavits from those who can personally attest to the applicant’s
experience during specific time periods in the business of private investigator
or as assistant private investigator, sufficient when added together, to
establish that the applicant has met the minimum standards for issuance of
license.
   (B)   The application required hereunder shall be accompanied by a full set
of fingerprints and a recent photograph and shall be verified by the applicant.
The application required shall be accompanied by an application fee as set by
the Council.
§9-805 INVESTIGATION OF FINGERPRINTS BY CHIEF OF POLICE.
   Within ten days after receipt of an application as provided for herein, the
Chief of Police shall cause such fingerprints of known criminals made, and if
any record is found affecting such prints, the Chief of Police shall
immediately notify the City Treasurer.
§9-806 STANDARDS FOR ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   (A)   The City Treasurer shall issue a license hereunder when he or she
finds:
      (1)   That the applicant has complied fully with the provisions
pertaining to the application for license;
      (2)   That the applicant has never been convicted of any felony or any
misdemeanor involving moral turpitude as determined by the Chief of Police;
      (3)   That the applicant is a citizen of the United States of America,
or, if not a citizen, submits proof that he or she is an alien lawfully
admitted within the country;
      (4)   That the applicant is at least 21 years of age;
      (5)   That the applicant has not been discharged from the armed services
of the United States under other than honorable conditions; and
      (6)   That the applicant has at least 2,000 hours’ experience engaged in
the business of private investigator or as assistant private investigator. For
the purpose of this section, the applicant may have gained such experience in
the business of private investigator while in the employ of any branch of
federal, state, county or city government.
   (B)   The standards herein set forth shall be exclusive and no additional
requirements can be imposed except by amendment of this chapter.
§9-807 ACTION ON APPLICATION.
   The City Treasurer shall act upon the application within 30 days after
receiving same. If all application requirements are met, a license shall be
issued to the successful applicant upon the payment of a license fee as herein
provided. If the City Treasurer disapproves or denies the application, he or
she shall notify the applicant in writing within ten days thereafter, giving
specific reasons for the disapproval or denial. Any applicant aggrieved shall
have the right of appeal, after notice to the Committee as herein provided.
§9-808 LICENSE FEE.
   A license fee as set by the City Council by motion or resolution shall be
paid to the city annually by all persons licensed hereunder.
§9-809 EMPLOYEES.
   The licensed private investigator may employ, to assist him or her in the
business of private investigator, as many persons as he or she shall deem
necessary pursuant to the following conditions.
   (A)   The licensee shall at all times accept full responsibility for the
conduct in the business of each and every person so employed.
   (B)   The licensee shall be responsible to see that all such employees meet
the requirements of §
9-806(A)(2) through (A)(5).
   (C)   Within ten days after employment of an assistant private investigator,
the licensed private investigator by whom such person has been employed shall
cause an employee registration form provided by the City Treasurer to be filed
with the City Treasurer upon payment of a registration fee as set by the
Council.
   (D)   The Chief of Police shall issue a photo identification card to the
employee pursuant to the regulation providing for identification cards.
   (E)   The employee’s status as assistant private investigator automatically
terminates upon the expiration, revocation or suspension of the responsible
employer/private investigator. It is the duty of the private investigator to
surrender the employee’s identification card when made necessary by this
provision.
§9-810 IDENTIFICATION CARDS.
   (A)   (1)   The Chief of Police shall issue a photo identification to an
applicant for a private investigator’s license upon determination that the
application has been approved by the City Treasurer and that the license fee
has been paid.
      (2)   Such card shall state the name of the applicant, the name of the
applicant’s business firm, the words “private investigator” and the expiration
date of the license.
   (B)   (1)   The Chief of Police shall issue a photo identification card to
an assistant private investigator upon determination that the appropriate
registration fee has been paid and that the employee has not been convicted of
a felony or any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude after having compared the
employee’s fingerprints with those of known criminals.
      (2)   Such card shall state the name of the employee, the words
“assistant private investigator employed by” and the name of the employee’s
business firm.
§9-811 CONDITIONS OF LICENSING.
   (A)   (1)   Licenses issued hereunder shall not be transferable. In
addition, a licensee who changes business firms must notify the City Treasurer
in writing within seven days of the effective date of such change.
      (2)   At the same time, the licensee shall turn in his or her
identification card and those of any assistant private investigators employed
by him or her, and upon paying a $5 processing charge for each new card
desired, shall be issued a new photo identification card or cards identical in
all respects except for the change in the business firm name.
   (B)   The City Treasurer shall issue renewal licenses to all licensees whose
licenses have not been suspended or revoked at the time the licenses have
expired, and for 90 days thereafter, upon payment of the license fee.
   (C)   All licenses issued hereunder shall expire on June 30 of each year.
   (D)   The Private Investigator’s Review Committee may, after hearing,
suspend for definite periods of time or revoke a license, or refuse a license
issued under this chapter:
      (1)   If such licensee has knowingly violated any of the provisions of
this chapter;
      (2)   If the licensee has knowingly made a false report in writing to his
or her client or other person entitled to receive such information, in respect
to any of the matters for which the licensee may be employed;
      (3)   If the licensee, during his or her employment by the client, shall
accept money or gratuities from any person whose affairs he or she may have
been employed by such client to investigate;
      (4)   If the licensee has knowingly or wrongfully divulged to any person
other than his or her client or employer, except as his or her client or
employer shall direct and except as may be required by law, any information
acquired by him or her during such employment, with respect to any of the work
to which he or she, or any other employee of such licensee, shall have been
assigned by the licensee, or with respect to any of the work, business or
affairs of the trustee;
      (5)   If the licensee has, knowingly or willfully, falsely stated or
represented any matter of information contained as a part of an application for
license hereunder;
      (6)   If the licensee willfully fails or refuses to render to a client
services or a report as agreed between the parties for which compensation has
been paid or tendered in accordance with the written agreement of the parties;
      (7)   If such licensee willfully fails or refuses to return to a client
the unused portion of a retainer or compensation which has been paid or
tendered, in accordance with the written agreement of the parties;
      (8)   If the licensee is convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving
moral turpitude;
      (9)   If the licensee has practiced any fraud, deceit or intentional
misrepresentation; and
      (10)   If an employee of a licensee has committed any of the
aforementioned acts at the direction and with the knowledge of the licensee.
   (E)   Identification cards issued hereunder shall remain the property of the
city and shall be surrendered by the licensee to the City Treasurer upon
expiration, revocation or suspension of a license.
§9-812 APPEAL FROM ACTION BY CITY TREASURER.
   (A)   Appeals from any action of the City Treasurer may be taken by the
person aggrieved to the Committee by filing within 30 days of the receipt of
notice of such action a written notice of appeal with the Chairperson of the
Committee stating the grounds for appeal.
   (B)   Upon receipt of such notice of appeal, the Committee shall, within 20
days thereafter, hold a public hearing thereon. At the conclusion of such
hearing, the Committee shall affirm, modify or reverse the action taken by the
City Treasurer.
§9-813 ACTION TO REVOKE OR SUSPEND LICENSE.
   (A)   (1)   The Committee shall, upon receipt by the Committee Chairperson
of a verified written complaint of any person setting forth facts which, if
proven, would constitute grounds for revocation or suspension of a license as
set forth herein, cause an inquiry to be made of all information presented for
its consideration.
      (2)   Only upon completion of the inquiry where a majority of the
Committee then present and voting are satisfied that the inquiry reveals
reasonable grounds to proceed, will a hearing be conducted.
   (B)   The Committee shall cause notice to the licensee of the following
prior to concluding the inquiry:
      (1)   The information has been presented to the Committee that the
licensee has allegedly committed an act or acts which may amount to grounds for
revocation or suspension;
      (2)   The Committee will conduct an inquiry designed to ascertain the
basis of such information;
      (3)   The licensee will be afforded an opportunity to be heard before the
Committee; and
      (4)   If the inquiry reveals reasonable grounds to conduct a hearing, the
procedures outlined herein shall apply.
   (C)   After inquiry and a determination by the Committee that a hearing
should be conducted, the Committee shall schedule a hearing on a date certain
wherein the licensee shall have been given not less than 14 days’ nor more than
28 days’ advance notice of the date of the hearing.
   (D)   Notice of the licensee required herein shall consist of the following:
      (1)   Notification that the Committee is in receipt of information that
the licensee is alleged to have committed an act or acts which may be grounds
for revocation or suspension;
      (2)   The Committee on its own inquiry has reasonable belief that the act
or acts of the theretofore presented information have occurred;
      (3)   The Committee has scheduled a fact-finding hearing, on a date from
14 to 28 days from the notice, to ascertain the full facts surrounding the
information; and
      (4)   The licensee has full right of appearance and representation before
the Committee on the date as specified.
   (E)   Any notice required herein shall be in writing and may be served by
delivery of the notice personally to the licensee or by mailing the notice by
registered mail to the place of business last theretofore specified by such
licensee in his or her last communication with the Committee.
   (F)   Upon good cause shown, the Committee may continue for up to 14 days
the hearing as scheduled.
   (G)   The Committee shall, after full consideration, notify the licensee and
the City Treasurer in writing of its decision and the reasons therefor within
14 days from the date the decision was rendered.
§9-814 CONDUCT OF COMMITTEE HEARINGS.
   All hearings before the Committee as required herein shall be held as
scheduled before a majority of the Committee members and be of a fact-finding
nature and will not be adversarial in scope or in nature. Strict legal rules of
evidence shall not be followed for the reason that the proceedings before the
Committee shall be to ascertain all facts surrounding the matter before the
Committee, matters of an irrelevant or immaterial nature excepted.
§9-815 APPEAL PROCEDURE.
   Any person aggrieved by the Committee’s decision to deny, revoke or suspend
a private investigator’s license shall have the right to appeal to the district
court.
§9-816 COMPOSITION OF THE PRIVATE INVESTIGATOR’S REVIEW COMMITTEE.
   (A)   The Mayor of the city, with the approval of the City Council, shall
appoint the Private Investigator’s Review Committee, which shall be composed of
two private investigators licensed as outlined herein or two investigators in
the described field, one private attorney at law, one private citizen and the
Chief of Police or his or her designated representative. The members of the
Committee shall be appointed for a term of three years, except the members
first appointed shall be appointed for a term of one, or two, or three years as
designated by the Mayor.
   (B)   The Committee shall elect from among its members the person who is to
serve as Chairperson.
   (C)   No person shall be appointed to the Private Investigator’s Review
Committee who holds office as an elected officer of the city, state or federal
government, or who is not a resident of the city. A member of the Committee may
be removed from office prior to the expiration of his or her term, for cause,
by the Mayor, only upon written request by three members of the Private
Investigator’s Review Committee, which written request shall set forth specific
reasons for the member’s removal.
CHAPTER 9: CITY AMBULANCE SERVICE
Section
   
9-901   Definitions
   
9-902   Contract for sole provider ambulance service
   
9-903   Investigation of sole provider
   
9-904   Minimum standards
   
9-905   Emergency Medical Services Board
   
9-906   Organization of Board
   
9-907   Duties of the Board
   
9-908   Emergency medical services license
   
9-909   Contracts with other persons, firms and corporations
   
9-910   Rates for ambulance service
§9-901 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. The word
“shall” is always mandatory and not merely directory.
   AMBULANCE. Any motor vehicle equipped with facilities therein to convey
infirm or injured persons.
   ATTENDANT. Any person who has the duty of caring for a sick, ill or injured
person in an ambulance, and who is registered with the city.
   BOARD. The Emergency Medical Services Board as herein established.
   CERTIFICATE. A certificate of public convenience and necessity issued by the
City Council, licensing an operator, as hereinafter defined.
   CLERK. The City Treasurer of the city or his or her designated
representative.
   CONTRACT FOR SERVICE. The contract by and between a designated sole service
provider and the city for ambulance service.
   COUNCIL. The City Council.
   DRIVER. Every individual who drives an ambulance, as herein defined and who
has a commercial chauffeur’s license issued by the State Department of Public
Safety, and who is registered with the city.
   HEALTH OFFICER. The Director of the City-County Health Department or his or
her designated representative.
   OPERATOR. Any person, firm or corporation engaged in business as the owner
or proprietor of ambulances.
   PERMIT. The operating permit which an operator is required to obtain
annually for each and every motor vehicle operated as an ambulance.
   PERSON. Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation or other
group or combination acting as a unit.
   PUBLIC ENTITY. For the purpose of this chapter, a public entity is the
state, a political subdivision of the state, public trust created pursuant to
60 O.S. §§ 171 et seq., with the city as its beneficiary.
   REGISTRATION. The registration of drivers and attendants by the city.
   SOLE SERVICE PROVIDER. The designated ambulance service transport provider
under contract with the city to provide ambulance service to the corporate
limits of the city.
(Ord. 1412, passed 11-12-1996)
§9-902 CONTRACT FOR SOLE PROVIDER AMBULANCE SERVICE.
   (A)   Pursuant to provision of 63 O.S., the city, after a majority vote of
the City Council may enter into contracts for sole provider ambulance service.
   (B)   Contracts will be executed with a sole provider service under the
following conditions:
      (1)   After competitive bid with proper notice given in accordance with
63 O.S. § 1-2515; or
      (2)   Without necessity of competitive bids when the contracting sole
provider is a public entity, as defined herein.
(Ord. 1412, passed 11-12-1996)
§9-903 INVESTIGATION OF SOLE PROVIDER.
   Prior to entering into a contract for sole provider ambulance service, or
prior to renewal of an existing contract, the City Council may direct the City
Clerk to cause an investigation to be made of the prospective or current
applicant to ensure that:
   (A)   In the case of a current or prospective provider that services have
been satisfactory, rules and regulations of the State Department of Health have
been complied with, that equipment is satisfactorily maintained, that any
organization providing service to the sole provider service is licensed,
insured and in compliance with state law; and
   (B)   Clerk shall provide all acquired information to the EMS Board for
evaluation.
(Ord. 1412, passed 11-12-1996)
§9-904 MINIMUM STANDARDS.
   (A)   The sole service provider will be required to comply with the minimum
standards for ambulance service adopted by resolution of the City Council.
   (B)   The City Council will adopt minimum standards for ambulance service by
utilizing the recommendations of an Emergency Medical Services Board which
existed under prior code section and is reestablished in § 9-905.
(Ord. 1412, passed 11-12-1996)
§9-905 EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES BOARD.
   (A)   There is hereby reestablished an Emergency Medical Services Board to
act in an advisory capacity to the City Council in the development, formulation
and alteration of rules, regulations and standards for the operations of
ambulances, certification of operators, issuance of permits and registrations
as defined herein. The Board shall be responsible for a continuing study and
recommendation concerning the emergency medical services of the city.
   (B)   (1)   The Board shall consist of seven members composed as follows:
         (a)   A member who is a licensed physician and who is also a member of
the County Medical Society;
         (b)   A member who is a representative of the city, the individual
appointed by the City Manager;
         (c)   A member who is a representative from the State Nurses
Association;
         (d)   A member who is a representative of one of the local law
enforcement agencies;
         (e)   Three members from the community at large; and
         (f)   The health officer shall serve as ex officio member and shall
act as secretary to the Board.
      (2)   All Board members shall serve without compensation.
   (C)   All members of the EMS Board, appointed under prior ordinance and
serving at the time of the enactment hereof shall complete their current terms
except the representative of the local hospital who shall be replaced by the
city representative who shall complete the term of the hospital representative.
   (D)   The members shall be nominated by the Mayor and appointed by a vote of
the City Council for a term of three years, except that initially two of the
members shall be appointed for three-year terms, three of the members shall be
appointed for two-year terms, and two of the members shall be appointed for a
one-year term. All members, however, shall hold office until their successors
are appointed. The initial members of the Board shall be appointed within two
weeks of the date of the enactment of this chapter.
(Ord. 1412, passed 11-12-1996)
§9-906 ORGANIZATION OF BOARD.
   The Board shall select annually a Chairperson from among its members. The
Board shall hold at least four regular meetings each year and such additional
meetings as the Chairperson deems necessary. Special meetings may be called by
the Chairperson, or upon written request of any four members. Four members of
the Board shall constitute a quorum. The secretary to the Board shall maintain
minutes of each Board meeting and provide a copy of same to the Council.
(Ord. 1412, passed 11-12-1996)
§9-907 DUTIES OF THE BOARD.
   Within 30 days from the time of its appointment, the Board shall submit to
the Council its initial rules, regulations and standards for operation of
ambulances, certification of operators, issuance of permits and registrations
as defined herein. The rules, regulations and permits and standards formulated
by the Board and approved by the Council shall become effective when adopted by
the Council by resolution. At no time shall the standards for ambulance service
operation, as adopted hereunder, be less than the current minimal standards
adopted by the committee on trauma of the American College of Surgeons,
National Highway Safety Bureau and the State Department of Health.
(Ord. 1412, passed 11-12-1996)
§9-908 EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES LICENSE.
   (A)   All license requirements provided for by the State Department of
Health emergency medical service division relating to personnel and equipment
will be complied with at all times by sole provider.
   (B)   City may make inquiry regarding EMS licenses at any time. Sole
provider must make information available to City Clerk within two business days
of inquiry.
(Ord. 1412, passed 11-12-1996)
§9-909 CONTRACTS WITH OTHER PERSONS, FIRMS AND CORPORATIONS.
   (A)   Sole service providers under contract with city or other public entity
may continue existing contracts with the public entity, or may contract with
other persons, firms or corporations through the city or public entity.
   (B)   Prior to execution of contracts with other entities, sole service
providers will notify the City Clerk in writing of their intent to do so.
   (C)   The city or public entity (City Hospital Authority) will, at their
discretion, approve contracts. Where approved by public entity other than the
city, a copy of the contract will be provided to City Council.
(Ord. 1630, passed 5-23-2006)
§9-910 RATES FOR AMBULANCE SERVICE.
   (A)   Prior to increase in rates charged by sole provider, EMS Board will
examine proposed rate changes to ensure compliance with state laws regulating
rates.
   (B)   EMS Board will provide City Council with a recommendation regarding
rate changes. The recommendations will address the necessity of change,
compliance with existing state law or regulation and a time frame for the
implementation.
   (C)   City Council will vote to ratify or deny the rate changes.
(Ord. 1412, passed 11-12-1996)
CHAPTER 10: GARAGE SALES
Section
   
9-1001   Purpose
   
9-1002   Definitions
   
9-1003   Limitation of garage sales
   
9-1004   Penalty
§9-1001 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to preserve the health, safety and general
welfare by the regulation of garage sales in such a manner as to prohibit the
continual operation thereof within residential areas.
(Ord. 1241, passed 7-9-1985)
§9-1002 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ADVERTISED. The publication, broadcast or posting of notice which specifies
the time and place of the sale; the posting of notice of sale at the site of
such sale; or the conspicuous display of merchandise within view from a public
street.
   GARAGE SALE. The advertised display for sale of new or used merchandise or
materials upon a residentially used property, whether within or outside a
building.
(Ord. 1241, passed 7-9-1985)
§9-1003 LIMITATION OF GARAGE SALES.
   It is unlawful for any person, firm, association or corporation to conduct
or operate a garage sale on any residentially used property for more than ten
days within any calendar year.
(Ord. 1241, passed 7-9-1985)
§9-1004 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person, firm, association or corporation who shall violate the
provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon
conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in §
1-108. Each day upon which a person, firm, association or corporation(s)
violates the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense.
   (B)   Notwithstanding the provisions of division (A) above, any person,
firm, association or corporation who shall violate the provisions of this
chapter may also be found guilty of violation of the zoning ordinance of the
city and may be punished as therein provided.
(Ord. 1241, passed 7-9-1985)
CHAPTER 11: PENALTY
Section
   
9-1101   Penalty for violation
§9-1101 PENALTY FOR VIOLATION.
   Any person, who engages in any business, profession, trade or occupation, or
exercises any privilege, for which a license or permit is required by this
part, without a valid license or permit as hereby required, or who violates any
provision of this part, is guilty of an offense against the city and, upon
conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in §
1-108.
CHAPTER 12: DONATION BOXES
Section
   
9-1201   Definitions
   
9-1202   Permit required
   
9-1203   Regulations
   
9-1204   Penalty
§9-1201 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   APPLICANT. The owner/operator of a donation box.
   DONATION BOX. A box, bin or storage container used for the collection of
clothing, shoes, small household items and other miscellaneous articles of
personal property intended for resale or reuse.
(Ord. 1729, passed 11-11-2014)
§9-1202 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (A)   No one shall place or allow to be placed any donation box outside of a
building within the city limits without first obtaining a business license to
do so from the city’s licensing agent.
   (B)   Application for a business license shall be made through the city’s
licensing agent prior to the placement of any box. In addition to the
application, the applicant shall submit a site plan and written permission from
the property owner. The site plan should show the proposed location of the box
and its relationship to property lines, easements, parking areas and any
buildings located on the property. The written permission should include the
property owner’s name, legibly printed, dates the property is to be used and to
whom permission is being granted. The written permission shall also be signed
and dated by the property owner. Once the complete application is submitted and
approved, a business license shall be issued to the applicant in accordance
with the regulations found below.
   (C)   All boxes will be issued a city decal with an approved business
license. Decals shall be placed on the front upper right corner of each box
with the front being the side where the box has an opening for donations/
collections. Each decal shall state the expiration date of the license and have
a unique number that can be used for tracking purposes.
   (D)   Donation boxes shall not require a business license if one of the
following conditions exist:
      (1)   Box is located on private property owned or controlled by the
applicant and is associated with the applicant’s permanent business located
within a building on the same property as box; or
      (2)   Box is sponsored by or under contract with the city and located on
public property.
   (E)   Boxes not requiring a business license are still subject to the
regulations found below.
(Ord. 1729, passed 11-11-2014)
§9-1203 REGULATIONS.
   (A)   No box shall be located in an R-1 or R-2 Zoning District or within 200
feet of a one- or two-family residence.
   (B)   No box shall be located within one mile of an existing box.
   (C)   No one applicant shall have more than five boxes within the city at
any given time; provided, that boxes located on property owned or controlled by
the applicant and are associated with the applicant’s permanent business
located within a building on the same property as the box shall not be included
in the five-box limit.
   (D)   No box shall be located on property that does not currently have a
permanent business in operation on the same property.
   (E)   No portion of any box shall be located within the front or side
building setback, on property owned by or dedicated to the public, or located
within the sight triangle of any intersecting streets or driveways.
   (F)   All boxes and related vehicular and pedestrian access, parking and
maneuvering shall be located on hard surface pavement.
   (G)   No required off-street parking spaces may be utilized for such box,
and such shall not be located in any loading lane, driving aisle, queuing area
or handicap parking space including access lane.
   (H)   No box shall be larger than six feet wide by six feet long and stand
taller than six feet.
   (I)   All boxes shall be clearly marked with the name and phone number of
the applicant and shall state whether donation is “tax deductible” or “non-tax
deductible,” provided:
      (1)   Required markings shall be in a font that is easily readable with
letters being at least four inches tall;
      (2)   Required markings shall be located on the front of each box with
the front being the side where the box has an opening for donations.
   (J)   All items for donation shall at all times be fully maintained within
the box. No accumulation of items, trash or debris outside of box shall be
allowed.
   (K)   All boxes shall be constructed of all weather type material and
regularly maintained (e.g., repainted/repaired) by the applicant such that they
remain in a like new condition.
(Ord. 1729, passed 11-11-2014)
§9-1204 PENALTY.
   If items, trash or debris accumulates outside of the box or if the box
becomes deteriorated due to lack of proper maintenance, the box shall be
considered junk and debris, and the applicant will be subject to citations
pursuant to §
1-108 and/or suspension or revocation of the business license. No business
license for a donation box shall be issued or renewed to any applicant with any
pending suspended license for a donation box or to any applicant whose business
license for a donation box has been revoked within the previous three calendar
years.
(Ord. 1729, passed 11-11-2014)
PART 10: OFFENSES AND CRIMES
Chapter
   
1.    OFFENSES IN GENERAL
   
2.    OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY
   
3.    OFFENSES AGAINST THE PUBLIC
   
4.    OFFENSES AGAINST HEALTH, WELFARE AND MORALS
   
5.    OFFENSES AGAINST PERSONS
   
6.    OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC AUTHORITY
   
7.    PENALTIES
CHAPTER 1: OFFENSES IN GENERAL
Section
   
10-101   Attempts to commit an offense
   
10-102   Aiding in an offense
§10-101 ATTEMPTS TO COMMIT AN OFFENSE.
   Every person who attempts to commit an offense against the ordinances of the
city, and in such attempt does any act toward the commission of such offense,
but fails or is prevented or intercepted in the perpetration thereof, is guilty
of an offense and shall be punished in the manner prescribed for the attempted
offense itself.
§10-102 AIDING IN AN OFFENSE.
   When no punishment for counseling or aiding in the commission of a
particular offense is expressly prescribed by ordinance, every person who
counsels or aids another in the commission of such is guilty of an offense, or
misdemeanor, and punishable in the same manner as the principal offender.
CHAPTER 2: OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY
Section
   
10-201   Petit larceny prohibited
   
10-202   Injuring automobiles and other vehicles
   
10-203   Destroying or injuring buildings and other property
   
10-204   Placing signs on property of another
   
10-205   Throwing or shooting at persons or property
   
10-206   Tampering with, damaging and theft of utilities
   
10-207   Unlawful intrusion upon land
   
10-208   Illegal entrance and loitering
   
10-209   Unlawful deposits
   
10-210   Trespass prohibited
   
10-211   Parking on property of another person or business
   
10-212   Improper use of driveways and parking areas
   
10-213   Interference with fire hydrants
   
10-214   Graffiti prohibited
§10-201 PETIT LARCENY PROHIBITED.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, PETIT LARCENY means the taking of
personal property of value not exceeding $1,000 accomplished by fraud or
stealth and with intent to deprive another thereof, but it does not include the
taking of such property from the “person” of another.
   (B)   Petit larceny is unlawful, and any person who commits larceny shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor.
(Ord. 1768, passed 8-22-2017)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 21 O.S. §§ 1704 and 1706
§10-202 INJURING AUTOMOBILES AND OTHER VEHICLES.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to start, otherwise meddle with, molest,
enter or occupy any automobile or other vehicle belonging to another, without
the consent of the owner or person in charge thereof.
   (B)   It is unlawful for any person to mutilate, deface or injure any
automobile or other vehicle, or to remove therefrom any number, tag or mark
indicating ownership or identity thereof.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 21 O.S. § 1787
§10-203 DESTROYING OR INJURING BUILDINGS AND OTHER PROPERTY.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to purposely destroy, injure, deface,
besmear or molest any structure, building, outbuilding, fence or any other
property, real or personal, public or private, belonging to another or to use
any such property wrongfully to the detriment of the owner or other person
entitled to its use. It is unlawful to interfere wrongfully with the use of any
such property by its owner or any other person entitled to its use.
   (B)   It is unlawful for any person to loosen or remove any plank, board,
block, brick, stone, stringer, support or other part from, or to injure or
destroy, any sidewalk, crossing, bridge, culvert, viaduct, gate, sign or other
property of another, without lawful authority.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 21 O.S. §§ 1760 et seq.
§10-204 PLACING SIGNS ON PROPERTY OF ANOTHER.
   It is unlawful for any person to place, stick, tack, paste, post, paint,
mark, write or print any sign, poster, picture, announcement, advertisement,
bill placard, device or inscription upon any public or private building, fence,
sidewalk, bridge, viaduct, post, automobile, other vehicle or other property of
another, without the consent of the owner or person in charge thereof.
§10-205 THROWING OR SHOOTING AT PERSONS OR PROPERTY.
   It is unlawful for any person to throw or shoot any stone or other object
into or across any street or alley, or in any place where he or she is likely
to hit another person wrongfully or to injure property, or to throw or shoot
any stone or other object at any person, vehicle, structure, electric light or
other property of another (whether public or private), except in case where
such is done in defense of oneself, of another person or of property.
§10-206 TAMPERING WITH, DAMAGING AND THEFT OF UTILITIES.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   UTILITY. Any person, firm, corporation, district or association, whether
private, municipal, body politic or cooperative, which is engaged in the sale,
generation, distribution or delivery of electricity, water, sewer, cable
television or gas.
   UTILITY SERVICE. The furnishing, sale, generation, distribution or delivery
of electricity, water, sewer, cable television or gas by a utility, as defined
herein.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person, with intent to defraud a utility,
to:
      (1)   Alter, tamper with, injure or knowingly allow the altering,
tampering with or injuring of any pipeline, line, wire, conduit, conductor,
meter, meter seal, transformer or other equipment used by a utility to deliver
or register service;
      (2)   Prevent any installed metering device from registering correctly
the quantity of service passing through such metering device;
      (3)   Make or cause to be made any connection between any pipeline,
lines, wires, conduits, conductors, meters, transformers or other equipment in
such manner as to prevent the correct registration of service by any metering
device, or to otherwise use electricity without the consent of the utility;
      (4)   Supply or cause to be supplied any utility service to any person
without such service first passing through the metering device provided by the
utility for measuring and registering the quantity of service; or
      (5)   Continue to use utility service, of any kind, prior to paying a
reinstatement fee or arranging with the utility for reestablishment of
services:
         (a)   Once notice of utility cutoff or discontinuance has been
provided to the utility customer in the manner and form customarily used by the
utility to give notice of cutoff; and
         (b)   Utility provider has discontinued service at the customer
delivery point or meter. This action shall be deemed to be theft of a utility.
   (C)   Any person who is convicted of violating the provisions of division
(B) above shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by payment of a fine as
provided in §
1-108, or by imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed 30
days.
   (D)   If a civil action is brought by a utility against a person, the person
may post a bond, cash or other security with the utility in an amount equal to
the value of the service alleged to be unlawfully used or diverted. Upon
posting of the bond or cash, and until final disposition of the case, the
utility shall restore to the person any service which it may have terminated.
   (E)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to apply to licensed and
certified contractors while performing usual and ordinary service in accordance
with the recognized standards.
   (F)   This section shall not be construed as repealing any laws of the state
relating to the power, duties or jurisdiction of the State Corporation
Commission, but shall be held as auxiliary and supplementary thereto.
   (G)   (1)   The municipal utility provider, acting through the City Manager,
or his or her designated representative may waive prosecution relating to
division (B)(5) above for consumers, customers, continual use of municipally
provided utilities as defined herein.
      (2)   The municipal utility shall provide notice by regular mail and also
post said notice on the property being served with municipal utilities. The
notice shall contain a provision allowing the utility consumer seven days to
notify the municipal provider that the consumer waives prosecution and will pay
$60 total in the form of a penalty.
      (3)   If the consumer fails to notify the municipal provider of its
decision within the time specified herein the municipal utility shall cause
charges to be filed in the municipal court pursuant to provision contained
herein.
      (3)   The municipal utility may waive prosecution relating to this
division (G) only one time per consumer or consumer household and shall
prosecute all other violations in conformance with this section.
(Ord. 1454, passed 1-27-1998; Ord. 1524, passed 3-27-2001)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 21 O.S. § 1737
§10-207 UNLAWFUL INTRUSION UPON LAND.
   It is unlawful for any person to intrude or squat upon any lot or piece of
land within the city without a license or authority from the owner thereof, or
to erect or occupy thereon any hut, hovel, shanty or other structure without
such license or authority, or to place, erect or occupy within the bounds of
any street, alley or avenue of the city, any hut, shanty, hovel or other
structure without authority of law or ordinance.
§10-208 ILLEGAL ENTRANCE AND LOITERING.
   (A)   Illegal entrance generally. It is illegal for any person to enter upon
the property of another or into an area or structure on such property (whether
such property, area or structure is public or private), when such entrance is
plainly forbidden by signs or otherwise or when the property area or structure
is enclosed, except when such entrance is in line of duty, or with the
expressed or tacit consent of the owner or person in charge, or otherwise by
authority of law or ordinance.
   (B)   Trespassing prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person without
lawful reason to trespass upon or loiter on or about the premises of any public
or private school.
   (C)   Loitering prohibited.
      (1)   No person shall loiter on private property that is customarily used
by the public as an integral part of a commercial venture; nor is loitering
allowed in the following instances:
         (a)   In such a manner as to disturb the peace as defined by state law
or ordinance;
         (b)   In obstructing the free passage of pedestrians or vehicles; or
         (c)   Obstructing or interfering with any person lawfully seeking
access or the use of the commercial venture conducted on the property or
contiguous to said property.
      (2)   For the purpose of this division (C), LOITERING is defined as
remaining stationary in one location, including walking around aimlessly, and
sitting or standing in or out of a motor vehicle; to stand or wait around idly
or without apparent purpose, or to linger or hang around in a public place or
business where one has no particular or legal purpose.
      (3)   No person shall be guilty of a violation of this division (C)
unless the property owner or tenant has posted “NO LOITERING” signs or other
notice of like meaning at the entrance or entrances to said property.
(Ord. 1315, passed 9-10-1991; Ord. 1847, passed 9-12-2023)
§10-209 UNLAWFUL DEPOSITS.
   (A)   No person may deposit, or cause to be deposited, in any street or
alley, any filth, garbage, ashes, rubbish, sweepings, paper, trash, leaves or
any other waste materials, junk, auto parts, iceboxes, refrigerators, boxes,
appliances, nor may any of the foregoing materials, other than ashes, soil,
leaves, refuse from building materials, such as plaster, brick and the like, or
other suitable materials, be placed or dumped on any lot within the city. It is
unlawful to place upon the sidewalks, alleys or streets any sweepings or trash
from stores or other buildings, or any leaves, yard cleanings, debris from
pruning or other refuse materials, except that materials designated by the City
Manager may be used for filling in places designated by him or her.
   (B)   No person as owner or occupant of any premises in the city shall
permit such premises to have any of the items prohibited in division (A) above
thereon.
§10-210 TRESPASS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PRIVATE PROPERTY. Any property other than public property.
   PUBLIC PROPERTY. Property which is dedicated to public use and over which
the federal, state or municipal government or any subdivision thereof exercises
control.
   TRESPASS. Each and every actual entry upon the premises of an owner or other
person in lawful possession of the premises without the express or the implied
consent of the owner or other person in lawful possession.
      (1)   TRESPASS shall also mean remaining upon the premises of an owner or
other person in lawful possession after having been told to leave the premises
by the owner, or the agent, or employee of the owner, or other person in lawful
possession of the premises.
      (2)   TRESPASS shall also be defined as the act of remaining on private
property at any time other than during posted hours of business operation after
having been directed to vacate such premises by a police officer; provided,
that the provisions of this sentence shall not apply to persons, including
employees, whose presence upon such premises is authorized by the owner or by a
person in lawful possession of such premises; nor shall the provisions of this
sentence apply unless hours of business operations are posted upon such
premises.
      (3)   TRESPASS shall also be defined as the act of returning to private
property before the posted time of opening for business operation on the next
business day after having been directed to vacate such premises under the terms
of this division (A).
   (B)   It is unlawful for any person to trespass on private property.
§10-211 PARKING ON PROPERTY OF ANOTHER PERSON OR BUSINESS.
   It is unlawful for any person to park an automobile or other vehicle, or to
place any structure or object on the driveway, parking area, yard or any
portion of the premises or property of another person or business, including,
but not limited to, any restaurant, gasoline/filling station or other business,
when the business is not open to the public for business without the expressed
or tacit consent of the owner or person in charge thereof, or when necessary in
the performance of a duty, or otherwise by authority of law or ordinance.
Cross-reference:
   See also
Part 15, Chapter 7  of this code
§10-212 IMPROPER USE OF DRIVEWAYS AND PARKING AREAS.
   It is unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle onto the premises,
driveway or parking area of any place of business without purchasing or
attempting to purchase or obtain service or merchandise thereat. It shall be
considered a violation of this section to drive onto the premises without
stopping and requesting services or attempting to purchase merchandise;
provided nothing herein shall prohibit deliveries of material or merchandise to
the premises.
§10-213 INTERFERENCE WITH FIRE HYDRANTS.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person except one duly authorized by the City
Water Superintendent or a member of the Fire Department to open, turn on or
off, interfere with, attach any pipe or hose to, or connect anything with, any
fire hydrant belonging to the city.
   (B)   It is unlawful for any person to obstruct free access to any fire
hydrant in the city. The obstructions prohibited in this section include, but
are not limited to, those caused by placement of boxes, cartons or other
containers, or brick, lumber or dirt, near or around such hydrants, or the
growth of grass, weeds or plants near the fire hydrants.
Cross-reference:
   See also
Part 13, Chapter 2  of this code
§10-214 GRAFFITI PROHIBITED.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      ADVERTISING. Any letter, word, name, number, symbol, slogan, message,
drawing, picture, writing or other mark of any kind lawfully placed on property
by an owner or occupant of the property or an agent of such owner or occupant,
for the purpose of promoting products or services or conveying information to
the public.
      APPLIES GRAFFITI, APPLY GRAFFITI or APPLYING GRAFFITI. The act of
drawing, painting, chiseling, scratching or etching graffiti on public or
private property within the city.
      GRAFFITI. Without limitation, any letter, word, name, number, symbol,
slogan, message, drawing, picture, writing or other mark of any kind visible to
the public that is drawn, painted, chiseled, scratched or etched on a rock,
tree, wall, bridge, fence, gate, building or other structure; provided,
however, that this definition shall not include advertising or any other
letter, word, name, number, symbol, slogan, message, drawing, picture, writing
or other mark of any kind lawfully placed on property by an owner of the
property, an occupant of the property or by an authorized agent for such owner
or occupant.
      OCCUPANT. Any person shown by the records of the County Clerk’s office as
a tenant of property, or any person in actual physical possession of property.
      OWNER. Any person shown by the records of the County Clerk’s office as
the owner of a fee simple interest in property.
   (B)   The Council hereby declares that graffiti on public or private
property within the city constitutes a public nuisance to the detriment of the
city and its inhabitants and visitors. The provisions for prevention of such
public nuisance are set forth in this section.
   (C)   No person shall apply graffiti to public or private property within
the city.
   (D)   (1)   Any person who applies graffiti to public or private property
within the city shall be deemed guilty of an offense. Each act of applying
graffiti shall constitute a separate offense.
      (2)   Any person convicted of the offense of applying graffiti to public
or private property within the city shall be punished by a fine of not to
exceed $100 for the first offense, or $349 or imprisonment not to exceed 30
days, or both fine and imprisonment, for a second or subsequent offense.
   (E)   The provisions of this section shall be enforced by the Police
Department.
(Ord. 1390, passed 3-12-1996)
CHAPTER 3: OFFENSES AGAINST THE PUBLIC
Section
   
10-300   Second Amendment sanctuary city
   
10-301   Disturbing the peace
   
10-302   Public speaking or gatherings prohibited on streets or sidewalks,
permits
   
10-303   Insulting signs, literature or language
   
10-304   Fireworks restrictions; public displays; permits and bond
   
10-305   Storing or keeping explosives
   
10-306   Carrying weapons exceptions
   
10-307   Sale or furnishing of weapons to minors
   
10-308   Discharging weapons; throwing missiles
   
10-309   Reckless conduct
   
10-310   Loud noise or music, permit
   
10-311   Interference with radio and television reception prohibited
§10-300 SECOND AMENDMENT SANCTUARY CITY.
   (A)   Any federal, state or county act, law, executive order, court order,
rule, policy or regulation ordering the buy-back, confiscation or surrender of
firearms, firearm accessories or ammunition from law-abiding citizens of the
city is considered an infringement on the rights of the citizens of the city to
keep and bear arms as guaranteed by the Second Amendment of the Constitution of
the United States.
   (B)   All law enforcement officers, and any other department of the city,
which receives any such action described in division (A) above, shall, to the
fullest extent possible, take all measures to protect the Second Amendment
rights of the law-abiding citizens of the city.
(Ord. 1820, passed 5-11-2021)
§10-301 DISTURBING THE PEACE.
   (A)   It is unlawful to disturb or alarm the peace of another or others by
doing any of the acts set out in division (B) below.
   (B)   Disturbing the peace is the doing of any of the following in such a
manner as would foreseeably alarm or disturb the peace of another or others:
      (1)   Using obscene, offensive, abusive, profane, vulgar, threatening,
violent or insulting language or conduct;
      (2)   Appearing in an intoxicated condition;
      (3)   Engaging in a fistic encounter;
      (4)   Lewdly exposing one’s person, or private parts thereof, in any
public place or in any place where there are present other persons to be
offended or annoyed thereby;
      (5)   Pointing any pistol or any other deadly weapon whether loaded or
not at any other person or persons either in anger or otherwise;
      (6)   Holding an unlawful assembly of three or more persons, including
being assembled together and acting in concert, to do any unlawful act against
the peace or to the terror of others or preparing for or moving toward such
acts, or otherwise assembling unlawfully or riotously;
      (7)   Interrupting any lawful assembly of people by making noise, by
rude, indecent or improper behavior, by profane, improper or loud language, or
in any other manner, either within the place of assembly or within hearing
distance thereof;
      (8)   Making unnecessarily loud, offensive noises;
      (9)   Disturbing any congregation or assembly of persons meeting for
religious worship by making noise, by rude, indecent or improper behavior, by
profane, improper or loud language, or in any other manner, either within the
place of worship or within hearing distance thereof; or
      (10)   Committing any other act in such a manner as to unreasonably
disturb or alarm the public.
§10-302 PUBLIC SPEAKING OR GATHERINGS PROHIBITED ON STREETS OR SIDEWALKS,
PERMITS.
   It is unlawful for any person to hold or attempt to hold, or to conduct or
attempt to conduct, or to aid or abet in holding or conducting, any public
speaking, meeting or gathering of any kind whatsoever upon any street within
the city or upon the parking or sidewalks adjacent thereto, except pursuant to
a permit issued by the city.
§10-303 INSULTING SIGNS, LITERATURE OR LANGUAGE.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation within the city to
display any sign, emblem, badge, flag or device, which in its common acceptance
is insulting, profane or abusive to the citizens of the city, and which is
calculated, or of which the natural consequence is, to cause a breach of the
peace or an assault.
   (B)   It is unlawful for any person to willfully use, utter, publish,
circulate or distribute any profane, violent, abusive or insulting language or
literature where:
      (1)   A natural consequence of the language or literature is to cause a
breach of the peace or an assault; or
      (2)   The language or literature, in its common acceptance, is calculated
to cause a breach of the peace or an assault.
§10-304 FIREWORKS RESTRICTIONS; PUBLIC DISPLAYS; PERMITS AND BOND.
   (A)   It is unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to
store, to offer for sale, expose for sale, sell at retail or wholesale, possess
or use, explode or discharge any pop bottle rocket, roman candle or any other
type of fireworks within the city limits except as hereinafter provided.
   (B)   The Fire Chief may adopt reasonable rules and regulations for the
granting of permits for supervised public displays of fireworks by
associations, amusement parks and other organizations or group of individuals.
Such permits may be granted upon application to the Fire Chief and the filing
of a bond by the applicant as provided herein. Every such display shall be
handled by a competent and experienced operator approved by the Fire Chief and
shall be of such composition, character and so located, discharged or fired as
in the opinion of the Fire Chief, after proper inspection, shall not be
hazardous to property or endanger any person or persons.
   (C)   Application for permits shall be made in writing at least 30 days in
advance of the date of the display. After such privilege has been granted,
sale, possession, use and distribution of fireworks for such display shall be
lawful for that purpose only. No permit granted hereunder shall be
transferable.
   (D)   The sale, possession, use and distribution of fireworks for display
purposes shall be conducted so as to be reasonably safe to persons and
property. Evidence that the sale, possession, use and distribution of fireworks
for display purposes has been conducted in accordance with the applicable
standard specified for this section shall be evidence that such sale,
possession, use and distribution of fireworks for display purposes provided
reasonable safety to persons and property.
   (E)   The Fire Chief shall require a bond from the permittee in a sum not
less than $1,000 conditioned on compliance with the provisions of this code.
   (F)   Before any permit for a pyrotechnic display shall be issued, the
person, firm or corporation making application therefor shall furnish proof of
financial responsibility to satisfy claims for damages to property or personal
injuries arising out of any fact or omission on the part of such person, firm
or corporation or any agent or employee thereof, in such amount, character and
form as the Fire Chief determines to be necessary for the protection of the
public.
   (G)   Any fireworks that remain unfired after the display is concluded shall
be immediately disposed of in a way safe for the particular type of fireworks
remaining.
   (H)   The Fire Chief shall seize, take, remove or cause to be removed at the
expense of the owner all stocks of fireworks offered or exposed for sale,
stored or held in violation of this section.
   (I)   For the purpose of this section, FIREWORKS shall be as defined in
state law, 68 O.S. § 1622.
§10-305 STORING OR KEEPING EXPLOSIVES.
   It is unlawful for any person to store or keep within the city any
nitroglycerin, dynamite, gunpowder or any other highly explosive material or
substance, except that gunpowder or black powder may be kept in quantities of
not to exceed five pounds where the same is securely kept.
§10-306 CARRYING WEAPONS EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person, except those persons authorized by law,
to carry concealed upon or about his or her person any pistol, revolver or
firearm or any weapon of the kind usually known as air pistol or air gun, or
weapon of the kind usually known as slingshot, Bowie knife, dirk knife,
switchblade knife, spring type knife, knife having a blade which opens
automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring or other device in
the handle of the knife, loaded cane, billy, metal knuckles or any other
offensive or defensive weapon, except as may be otherwise authorized by state
law.
   (B)   Notwithstanding the provisions of division (A) above, persons shall be
permitted to carry within the city shotguns, rifles or air guns which are not
concealed, if unloaded, if within a reasonable time they are carried from the
city, or being carried for the purpose of having them repaired, or for the
purpose of using the same in a public muster or military drills, or for any
other purpose as may be authorized by state law or city ordinance.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. § 22-110 and 21 O.S. §§ 1272 and 1289.1 et
seq.
§10-307 SALE OR FURNISHING OF WEAPONS TO MINORS.
   It is unlawful for any person within the city to sell or give to any minor
any of the arms or weapons designated in §
10-306, in accordance with applicable state law.
§10-308 DISCHARGING WEAPONS; THROWING MISSILES.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to discharge any species of firearms,
air pistol, air gun, slingshot or discharge a hand grenade, bomb or similar
device, or other weapon, or throw any missile within the city, except when
necessary for the protection of life or property or as authorized by the city
or state law.
   (B)   The prohibition of division (A) above shall not apply to a licensed
shooting gallery, or in common grounds or premises under circumstances which
such instrument can be fired, discharged or operated in such a manner as to not
endanger persons or property, and also in such a manner as to prevent the
projectile from traversing any ground or space outside the limits of such
gallery, grounds or residence. Nothing herein contained shall be in derogation
of the laws of the state as they now exist or as they may be hereinafter
amended.
(Ord. 1248, passed 10-22-1985)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. § 22-110 and 21 O.S. § 1364
§10-309 RECKLESS CONDUCT.
   It is unlawful for any person to engage in reckless conduct while having in
his or her possession any shotgun, rifle or pistol, such actions consisting of
creating a situation of unreasonable risk and probability of death or great
bodily harm to another and demonstrating a conscious disregard for the safety
of another person.
§10-310 LOUD NOISE OR MUSIC, PERMIT.
   It is unlawful and an offense against the city for any person, firm or
corporation, either as principal, agent or employee, to play, use or operate
for advertising purposes, or for any other purpose whatsoever, except fixed
installations in churches, consisting of church chimes, on, above or upon the
public streets, alleys or thoroughfares in the city, any device known as a
sound truck, loudspeaker or sound amplifier, radio or phonograph with a
loudspeaker or sound amplifier or any instrument known as a calliope or any
other instrument of any kind or character which emits therefrom any
unreasonable loud and raucous noises and is attached to, in, above and upon any
buildings, or vehicle operated or standing upon the streets or public places
without first having procured from the Chief of Police of the city a written
permit. The Chief of Police in granting his or her written permit to any
person, firm or corporation, shall be controlled and take into consideration
the period of time, place, use and purpose, volume of sound, the comfort,
safety, convenience, quietude and tranquility of the residents of the city.
§10-311 INTERFERENCE WITH RADIO AND TELEVISION RECEPTION PROHIBITED.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation knowingly or
wantonly to operate or cause to be operated any machine, device, apparatus or
instrument of any kind whatsoever within the corporate limits of the city, the
operation of which shall cause reasonably preventable electrical interference
with radio or television reception within the limits of the city. X-ray
pictures, examination or treatments may be made at any time if the machine or
apparatus used therefor is properly equipped to avoid all unnecessary or
reasonably preventable interference with radio and television receptions and is
not negligently operated.
   (B)   This section shall not be held or construed to embrace or cover the
regulation of any transmitting, broadcasting or receiving instrument, apparatus
or device which is licensed or authorized by or under the provisions of any act
of the Congress of the United States.
CHAPTER 4: OFFENSES AGAINST THE HEALTH, WELFARE AND MORALS

10-401   Public intoxication and drinking prohibited
