      (41)   Pharmacy;
      (42)   Photographer studio;
      (43)   Radio and television sales and service;
      (44)   Restaurant or cafeteria;
      (45)   Self-service laundry or dry-cleaning;
      (46)   Sewing machine sales, instruction and service;
      (47)   Shoe repair shop;
      (48)   Sporting goods store;
      (49)   Tailor shop;
      (50)   Toy store; and
      (51)   Variety store.
   (D)   Advertising signs and structures:
      (1)   One business sign, not exceeding 32 square feet in display area may
be erected on each street frontage of the lot. If this sign is pole mounted, it
shall not exceed the height of the building in which the principal use is
located, or 20 feet, whichever is lower;
      (2)   One wall sign may be erected on the primary structure not exceeding
an aggregate display surface area equal to two square feet per linear foot of
street frontage; total sign size is limited to 65% of the total wall area of
the wall to which the sign is attached;
      (3)   No signs advertising products not sold on the premises will be
permitted; and
      (4)   No signs shall be permitted upon lots not containing one business
establishment.
   (E)   Accessory buildings and uses customarily incidental to the above uses;
and
   (F)   A building used for any of the above enumerated uses may not have more
than 40% of its floor area devoted to purposes incidental to the primary use.
No material or goods offered for sale or stored in connection with the uses
enumerated in divisions (A) through (E) above shall be displayed or stored
outside of a building.
(Ord. 1452, passed 1-13-1998)
§12-242 USES PERMITTED ON REVIEW.
   The following uses may be permitted on review in accordance with the
provisions contained in this part:
   (A)   Automated and/or self-service car wash; and
   (B)   Self-service gasoline pumps.
(Ord. 1516, passed 12-12-2000)
§12-243 AREA REGULATIONS.
   The area requirements for dwellings shall be the same as the requirements of
the R-3 General Residential District. The following requirements shall apply to
all other uses permitted in this district.
   (A)   Front yard. All buildings shall set back from the street right-of-way
line to provide a front yard having not less than 25 feet in depth.
   (B)   Side yard. On the side of a lot adjoining a dwelling district there
shall be a side yard of not less than ten feet. There shall be a side yard
setback from an intersecting street of not less than 20 feet.
   (C)   Rear yard. There shall be provided an alley, service court, rear yard
or combination thereof of not less than 20 feet with 30 feet recommended.
§12-244 HEIGHT REGULATIONS.
   No building shall exceed two and one-half stories or 35 feet in height,
except as hereinafter provided in §
12-362.
§12-245 C-2 OFFICE COMMERCIAL DISTRICT.
   This commercial district is intended to provide a place for those types of
institutional and commercial activities that require separate buildings and
building groups surrounded by landscaped yards and open area. Land, space and
aesthetic requirements of these uses make desirable a location near residential
neighborhoods or rural countryside, and away from the concentration of people
and traffic of the retail, wholesale and industrial areas of the community.
§12-246 USES PERMITTED.
   Property and buildings in a C-2 Office Commercial District shall be used
only for the following purposes:
   (A)   Any use permitted in an R-3 General Residential District;
   (B)   Any of the following uses:
      (1)   Adult daycare center, as provided in §
12-232;
      (2)   Apartment hotel;
      (3)   Art gallery;
      (4)   Assembly halls;
      (5)   Banking and financing institutions;
      (6)   Barbershop;
      (7)   Beauty shop;
      (8)   Business colleges;
      (9)   Daycare centers and homes as provided in §
12-222;
      (10)   Drugstores and fountains;
      (11)   Hotel;
      (12)   Laboratories for research and testing;
      (13)   Libraries;
      (14)   Medical facility;
      (15)   Museums;
      (16)   Music conservatories;
      (17)   Office buildings and office business in which no activity is
carried on catering to retail trade and the general public, and no stock of
goods is maintained for sale to customers. These include, but shall not
necessarily be limited to, doctors, dentists, lawyers, architects and
engineers; provided, however, that this shall in no way be construed as
permitting undertaking establishments and funeral homes;
      (18)   Parking lot;
      (19)   Post office;
      (20)   Public and private schools and colleges with students in residence
and dormitories associated therewith;
      (21)   Restaurant designed to serve the people conducting business
activities in this district;
      (22)   Studios for professional work and including the teaching of any
form of fine arts, such as music, drama, dance, photography, but not including
a commercial gymnasium; and
      (23)   Trade schools and schools for vocational training.
   (C)   Recreational uses associated with and maintained primarily for the
benefit and use of the occupants and families of the uses listed under division
(B) above;
   (D)   Shops and stores associated with and maintained primarily for the
benefit and use of the occupants and families of the uses listed under division
(B) above;
   (E)   Buildings and structures and uses customarily incidental and accessory
to the above uses; and
   (F)   Advertising signs and structures:
      (1)   (a)   One business sign, not exceeding 32 square feet in display
area may be erected on each street frontage of the lot.
         (b)   If this sign is pole mounted, it shall not exceed the height of
the building in which the principal use is located, or 20 feet, whichever is
lower;
      (2)   One wall sign may be erected on the primary structure not exceeding
an aggregate display surface area equal to two square feet per linear foot of
street frontage; total sign size limited to 65% of the total wall area of the
wall to which the sign is attached;
      (3)   No signs advertising products not sold on the premises will be
permitted; and
      (4)   No signs shall be permitted upon lots not containing one business
establishment.
(Ord. 1452, passed 1-13-1998; Ord. 1508, passed 6-27-2000; Ord. 1531, passed 8-
14-2001)
§12-247 AREA REGULATIONS.
   (A)   The area requirements for dwellings and buildings accessory thereto
shall be the same as the area requirement for the R-3 General Residential
District.
   (B)   The following requirements shall apply to all other uses permitted in
this district.
      (1)   Front yard. All buildings shall set back from the street right-of-
way line to provide a front yard having not less than 25 feet in depth.
      (2)   Side yard. Where a side yard is adjacent to a dwelling district no
building shall be located closer than 30 feet to the side lot line. In all
other cases no building shall be located closer than 20 feet to the side lot
line.
      (3)   Rear yard. No building shall be located closer than 20 feet to the
rear lot line.
      (4)   Coverage. The total gross floor area of the main building shall not
exceed three times the area of the lot.
§12-248 HEIGHT REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Height regulations for dwellings shall be the same as those of the R-
3 General Residential District.
   (B)   No building or structure shall exceed eight stories or 90 feet in
height, except as hereinafter provided in §
12-341.
§12-250 C-3 PLANNED SHOPPING CENTER DISTRICT.
   This commercial district is intended for a unified grouping, in one or more
buildings, of retail shops and stores that provide for the regular needs and
are for the convenience of the people residing in the adjacent residential
neighborhoods. It is intended that the planned shopping center be developed as
a unit, with adequate off-street parking space for customers and employees, and
with appropriate landscaping and screening materials.
§12-251 USES PERMITTED.
   Property and buildings in a C-3 Planned Shopping Center District shall be
used only for the uses enumerated below; provided, however, that these uses
shall be located in a unified shopping center which shall have not less than
five shops and stores, at least one of which shall be a supermarket or variety
store, or junior department store of not less than 10,000 square feet of gross
floor area. The shops and stores of the shopping center shall have a combined
total gross floor area of not less than 20,000 square feet and shall be located
on a tract of land of not less than two and one-half acres in area:
   (A)   Any of the following uses shall be permitted:
      (1)   Antique shop;
      (2)   Apparel store, family, children, men or women;
      (3)   Appliance shop;
      (4)   Artist’s supplies;
      (5)   Automobile parking lot;
      (6)   Bakery goods store;
      (7)   Bank;
      (8)   Barbershop;
      (9)   Beauty shop;
      (10)   Book or stationery store;
      (11)   Camera store;
      (12)   Catering establishment;
      (13)   Cleaning and pressing collection station;
      (14)   Curio shop;
      (15)   Dairy products or ice cream store;
      (16)   Delicatessen;
      (17)   Drugstore or fountain;
      (18)   Dry goods store;
      (19)   Florist shop;
      (20)   Furniture store;
      (21)   Garden supply store;
      (22)   Gift shop;
      (23)   Grocery store;
      (24)   Hardware store;
      (25)   Jewelry store;
      (26)   Junior department store;
      (27)   Key shop;
      (28)   Leather goods shop;
      (29)   Liquor store;
      (30)   Meat market;
      (31)   Medical facility;
      (32)   Messenger and telegraph office;
      (33)   Music store;
      (34)   Newspaper or magazine sales;
      (35)   Notions store;
      (36)   Office supply store;
      (37)   Optometrists’ sales and service;
      (38)   Paint and decorating shop;
      (39)   Pharmacy;
      (40)   Photographer studio;
      (41)   Radio and television sales and service;
      (42)   Restaurant;
      (43)   Self-service laundry and dry-cleaning;
      (44)   Sewing machine sales, service and instruction;
      (45)   Shoe store or repair shop;
      (46)   Sporting goods sales;
      (47)   Supermarket;
      (48)   Tailor shop;
      (49)   Theater;
      (50)   Toy store; and
      (51)   Variety store.
   (B)   Office uses; provided, however, that the total gross floor area of all
office uses, exclusive of those listed in division (A) above, shall not exceed
20% of the gross floor area of the shopping center;
   (C)   Gasoline service or filling station; provided that it is designed as
an integral part of the shopping center building group;
   (D)   Advertising signs relating to the shopping center, the stores and
shops therein and products sold therein. All advertising signs and structures
shall be designed as an integral part of the shopping center development and
shall be harmonious with the other design features of the center; and
   (E)   Accessory buildings and uses customarily incidental to the above uses.
§12-252 AREA REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Minimum area. The parcel of land on which a planned shopping center is
located shall not be less than two and one-half acres in area.
   (B)   Yards. It is intended that the grouping of buildings and parking areas
to be designed to protect, insofar as possible, adjacent residential areas and
that ornamental screening from noise and light be provided where necessary;
provided, however, that in no case shall the design of the shopping center
provide less than the following standards:
      (1)   All buildings shall set back from all street right-of-way lines not
less than 25 feet;
      (2)   On the side of a lot adjoining a dwelling district, there shall be
a side yard of not less than 25 feet; and
      (3)   There shall be a rear yard, alley, service court or combination
thereof, of not less than 20 feet in width and 30 feet recommended, and all of
the service area of all buildings shall be screened from public view with
ornamental screening materials.
   (C)   Coverage. Buildings shall not cover more than 40% of the site on which
the shopping center is located.
§12-253 HEIGHT REGULATIONS.
   No building shall exceed two and one-half stories, or 35 feet in height,
except as hereinafter provided in §
12-362.
§12-254 OFF-STREET PARKING.
   The off-street parking requirements set forth in §
12-368, may be complied with providing a permanent, common off-street parking
facility for all of the uses within the shopping center, provided that the lot
contains the requisite number of spaces for each use. The total number of
spaces provided shall not be less than the sum of the individual requirements;
provided, however, that in no case shall the amount of off-street parking area,
including driveways required for ingress and egress and circulation, be less
than three and one-half times the gross floor area used for retail trades in
the shopping center.
§12-255 ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES FOR PLANNED SHOPPING CENTER DEVELOPMENT.
   (A)   An application for rezoning for a planned shopping center shall
include the following, in addition to the administrative requirements set forth
in §
12-391:
      (1)   The developer shall submit site plans of the proposed development
which shall be adequate in detail to determine compliance with the provisions
of this section; and which shall show the arrangement of buildings, types of
shops and stores, design and circulation pattern of the off-street parking
area, and utility and drainage easements and facilities; and the relationship
of the shopping center development to adjacent areas which it may affect; and
      (2)   Evidence that indicates, to the satisfaction of the City Council
and Planning Commission, the ability and intent of the developer to carry out
the development of the shopping center in accordance with the plans submitted
in accordance with division (A)(1) above.
   (B)   Development procedures are as follows.
      (1)   The developer shall obtain a building permit for the shopping
center in accordance with the requirements and procedure of §
12-387 and shall begin construction of the shopping center within two years
after the effective date of rezoning for the shopping center and shall make a
reasonable and continuous progress toward completion. If the shopping center is
not under construction within two years after the effective date of the
shopping center rezoning, the Planning Commission shall review the status of
the development, and if it shall find that the developer cannot proceed
immediately with the development, in conformity with the requirements of this
section, this fact and the reasons thereof shall be reported to the City
Council. The City Council may, at its discretion, rezone the shopping center
district to a zoning district classification consistent with the general plan.
      (2)   Any substantial deviation from the plans submitted at the time of
rezoning shall constitute a violation of the building permit authorizing
construction of the shopping center. Substantial changes in plans shall be
resubmitted to the City Council and the Planning Commission to ensure
compliance with the requirements and purpose and intent of this section, and no
building permit shall be issued for any construction which is not in
substantial conformity with the approved plan.
§12-256 C-4 GENERAL COMMERCIAL DISTRICT.
   The C-4 General Commercial District is intended for the conduct of personal
and business services and the general retail business of the community. Persons
living in the community and in the surrounding trade territory require direct
and frequent access. Traffic generated by the uses will be primarily passenger
vehicles and those trucks and commercial vehicles required for stocking and
delivery of retail goods.
§12-257 USES PERMITTED.
   Property and buildings in a C-4 General Commercial District shall be used
only for the following purposes:
   (A)   Any use permitted in C-1, C-2 or C-3 District;
   (B)   Amusement enterprises;
   (C)   New automobile sales and services; new machinery sales and service;
public garages, provided no gasoline is stored aboveground; and used automobile
and machinery sales and service, and automobile and machinery repairing if
conducted wholly within a completely enclosed building, but not including
automobile or machinery wrecking establishments or junkyards;
   (D)   Any of the following businesses:
      (1)   Advertising signs or structures:
         (a)   One wall or canopy sign may be erected, not exceeding an
aggregate surface display area of three square feet per each linear foot of
building wall to which the sign is affixed; total sign size is limited to 65%
of the total wall area of the wall to which the sign is attached;
         (b)   In addition to the wall or canopy signs permitted above, a lot
containing one business establishment may erect pole or ground signs of two
square feet of display area per linear foot of street frontage; provided,
however, that if more than one such pole or ground sign is erected, an
aggregate display area not exceeding one square foot per linear foot of street
frontage shall be allowed;
         (c)   Ground or pole signs shall not exceed 35 feet in height; and
         (d)   No signs advertising products not sold on the premises will be
permitted.
      (2)   Ambulance service, office or garage;
      (3)   Auto court or tourist court;
      (4)   Automobile car wash;
      (5)   Automobile service station;
      (6)   Bait sales;
      (7)   Bakery;
      (8)   Bathhouse;
      (9)   Boat sales;
      (10)   Bus terminal;
      (11)   Cleaning plant;
      (12)   Clothing or apparel store;
      (13)   Commercial school or hall;
      (14)   Department store;
      (15)   Drive-in theater or restaurant;
      (16)   Electric transmission station;
      (17)   Feed and fuel store;
      (18)   Frozen food locker;
      (19)   Funeral parlor or mortuary;
      (20)   Furniture repair and upholstery;
      (21)   Golf course, miniature or practice range;
      (22)   Heating, ventilating or plumbing supplies, sales and service;
      (23)   Hotel;
      (24)   Ice storage locker plant or storage house for food;
      (25)   Laundry;
      (26)   Liquefied petroleum gas;
      (27)   Motel retail sales meeting city and state regulations;
      (28)   Museums;
      (29)   Novelty shop;
      (30)   Nursery or garden supply store;
      (31)   Office business;
      (32)   Outdoor advertising signs;
      (33)   Pawnshop;
      (34)   Pet shop;
      (35)   Printing plant;
      (36)   Recreation center;
      (37)   Research laboratories;
      (38)   Sign painting;
      (39)   Skating rink;
      (40)   Theater;
      (41)   Travel trailer park;
      (42)   Used automobile sales; and
      (43)   Wholesale distributing center.
   (E)   Buildings, structures and uses accessory and customarily incidental to
any of the above uses, provided that there shall be no manufacture, processing
or compounding of products other than such as are customarily incidental and
essential to retail establishments;
   (F)   Any other store or shop for retail trade or for rendering personal,
professional or business service which does not produce more noise, odor, dust,
vibration, blast or traffic than those enumerated above; and
   (G)   No article or material stored in connection with uses permitted under
this section shall be stored or displayed outside of a building unless it is so
screened by permanent ornamental walls, fences or planting that it cannot be
seen from adjoining streets or lots when viewed by a person standing on ground
level; provided, however, that no screening in excess of seven feet in height
shall be required.
(Ord. 1438, passed 5-27-1997; Ord. 1452, passed 1-13-1998; Ord. 1487, passed 6-
22-1999)
§12-258 USES PERMITTED ON REVIEW.
   The following uses may be permitted on review in accordance with the
provisions contained in this part:
   (A)   Dance hall;
   (B)   Hospital for small animals;
   (C)   Kennel;
   (D)   Laboratories, testing and experimental;
   (E)   Nightclub;
   (F)   Propane dispensary;
   (G)   Storage warehouse, subject to the conditions specified in §
12-260;
   (H)   Tattoo parlor or body piercing establishment;
   (I)   Tavern; and
   (J)   Towers.
(Ord. 1756, passed 8-23-2016)
Cross-reference:
   See also § 12-390(B)
§12-259 OPEN DISPLAY USES PERMITTED.
   (A)   The following uses shall be permitted in the C-4 General Commercial
District, provided that they comply with the additional provisions of this
section:
      (1)   Boat sales and service;
      (2)   Farm implement machinery, new and used, sales;
      (3)   Metal and wood fencing, or ornamental grillwork and decorative
wrought iron work and play equipment sales;
      (4)   Mobile home and travel trailer sales;
      (5)   Monument sales;
      (6)   New and used automobile sales;
      (7)   Prefabricated house sales; and
      (8)   Trailers for hauling, rental and sales.
   (B)   The uses enumerated in division (A) above shall comply with the
following provisions:
      (1)   (a)   All open storage and display of merchandise, material and
equipment shall be so screened by ornamental fencing or evergreen planting that
it cannot be seen by a person standing on ground level adjacent to the side or
the rear of the lot on which the open storage or display occurs; provided,
however, that screening shall not be required in excess of seven feet in
height.
         (b)   All planting shall be kept neatly trimmed and maintained in good
condition at all times.
         (c)   Merchandise and materials which are not completely assembled or
which are not immediately and actively being offered for sale, in addition to
complying with the above screening requirements, shall be so screened by
ornamental fences or evergreen planting or by permanent buildings that it
cannot be seen from a public street;
      (2)   All yards, unoccupied with buildings or merchandise or used as
trafficways, shall be landscaped with grass or shrubs and maintained in good
condition the year round;
      (3)   All of the lot used for the parking of vehicles, for the storage
and display of merchandise and all driveways used for vehicle ingress and
egress shall be paved with a sealed surface pavement and maintained in such a
manner that no dust will be produced by continued use;
      (4)   All servicing of vehicles carried on as an incidental part of the
sales operation shall be conducted within a completely enclosed building;
      (5)   Driveways used for ingress and egress shall not exceed 25 feet in
width, exclusive of curb returns; and
      (6)   Outdoor lighting, when provided, shall have an arrangement of
reflectors and an intensity of lighting which will not interfere with adjacent
land uses or the use of adjacent streets.
§12-260 AREA REGULATIONS.
   (A)   The front, side and rear yard regulations for residential uses shall
be the same as the requirements of the R-3 General Residential District.
   (B)   Whenever property in this district abuts or is separated only by a
street or alley from property within a residential or agricultural district,
issuance of building permits thereon may be subject to approval of a
development plan by the Planning Commission as follows.
      (1)   The conditions of such approval may impose such front, side and
rear yard setbacks, screening, landscaping, driveway and parking area design
requirements as shall be deemed necessary to protect the character of the
adjacent properties; provided, that in no instance shall a setback of greater
than 25 feet from any property line be required.
      (2)   Conditions imposed by the Planning Commission shall be set forth in
the minutes of the Commission and shall have the same force and effect as if
set forth in these regulations.
   (C)   Except as provided above or in the major street plan, there are no
specific front or side yard requirements.
   (D)   There shall be provided an alley, service court, rear yard or
combination thereof, of not less than 20 feet with 30 feet recommended.
   (E)   Buildings shall be provided with a yard area adequate to meet the off-
street parking requirements set forth in §
12-364.
   (F)   (1)   The City Council finds that while storage warehouses conform to
the general intent of this district, they are not the highest and best use of
the prime commercial frontage property of the district. Further, the location
of such warehouses directly on certain street frontages detracts from the
appearance and character of the community.
      (2)   It is, therefore, the policy of the city that storage warehouses in
this district shall comply with the following conditions.
         (a)   Notwithstanding the zoning of the abutting property, the
property owner or developer shall submit a development plan subject to the
approval of, and the conditions established by, the Planning Commission in the
manner as provided in division (B) above.
         (a)   1.   Except as may be required for ingress and egress, or as
provided in division (F)(3) below, storage warehouses shall not be located on
any lot, parcel or tract of land which has any portion of its boundaries
situated within 300 feet of the right-of-way of a designated arterial in the
major street plan with an aggregate traffic count exceeding 10,000 vehicles per
day.
            2.   For purposes of verifying a traffic count, the Community
Development Director may take notice of data available to his or her office or
may require the owner/developer to obtain a traffic count at his or her
expense.
         (b)   Where storage warehouses are proposed as part of a planned unit
development pursuant to §§
12-340 through
12-342, such warehouses may be located on a lot, parcel or tract which is
closer to the designated arterial than specified in division (F)(2) above;
provided, that in all cases, said warehouses and accessory buildings shall be
set back from the right-of-way a minimum of 325 feet.
(Ord. 1486, passed 6-22-1999; Ord. 1511, passed 8-22-2000)
§12-261 HEIGHT REGULATIONS.
   No building shall exceed two and one-half stories or 35 feet in height,
except as hereinafter provided in §
12-362.
ARTICLE E. INDUSTRIAL DISTRICTS (I)
§12-265 I-1 RESTRICTED MANUFACTURING AND WAREHOUSING DISTRICT.
   The I-1 Restricted Manufacturing and Warehousing District is intended for
manufacturing and assembly plants and warehousing that are conducted so the
noise, odor, dust and glare of each operation is completely confined within an
enclosed building. These industries may require direct access to rail, air or
street transportation facilities; however, the size and volume of the raw
materials and finished products involved should not produce the volume of
freight generated by the uses of the Light and Heavy Industrial Districts.
Buildings in this district should be architecturally attractive and surrounded
by landscaped yards.
§12-266 USES PERMITTED; USES PERMITTED ON REVIEW.
   (A)   Permitted. Property and buildings in an I-1 District shall be used
only for the following purposes:
      (1)   Any use, except a residential use, permitted in a C-4 General
Commercial District. No dwelling uses except sleeping facilities for caretakers
and night watchpersons employed on the premises shall be permitted;
      (2)   Any of the following uses:
         (a)   Bakery;
         (b)   Bookbindery;
         (c)   Bottling works;
         (d)   Candy manufacturing;
         (e)   Commercial uses that are incidental and/or complement the
primary industrial use or manufacturing use of the property, which may include
the retail and wholesale of items made on the property and/or off-site;
         (f)   Electronic equipment assembly and manufacture;
         (g)   Engraving plant;
         (h)   Food products processing and packing;
         (i)   Furniture manufacturing;
         (j)   Instrument and meter manufacturing;
         (k)   Jewelry and watch manufacturing;
         (l)   Laundry and cleaning establishment;
         (m)   Leather goods fabrication;
         (n)   Optical goods manufacturing;
         (o)   Paper products manufacturing;
         (p)   Propane dispensary;
         (q)   Shoe manufacturing;
         (r)   Sporting goods manufacturing;
         (s)   Storage warehouse; and
         (t)   Wholesale or warehousing enterprise.
      (3)   All of the uses permitted under this section shall have their
primary operations conducted entirely within enclosed buildings, and shall not
emit any dust or smoke, or noxious odor or fumes outside of the building
housing the operation, or produce a noise level occurring on the adjacent
street. Any article or material stored temporarily outside of an enclosed
building as an incidental part of the primary operation shall be so screened by
ornamental walls and fences or evergreen planting that it cannot be seen from
adjoining public streets or adjacent lots when viewed by a person standing at
ground level.
   (B)   Permitted on review. Towers.
(Ord. 1523, passed 3-13-2001; Ord. 1779, passed 6-26-2018)
§12-267 AREA REGULATIONS.
   All buildings shall be set back from the street right-of-way lines and lot
lines to comply with the following yard requirements.
   (A)   Front yard. All buildings shall set back from the street right-of-way
line to provide a front yard having not less than 25 feet in depth.
   (B)   Side yard. No building shall be located closer than 25 feet to a side
lot line.
   (C)   Rear yard. No building shall be located closer than 25 feet to the
rear lot line.
   (D)   Coverage. Main and accessory buildings and off-street parking and
loading facilities shall not cover more than 80% of the lot area.
   (E)   Landscaping. All yard areas required under this section and other
yards and open spaces existing around buildings shall be landscaped and
maintained in a neat condition.
   (F)   Plan approval. Whenever property in this district abuts or is
separated only by a street or alley from property within a residential or
agricultural district, issuance of building permits thereon may be subject to
approval of a development plan by the Planning Commission as follows.
      (1)   The conditions of such approval may impose such front, side and
rear yard setbacks, screening, landscaping, driveway and parking area design
requirements as shall be deemed necessary to protect the character of the
adjacent properties; provided, that in no instance shall a setback of greater
than 25 feet from any property line be required.
      (2)   Conditions imposed by the Planning Commission shall be set forth in
the minutes of the Commission and shall have the same force and effect as if
set forth in these regulations.
(Ord. 1486, passed 6-22-1999)
§12-268 HEIGHT REGULATIONS.
   No building or structure shall exceed 90 feet in height, except as
hereinafter provided in §
12-362.
§12-269 SIGN REGULATIONS.
   (A)   One wall or canopy sign may be erected, not exceeding an aggregate
surface display area of three square feet per each linear foot of building wall
to which the sign is affixed; total sign size is limited to 65% of the total
wall area of the wall to which the sign is attached.
   (B)   In addition to the wall or canopy signs permitted above, a lot
containing one business establishment or vacant lot may utilize for business
sign or outdoor advertising one projecting or ground sign of two square feet of
display surface area per linear foot of street frontage; provided, however,
that if more than one such pole or ground sign is erected, an aggregate display
area not exceeding one square foot of display surface area per linear foot of
street frontage shall be allowed.
   (C)   Ground or pole signs shall not exceed 35 feet in height.
(Ord. 1452, passed 1-13-1998)
§12-270 I-2 LIGHT INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT.
   (A)   The I-2 Light Industrial District is intended primarily for the
conduct of manufacturing, assembling and fabrication.
   (B)   These uses do not depend primarily on frequent visits of customers or
clients, but usually require good accessibility to major rail, air or street
transportation facilities.
§12-271 USES PERMITTED; USES PERMITTED ON REVIEW.
   (A)   Permitted. Property and buildings in an I-2 Light Industrial District
shall be used only for the following purposes:
      (1)   Any use permitted in the I-1 Restricted Manufacturing and
Warehousing District. No dwelling use, except sleeping facilities required by
caretakers or night watchpersons employed on the premises, shall be permitted
in an I-2 Light Industrial District;
      (2)   (a)   Any of the following uses:
            1.   Building materials sales yard and lumberyard, including the
sale of rock, sand, gravel and the like as an incidental part of the main
business, but not including a concrete batch plant or transit mix plant;
            2.   Contractor’s equipment storage yard or plant, or rental of
equipment commonly used by contractors;
            3.   Farm produce, grain and feed storage including grain
elevators;
            4.   Freighting or trucking yard or terminal;
            5.   Oil field equipment storage yard;
            6.   Public utility service yard or electrical receiving or
transforming station; and
            7.   Sale barn.
         (b)   No article or material permitted in this division (A)(2) shall
be kept, stored or displayed outside of a building unless it be screened by
fences, walls or planting so that it cannot be seen from adjoining public
streets or adjacent lots when viewed by a person standing on ground level
immediately adjacent to the lot on which the use is located; provided, however,
that screening shall not be required in excess of seven feet in height.
      (3)   The following uses, when conducted within a completely enclosed
building:
         (a)   Assembly of electrical appliances, electronic instruments and
devices, radios and phonographs, including the manufacture of small parts only,
such as coils, condensers, transformers, crystal holders and the like;
         (b)   Automobile assembling, painting, upholstering, rebuilding,
reconditioning, body and fender works, truck repairing and overhauling, tire
retreading or recapping and battery manufacturing;
         (c)   Foundry casting lightweight nonferrous metal not causing noxious
fumes or odors;
         (d)   Machine shop;
         (e)   Manufacture of musical instruments, toys, novelties and rubber
and metal stamps;
         (f)   The manufacture and maintenance of electric and neon signs,
commercial advertising structure, light sheet metal products, including heating
and ventilating ducts and equipment, cornices, eaves and the like;
         (g)   The manufacture, compounding, assembling or treatment of
articles or merchandise from the following previously prepared materials: bone,
cellophane, canvas, cloth, cork, feathers, felt, fiber, fur, glass, hair, horn,
leather, paper, plastics, precious or semiprecious metals or stone, shell,
textiles, tobacco, wood, yarn and paint not employing a boiling process;
         (h)   The manufacture, compounding, processing, packaging or treatment
of such products as bakery goods, candy, cosmetics, dairy products, drugs,
perfumes, pharmaceuticals, perfumed toilet soap, toiletries and food products;
and
         (i)   The manufacture of pottery and figurines or other similar
ceramic products, using only previously pulverized clay, and kilns fired only
by electricity or gas.
      (4)   Buildings, structures and uses accessory and customarily incidental
to any of the above uses; and
      (5)   Commercial uses that are incidental and/or complement the primary
industrial use or manufacturing use of the property, which may include the
retail and wholesale of items made on the property and/or off-site.
   (B)   Requirements. The uses permitted under this section shall be conducted
in such a manner that no noxious odor, fumes or dust will be emitted beyond the
property line of the lot on which the use is located.
   (C)   Permitted on review. Towers.
(Ord. 1523, passed 3-13-2001; Ord. 1780, passed 6-26-2018)
§12-272 AREA REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Front and side yard. There are no specific front or side yard
requirements for uses in this district; provided, however, that a building
shall set back a distance of not less than 25 feet from the side lot line that
adjoins a dwelling district.
   (B)   Rear yard.
      (1)   Where a building is to be serviced from the rear there shall be
provided an alley, service court, rear yard or combination thereof of not less
than 20 feet in width with 30 feet recommended, or of adequate area and width
to provide for maneuver of service vehicles, whichever is the greater.
      (2)   In all other cases no rear yard is required; provided, however,
that a building shall set back a distance of not less than 25 feet from the
rear lot line that adjoins a dwelling district.
   (C)   Yard area. Buildings shall be provided with a yard area adequate to
meet the off-street parking requirements set forth in § 12-368.
   (D)   Plan approval. Whenever property in this district abuts or is
separated only by a street or alley from property within a residential or
agricultural district, issuance of building permits thereon may be subject to
approval of a development plan by the Planning Commission as follows.
      (1)   The conditions of such approval may impose such front, side and
rear yard setbacks, screening, landscaping, driveway and parking area design
requirements as shall be deemed necessary to protect the character of the
adjacent properties; provided, that in no instance shall a setback of greater
than 25 feet from any property line be required.
      (2)   Conditions imposed by the Planning Commission shall be set forth in
the minutes of the Commission and shall have the same force and effect as if
set forth in these regulations.
(Ord. 1486, passed 6-22-1999)
§12-273 HEIGHT REGULATIONS.
   No building shall exceed 90 feet in height, except as hereinafter provided
in §
12-362.
§12-274 SIGN REGULATIONS.
   One wall or canopy sign may be erected, not exceeding an aggregate surface
display area of three square feet per each linear foot of building wall to
which the sign is affixed; total sign size is limited to 65% of the total wall
area of the wall to which the sign is attached. In addition to the wall or
canopy signs permitted above, a lot containing one business establishment or
vacant lot may utilize for business sign or outdoor advertising one projecting
or ground sign of two square feet of display surface area per linear foot of
street frontage; provided, however, that if more than one such pole or ground
sign is erected, an aggregate display area not exceeding one square foot of
display surface area per linear foot of street frontage shall be allowed.
Ground or pole signs shall not exceed 35 feet in height.
(Ord. 1452, passed 1-13-1998)
§12-275 I-3 GENERAL INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT.
   This industrial district is intended to provide for heavy industrial uses
and other uses not otherwise provided for in the districts established by this
chapter. The intensity of uses permitted in this district makes it most
desirable that they be located downwind and separated from residential and
commercial uses.
§12-276 USES PERMITTED.
   Property and buildings in an I-3 Heavy Industrial District may be used for
any use except the following:
   (A)   All residential uses except sleeping facilities required by night
watchpersons and caretakers employed upon the premises; and
   (B)   All uses not complying with this chapter, or any other county, state
or federal regulation or law.
§12-277 USES PERMITTED ON REVIEW.
   The following uses may be permitted on review in accordance with the
provisions contained in this part:
   (A)   Cement, lime or gypsum manufacture;
   (B)   Commercial feed pens for livestock;
   (C)   Natural gas production and distribution;
   (D)   Petroleum production and refining;
   (E)   Wholesale or bulk storage of gasoline, propane or butane, or other
petroleum products;
   (F)   Disposal plants of all types, including trash and garbage, sewage
treatment, including lagoons, and compost plants;
   (G)   Property and buildings in an I-3 Heavy Industrial District, when
permitted on review for the following purposes, shall have the use thereon
conducted in such a manner that all operation, display or storage of material
or equipment is so screened by ornamental fences, walls or permanent evergreen
planting that it cannot be seen from a public street or from adjacent lots when
viewed by a person standing on ground level, provided, however, that no
screening in excess of seven feet in height shall be required:
      (1)   Automobile salvage or junk yard;
      (2)   Building materials salvage yard;
      (3)   Junk or salvage yard of any kind;
      (4)   Scrap metal storage yard; and
      (5)   Any use not otherwise authorized by this chapter.
   (H)   Towers.
(Ord. 1523, passed 3-13-2001)
§12-278 AREA REGULATIONS.
   (A)   There are no specific front or side yard requirements for uses in this
district.
   (B)   (1)   Where a building is to be serviced from the rear there shall be
provided an alleyway, service court, rear yard or combination thereof of not
less than 20 feet with 30 feet recommended or of adequate area and width to
provide for maneuver of service vehicles, whichever is the greater.
      (2)   In all other cases, no rear yard is required.
   (C)   Buildings shall be provided with a yard area adequate to meet the off-
street parking requirements set forth in this chapter.
   (D)   Whenever property in this district abuts or is separated only by a
street or alley from property within a residential or agricultural district,
issuance of building permits thereon may be subject to approval of a
development plan by the Planning Commission as follows.
      (1)   The conditions of such approval may impose such front, side and
rear yard setbacks, screening, landscaping, driveway and parking area design
requirements as shall be deemed necessary to protect the character of the
adjacent properties; provided, that in no instance shall a setback of greater
than 25 feet from any property line be required.
      (2)   Conditions imposed by the Planning Commission shall be set forth in
the minutes of the Commission and shall have the same force and effect as if
set forth in these regulations.
(Ord. 1486, passed 6-22-1999)
§12-279 HEIGHT REGULATIONS.
   Where a lot adjoins a dwelling district, the building shall not exceed 35
feet, unless it is set back ten feet from all front and side yard lines, plus
an additional one foot of setback for each foot of additional height above 45
feet, except as otherwise provided in this chapter.
§12-280 SIGN REGULATIONS.
   (A)   One wall or canopy sign may be erected, not exceeding an aggregate
surface display area of three square feet per each linear foot of building wall
to which the sign is affixed; total sign size is limited to 65% of the total
wall area of the wall to which the sign is attached.
   (B)   In addition to the wall or canopy signs permitted above, a lot
containing one business establishment or vacant lot may utilize for business
sign or outdoor advertising one projecting or ground sign of two square feet of
display surface area per linear foot of street frontage; provided, however,
that if more than one such pole or ground sign is erected, an aggregate display
area not exceeding one square foot of display surface area per linear foot of
street frontage shall be allowed.
   (C)   Ground or pole signs shall not exceed 35 feet in height.
(Ord. 1452, passed 1-13-1998)
ARTICLE F. OTHER DISTRICTS
§12-290 F-1 FLOODPLAIN DISTRICT.
   (A)   This district is intended to encompass those lands lying within the
boundaries of the 100-year floodplains identified in the flood insurance study
for the city and provide regulations assuring appropriate land uses within this
district in order to minimize flood danger and loss to life and property.
   (B)   The uses permitted in this district are those allowed in the
underlying zoning district subject to the provisions of this district and the
flood hazard area development regulations of the city.
Cross-reference:
   See also Chapter 6 of this part
§12-291 APPLICATION AS AN OVERLAY DISTRICT.
   The provisions of this district shall be in addition to those of the several
zoning districts of this chapter. Nothing in this district shall be construed
as permitting any uses of land which do not conform to the underlying zoning
district classification.
§12-292 BOUNDARIES ESTABLISHED.
   The boundaries of this district are hereby established as those of the
floodways and 100-year floodplains established in exhibits 3 and 4 of the flood
insurance study for the city, as furnished by the federal insurance
administration, and subsequent amendments thereto, which are hereby made a part
of this chapter by reference and shall have the same force and effect as the
zoning districts map.
§12-293 USES PERMITTED.
   (A)   Floodway uses. Property located in a designated floodway shall be
restricted to uses having a low flood damage potential and not obstructing
flood flows to the extent that they conform to the underlying zoning district
and do not require structures, fences, fill or storage of equipment damaged by
periodic inundation or subject to flotation. No use shall adversely affect the
capacity of the floodway. Uses permitted are:
      (1)   Agricultural uses, such as the raising of crops, pasture, grazing
and outdoor plant nurseries; provided, that such uses may be permitted as a use
on review in residential, commercial and industrial zoning districts;
      (2)   Commercial and industrial uses such as loading areas, parking areas
and storage yards; but not including storage of automobiles for sale;
      (3)   Private and public recreational facilities; and
      (4)   Residential accessory uses such as lawns, gardens and parking
areas.
   (B)   Flood fringe uses. Property located in the flood fringe may be used
for any use allowed in the underlying zoning district; provided, that all
buildings and structures shall be evaluated or protected from flooding or flood
damage in conformance with the provisions of the flood hazard area development
regulations of the city.
§12-294 DEVELOPMENT PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Prior to issuance of building permits for any property in the F-1 Floodplain
District, an approved development permit as required in the flood hazard area
development regulations of the city shall be submitted to the building
inspector.
§12-295 CHANGE OF ZONING MAP FOR F-1 FLOODPLAIN DISTRICT.
   Property currently within the F-1 Floodplain District shall be rezoned to
its zoning district classification prior to its designation as being within the
F-1 Floodplain District and the zoning districts map be amended to reflect the
change.
§12-296 ADOPTION OF REGULATIONS.
   (A)   The flood hazard area regulations of the city, as adopted by the
Metropolitan Area Planning Commission are hereby adopted by reference and shall
have the same force and effect as if specifically stated herein, adopted and
codified in whole within this part.
   (B)   The flood hazard area regulations herein adopted shall be codified in
this part, a true and accurate copy to be filed with the City Clerk.
§12-297 FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH FLOOD HAZARD REGULATION; OFFENSE.
   (A)   Failure to comply with the provisions of the flood hazard area
development regulations shall be an offense against the city, the same as if
the regulations were adopted and codified in whole within this part.
   (B)   Each day in which any person, firm or corporation maintains any
development, in violation of the flood hazard area development regulations,
shall be deemed a separate offense subject to a fine as provided in §
1-108.
§ 12-298 [RESERVED].
§ 12-299 [RESERVED].
§12-300 T-C TOURIST COMMERCIAL DISTRICT.
   T-C Tourist Commercial District zoning is intended to accommodate the
grouping of those commercial activities necessary to supply the normal needs of
tourists, and to protect these against other incompatible commercial uses. This
district is intended to be located in defined areas, adjacent or convenient to
arterials and arterial highways and at the intersection of arterials or
arterial highways and roads leading into primary entrances of major public
recreational area.
§12-301 USES PERMITTED.
   The following uses are permitted:
   (A)   Art supply store and hobby shop;
   (B)   Bait shop (live bait);
   (C)   Boat and marine sales and service;
   (D)   Cafeteria or restaurant;
   (E)   Drive-in restaurant;
   (F)   Gift, novelty or souvenir store;
   (G)   Hotel, motel, tourist court;
   (H)   Ice dispensing machine (and other outdoor type automatic vending
machines);
   (I)   Laundry or dry-cleaning pick up stations;
   (J)   Laundry, self-service;
   (K)   Miniature golf course;
   (L)   Mobile home court or park, trailer court;
   (M)   Municipal building, public building;
   (N)   Offices accessory to main use;
   (O)   Parking lot or structure, noncommercial accessory to and within 200
feet;
   (P)   Parks or playgrounds;
   (Q)   Service station; and
   (R)   Sporting goods store.
§ 12-302 USES PERMITTED ON REVIEW.
   The following uses are permitted on review:
   (A)   Bar, lounge or tavern, private club;
   (B)   Beauty shop, barbershop;
   (C)   Dance hall;
   (D)   Drugstore or pharmacy;
   (E)   Grocery, supermarket, delicatessen;
   (F)   Group fallout shelter, bomb or tornado;
   (G)   Liquor store; retail outlet;
   (H)   Theater, drive-in, provided that no part of the theater screen,
projection booth or other building shall be located closer than 500 feet to any
residential district, or closer than 50 feet to any exterior property line or
public right-of-way; and no parking space shall be located closer than 100 feet
to any residential district; and
   (I)   Theater, indoor.
§12-303 ADVERTISING SIGNS OR STRUCTURES.
   (A)   Accessory signs (signs relating to businesses or goods sold on the
property on which they are located) shall not be greater in area than 400
square feet, provided, that for every five feet of height above 20 feet, the
sign shall be reduced in area by 100 square feet. Such signs shall not be
located closer than 25 feet to the front property line of any street right-of-
way. Provided, further, that the signs shall have no moving or flashing lights
or colors if located within 250 feet of and viewable from any residential
district.
   (B)   Temporary advertising signs no greater than 20 square feet in area
advertising the sale of the land or homes on which the signs are located, so
long as the signs be forthwith removed upon the sale and conveyance of the land
or homes.
§12-304 OTHER USES.
   Any use which, in the opinion of the Planning Commission, would be similar
in character to those above enumerated and is not more obnoxious or detrimental
to the area in which it is located, by reason of noise, offensive odor, smoke,
dust, vibration, traffic congestion or danger to life and property than those
uses enumerated above.
§12-305 AREA AND SETBACK REQUIREMENTS.
   The minimum front yard, side yard, rear yard and the maximum coverage for
the buildings shall be determined by the plot plan approved by the City
Council.
§12-306 HEIGHT REGULATIONS.
   There shall be no height limit for any building or structure in this
district.
§12-307 SPECIAL PROVISIONS.
   (A)   There shall be no outdoor storage, display or use within any required
front, side or rear yard setback other than parking, loading and unloading and
landscaping, except that signs shall be governed as set forth above.
   (B)   Off-street parking requirements are as follows.

ARTICLE G. AGRICULTURAL DISTRICTS (A)
§12-320 A-1 GENERAL AGRICULTURAL DISTRICT.
   This district is intended to provide an area primarily for agricultural uses
or the extraction of the various products such as oil, minerals, rock and
gravel from the earth. The rural nature and low density of population in this
district requires only that the buildings and extraction facilities related to
the uses of this district have a reasonable setback from streets and highways.
It is the purpose of this district to protect such uses from unplanned
urbanization so long as the land therein is devoted primarily to agriculture or
extraction of minerals.
§12-321 USES PERMITTED.
   Property and buildings in an A-1 General Agricultural District shall be used
only for the following purposes:
   (A)   One-family or two-family dwellings for farm owner, operator or
employee;
   (B)   All agricultural land uses, buildings and activities;
   (C)   Mining, quarrying and earth extraction industries;
   (D)   Oil well or gas well including the drilling thereof;
   (E)   Transportation, pipeline and utility easements and rights-of-way;
   (F)   Temporary roadside stands for the sale of farm products grown on the
premises; provided, however that up to one-third of the display area for
produce may be used for the sale of products not grown on the premises. The
temporary structure shall be required to set back from the roadway an adequate
distance to permit parking and ingress and egress and shall not be constructed
in such a location as would create an undue traffic hazard;
   (G)   All the following uses:
      (1)   Advertising signs:
         (a)   One wall or canopy sign may be erected, not exceeding an
aggregate surface display area of three square feet per each linear foot of
building wall to which the sign is affixed; total sign size is limited to 65%
of the total wall area of the wall to which the sign is attached;
         (b)   In addition to the wall signs permitted above, outdoor
advertising signs may be erected. One projecting or ground sign of two square
feet of display surface area per linear foot of street frontage is allowed;
provided, however, that if more than one such pole or ground sign is erected,
an aggregate display area not exceeding one square foot of display surface area
per linear foot of street frontage shall be allowed; providing further that no
single sign shall exceed 400 square feet in area; and
         (c)   Ground or pole signs shall not exceed 35 feet in height.
      (2)   Church;
      (3)   Home occupation;
      (4)   Kennel;
      (5)   Library;
      (6)   Municipal buildings and facilities and public utilities, but not
excluding storage yards or work yards;
      (7)   Park and playground or public recreation area;
      (8)   Plant nursery or greenhouse;
      (9)   School; and
      (10)   Sewage treatment plant and lagoon.
   (H)   Accessory buildings which are not a part of the main building,
including barns, sheds and other farm buildings, private garages and accessory
buildings which are a part of the main building.
(Ord. 1452, passed 1-13-1998)
§12-322 USES PERMITTED ON REVIEW.
   The following uses may be permitted on review in accordance with the
provisions contained in this part:
   (A)   Airport or landing field;
   (B)   Bed and breakfast, principally used as a single-family home, with the
provision of guest lodging as a secondary feature and must conform to all the
following conditions:
      (1)   May be permitted in any residential or agricultural zoning
district;
      (2)   No more than four guest bedrooms may be provided;
      (3)   No individual cooking facilities may be installed in any guestroom;
      (4)   Meal service is limited to breakfast and limited to resident guests
only. Sale of food and beverages to other than overnight guests is strictly
prohibited;
      (5)   The owner shall reside on-premises;
      (6)   One parking space shall be provided for the owner-operator plus two
spaces for each four rooms that serve as guest bedrooms;
      (7)   Parking shall be located to the side or rear of the structure;
      (8)   Any proposed additions must be compatible with the architectural
style and building materials of the dwelling; and
      (9)   No lighting or signage may be installed which has not been reviewed
as part of the proposed development plan.
   (C)   Cemetery;
   (D)   Group home;
   (E)   Home beauty shop located in a dwelling, provided such shop is
conducted within the main building, and is operated only by the inhabitants
thereof, and does not exceed one operator. The use shall be conducted in such a
way that it is clearly incidental to the dwelling use and shall not change the
character thereof. No sign shall be permitted except one non-illuminated
nameplate not exceeding two square feet in area, attached to the main building;
   (F)   Private marina, boat docks, golf course or driving range, or other
private outdoor recreation activity;
   (G)   Public stable or riding academy;
   (H)   Sale barn or commercial feed pen for livestock;
   (I)   Towers; and
   (J)   Veterinary clinic.
(Ord. 1254, passed 12-17-1985; Ord. 1414, passed 11-26-1996; Ord. 1523, passed
3-13-2001; Ord. 1819, passed 3-23-2021)
§12-323 AREA REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Front yard. All buildings and mining operations, except roadside
stands for the sale of farm products grown on the premises, shall be set back
from road and street right-of-way lines to comply with the following front yard
requirements.
      (1)   All buildings shall set back from a state or federal highway or
county highway or section line road a minimum of 25 feet from the right-of-way
line or 75 feet from the centerline of the right-of-way easement, whichever is
greater.
      (2)   On all public roads or streets, other than federal, state or county
highways and section line roads, all buildings shall set back a minimum of 25
feet from the right-of-way line or 55 feet from the centerline of the right-of-
way easement, whichever is greater.
   (B)   Side yard.
      (1)   For dwellings located on interior lots, there shall be a side yard
on each side of the main building of not less than eight feet for dwellings of
one story and of not less than 12 feet for dwellings of more than one story,
except as hereinafter provided in §
12-362.
      (2)   For unattached buildings of accessory use, there shall be a side
yard of not less than eight feet; provided, however, that unattached one-story
buildings of accessory use shall not be required to set back more than three
feet from an interior side lot line when all parts of the accessory buildings
are located more than 70 feet behind the front lot line.
      (3)   For dwellings and accessory buildings located on corner lots, there
shall be a side yard setback from the intersecting street of not less than 15
feet in case such lot is back-to-back with another corner lot and 20 feet in
every other case. The interior side yard of a corner lot shall be the same as
for dwellings and accessory buildings on an interior lot.
      (4)   Churches and main and accessory buildings, other than dwellings and
buildings accessory to the dwellings, shall set back from all exterior and
interior side lot lines a distance of not less than 25 feet.
   (C)   Rear yard. There shall be a rear yard for a main building of not less
than 20 feet or 20% of the depth of the lot, whichever amount is smaller.
Unattached buildings of accessory use may be located in the rear yard of a main
building, but not closer than five feet to a rear lot line or not within a
utility easement.
§12-324 A-2 SUBURBAN DISTRICT.
   This district is intended to provide a location for the land situated on the
fringe of the urban area that is used for agricultural purposes, but will be
undergoing urbanization in the near future. Many tracts in this district will
be in close proximity to residential and commercial uses. Therefore, the
agricultural activities conducted in this district should not be detrimental to
urban land uses. It is not intended that this district provide a location for a
lower standard of residential, commercial or industrial development than is
authorized in other districts. The types of uses, required area and intensity
of use of land which is permitted in this district is designed to encourage and
protect agricultural uses so long as the land therein is devoted primarily to
agriculture.
§12-325 USES PERMITTED.
   Property and buildings in an A-2 Suburban District shall be used only for
the following purposes:
   (A)   Detached one-family dwelling for farm owner, operator or employee;
   (B)   Church;
   (C)   Public school or school offering general educational courses the same
as ordinarily given in the public schools and having no rooms regularly used
for housing or sleeping;
   (D)   Agricultural crops;
   (E)   The raising of farm animals, but not the operation of commercial feed
pens for livestock. On all tracts of land containing less than ten acres the
raising of hogs shall be prohibited, and on all other tracts the number of hogs
weighing more than 25 pounds shall not exceed 20 grain-fed or three garbage-fed
hogs. Hogs shall not be located closer than 200 feet to the property line of
the tract on which they are located;
   (F)   Oil well or gas well, including the drilling thereof;
   (G)   All of the following uses:
      (1)   Country club and golf course;
      (2)   Home occupation;
      (3)   Library;
      (4)   Park or playground or public recreation area; and
      (5)   Plant nursery.
   (H)   Transportation, pipeline and utility easements and rights-of-way;
   (I)   Bulletin board or sign, not exceeding 40 square feet in area
appertaining to the lease, hire or sale of a building or premises, which board
or sign shall be removed as soon as the premises are leased, hired or sold; and
   (J)   Accessory buildings which are not a part of the main building,
including barns, sheds and other farm buildings and private garages and
accessory buildings which are a part of the main building.
§12-326 USES PERMITTED ON REVIEW.
   The following uses may be permitted on review in accordance with the
provisions contained in this part:
   (A)   Airport or landing field;
   (B)   Bed and breakfast, principally used as a single-family home, with the
provision of guest lodging as a secondary feature and must conform to all the
following conditions:
      (1)   May be permitted in any residential or agricultural zoning
district;
      (2)   No more than four guest bedrooms may be provided;
      (3)   No individual cooking facilities may be installed in any guestroom;
      (4)   Meal service is limited to breakfast and limited to resident guests
only. Sale of food and beverages to other than overnight guests is strictly
prohibited;
      (5)   The owner shall reside on-premises;
      (6)   One parking space shall be provided for the owner-operator plus two
spaces for each four rooms that serve as guest bedrooms;
      (7)   Parking shall be located to the side or rear of the structure;
      (8)   Any proposed additions must be compatible with the architectural
style and building materials of the dwelling; and
      (9)   No lighting or signage may be installed which has not been reviewed
as part of the proposed development plan.
   (C)   Cemetery;
   (D)   Group home;
   (E)   (1)   Home beauty shop located in a dwelling, provided such shop is
conducted within the main building, and is operated only by the inhabitants
thereof, and does not exceed one operator. The use shall be conducted in such a
way that it is clearly incidental to the dwelling use and shall not change the

      (2)   No sign shall be permitted except one non-illuminated nameplate not
exceeding two square feet in area, attached to the main building;
   (F)   Kennel;
   (G)   Private marina, boat docks, golf course or driving range, or other
private outdoor recreation activity;
   (H)   Public stable or riding academy;
   (I)   Radio or television station;
   (J)   Sewage lagoon; and
   (K)   Towers.
(Ord. 1254, passed 12-17-1985; Ord. 1414, passed 11-26-1996; Ord. 1523, passed
3-13-2001)
§12-327 AREA REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Front yard. All buildings shall be set back from the street right-of-
way lines to comply with the following front yard requirements.
      (1)   All buildings shall set back from a state or federal highway,
county highway or section line road a minimum of 25 feet from the right-of-way
line or 75 feet from the centerline of the right-of-way easement, whichever is
greater.
      (2)   On all public roads or streets other than federal, state or county
highways and section line roads, all buildings shall set back a minimum of 25
feet from the right-of-way line or 55 feet from the centerline of the right-of-
way easement, whichever is greater.
      (3)   When a yard has double frontage, the front yard requirements shall
be complied with on both streets, except when rear access is denied.
   (B)   Side yard.
      (1)   For dwellings located on interior lots, there shall be a side yard
on each side of the main building of not less than eight feet for dwellings of
one story, and of not less than 12 feet for dwellings of more than one story,
except as hereinafter provided in §
12-362.
      (2)   For unattached buildings of accessory use, there shall be a side
yard of not less than eight feet; provided, however, that unattached one-story
buildings of accessory use shall not be required to set back more than three
feet from an interior side lot line when all parts of the accessory building
are located more than 70 feet behind the front lot line.
      (3)   For dwellings and accessory buildings located on corner lots, there
shall be a side yard setback from the intersecting street of not less than 15
feet in case such lot is back-to-back with another corner lot and 20 feet in
every other case. The interior side yard of a corner lot shall be the same as
for dwellings and accessory buildings on an interior lot.
      (4)   Churches and main and accessory buildings, other than dwellings and
buildings accessory to dwellings, shall set back from all exterior and interior
side lot lines a distance of not less than 25 feet.
   (C)   Rear yard.
      (1)   There shall be a rear yard for a main building of not less than 20
feet or 20% of the depth of the lot, whichever amount is smaller.
      (2)   Unattached buildings of accessory use may be located in the rear
yard of a main building, but not closer than five feet from the rear lot line.
   (D)   Lot width. For dwellings there shall be a minimum lot width of 50 feet
at the front building line, and such lot shall abut on a street for a distance
of not less than 30 feet.
   (E)   Intensity of use.
      (1)   For each dwelling and buildings accessory thereto, there shall be a
lot area of not less than two acres.
      (2)   For churches and main and accessory buildings other than dwellings
and buildings accessory to dwellings, the lot area shall be adequate to provide
the yard areas required by this section and the off-street parking areas
required in §
12-364.
   (F)   Coverage. Main and accessory buildings shall not cover more than 30%
of the lot area on interior lots, and 35% of the lot area on corner lots;
accessory building shall not cover more than 20% of the rear yard.
§12-328 HEIGHT REGULATIONS.
   No building shall exceed two and one-half stories or 35 feet in height
except as provided in §
12-362.
§12-329 AP AGRICULTURE PRESERVE DISTRICT.
   (A)   The AP Agriculture Preserve District is intended to provide an area
primarily for agricultural uses or the extraction of the various products such
as oil, minerals, rock and gravel from the earth on parcels of ten acres or
more in size. It is the purpose of this district to protect such uses from
urban densities and intensities of development principally in the Stagestand
Creek drainage basin and in areas with similar rural and agricultural
characteristics as the Stagestand Creek drainage basin. The district is
considered appropriate as the zoning district applied to rural areas annexed,
may be applied to existing areas characterized as rural or low density, and is
intended to implement the Highway 7 corridor study recommendations and preserve
the rural, agricultural nature rural and low density areas, while providing for
rural low density development that will require minimal public improvements and
services.
   (B)   Large lot residential subdivision tracts are permitted, but public
sewer is not provided, although public water may be available near boundaries
within the Claridy Creek drainage basin. Private sewage lagoons shall not be
considered an acceptable form of sewage disposal within the city limits. This
district is designed to encourage a wide variety of agricultural development
while restricting the subdivision of land into parcels too small to farm to
meet the definition of “agriculture” and/or “agriculture preserve.”
   (C)   It is not intended that this district provide a location for urban
service standards of residential development that is authorized in other
districts.
(Ord. 1558, passed 2-25-2003)
§12-330 USES PERMITTED.
   (A)   Advertising signs:
      (1)   A sign not exceeding 15 square feet in area attached to the main
building or located no closer than ten feet back from the right-of-way line on
the same lot with the main building, and with the height of the sign not to
exceed five feet; and
      (2)   No signs advertising products not sold on the premises will be
permitted.
   (B)   Any agricultural operation;
   (C)   Home occupation;
   (D)   Mining, quarrying and earth extraction industries;
   (E)   Oil well or gas well including the drilling thereof;
   (F)   One-family or two-family dwelling for agricultural property owner,
operator or farm employee;
   (G)   Plant nurseries and greenhouses;
   (H)   Temporary roadside stands for the sale of farm products grown on the
premises; provided, however that up to one-third of the display area for
produce may be used for the sale of products not grown on the premises. The
temporary structure shall be required to set back from the roadway an adequate
distance to provide parking off the street right-of-way and shall not be placed
in such a location as would create an undue traffic hazard; and
   (I)   Accessory structures and uses customarily incidental to any of the
above permitted uses when located on the same property.
(Ord. 1558, passed 2-25-2003)
§12-331 USES PERMITTED ON REVIEW.
   (A)   Aircraft landing field and associated facilities;
   (B)   Cemetery;
   (C)   Church;
   (D)   Commercial outdoor recreation facilities, including, but not limited
to, golf course, driving ranges, park facilities or other private outdoor
recreation activities;
   (E)   Commercial radio and television towers and transmitters;
   (F)   Community or government building;
   (G)   Hunting club or shooting preserve;
   (H)   Kennel for the raising of fur-bearing animals;
   (I)   Memorial garden;
   (J)   Park or recreational area operated by a governmental agency;
   (K)   Private stable or riding academy;
   (L)   Public or private school;
   (M)   Sale barn for livestock;
   (N)   Veterinary clinic; and
   (O)   Accessory structures and uses customarily incidental to any of the
above uses permitted on review when located on the same property.
(Ord. 1558, passed 2-25-2003)
§12-332 AREA REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Front yard. All buildings and mining operations, except roadside
stands for the sale of farm products grown on the premises, shall be set back
from road and street right-of-way lines to comply with the following front yard
requirements.
      (1)   All buildings shall set back from a state or federal highway or
county highway or section line road a minimum of 50 feet from the right-of-way
line or 100 feet from the centerline of the right-of-way easement, whichever is
greater.
      (2)   On all public roads or streets, other than federal, state or county
highways and section line roads, all buildings shall set back a minimum of 25
feet from the right-of-way line or 55 feet from the centerline of the right-of-
way easement, whichever is greater.
   (B)   Side yard. All buildings shall be set back a minimum of 30 feet from
the right-of-way line.
   (C)   Rear yard. All buildings shall be set back a minimum of 50 feet from
the right-of-way line.
   (D)   Intensity of use. There shall be a lot area of not less than ten
acres.
   (E)   Coverage.
      (1)   Main and accessory buildings shall not cover more than 30% of the
lot area on interior lots and more than 35% of the lot area on corner lots.
      (2)   Accessory buildings shall not cover more than 20% of the rear yard.
(Ord. 1558, passed 2-25-2003)
§12-333 HEIGHT REGULATIONS.
   No building shall exceed two and one-half stories or 35 feet in height,
except as provided in §
12-362.
(Ord. 1558, passed 2-25-2003)
§12-334 CO HIGHWAY 7 CORRIDOR OVERLAY DISTRICT.
   (A)   It is the intent of the Highway 7 Corridor Overlay District to
prescribe additional regulations designed to protect and ensure compatible land
uses, rational infrastructure and public service development and a visually
appealing and scenic quality of development along the Highway 7 corridor
through the city in order to attract future residents, business and industry.
The specific regulations of any underlying zoning district or districts remain
applicable, except as specifically modified by this overlay district, in which
case the provisions of this overlay district shall control.
   (B)   Unless otherwise specified in the ordinance creating the Highway 7
Corridor Overlay District, when any lot is partially located within the overlay
district, the remainder of the lot shall not be subject to the provisions of
this section.
(Ord. 1559, passed 2-25-2003)
§12-335 OVERLAY DISTRICT BOUNDARIES.
   The Highway 7 Corridor Overlay District shall include all properties located
within 660 feet each side of the centerline of Highway 7 connector route right-
of-way.
(Ord. 1559, passed 2-25-2003)
§12-336 USES PERMITTED.
   The Highway 7 Corridor Overlay District provisions apply to any base
district set forth in this chapter that exists within the defined overlay
district area.
(Ord. 1559, passed 2-25-2003)
