            4.   The adjusted lots in a “lot line adjustment” shall meet the
building site dimensions for the district in which the lot is located, with
respect to configuration and access to public streets, or if the lots do not
meet these requirements, the adjusted lots do not increase the degree of
nonconformity.
            5.   The “lot line adjustment” does not create any lot which does
not meet the minimum lot width and area standards for the zone district in
which it is located.
            6.   The “lot line adjustment” does not increase the degree of
nonconformance of structures, lots or other factors with respect to zoning
standards.
            7.   “Lot line adjustment” requests shall be reviewed and approved
or denied by the Community Development Director, with the right of appeal to
the Planning Commission.
   (D)   Submission for approval. Each sketch plat, preliminary plat and final
plat submitted for approval shall be placed on the agenda of the Planning
Commission only after fulfilling the appropriate requirements of these
regulations. However, a plat not meeting all of the requirements may be
submitted providing the subdivider presents with the plat a written request for
specific exceptions and enumerates in detail the reasons therefor.
      (1)   Plats submitted for consideration by the Planning Commission shall
be presented to the administrative officer of the Commission not less than 15
days prior to the date of first consideration.
      (2)   The date of the regular meeting of the Planning Commission at which
the initial hearing on any plat required by these regulations is held shall
constitute the official submittal date of the plat at which the statutory
period required for formal approval or disapproval of the plat shall commence
to run.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977; Ord. 1619, passed 2-14-2006)
§12-421 SKETCH PLAT.
   (A)   The purpose of the sketch plat is to provide for the identification
and arbitration of the interests of the parties involved in the subdivision of
land. These parties include the subdivider, adjacent landowners, Planning
Commission and the governing body.
   (B)   Prior to submission of a preliminary plat, the subdivider shall file
an application for sketch plat approval with the administrative officer of the
Planning Commission. This application shall:
      (1)   Be made on forms available from the administrative officer;
      (2)   Include all contiguous holdings of the owner including land under
the “same ownership” with an indication of which portion is proposed to be
subdivided;
      (3)   Be accompanied by a minimum of four copies of the sketch plat as
described in these regulations; and
      (4)   Include a list of adjoining property owners as reflected in the
latest tax rolls; and the mailing addresses of the owners or their
representatives.
   (C)   The sketch plat shall be reviewed by the administrative officer of the
Planning Commission with the advice of persons or agencies which he or she
shall so designate. In reviewing the sketch plat, the administrative officer
shall follow the procedures contained in these regulations.
   (D)   Upon receipt of a sketch plat, the administrative officer shall:
      (1)   Notify adjoining landowners of the sketch plat by first class mail
allowing ten days from the date of mailing for submission of comments;
      (2)   Prepare written comments and recommendations regarding the sketch
plat and transmit the report to the subdivider within 15 days of receipt of the
sketch plat.
      (3)   The report shall indicate whether the sketch plat shall be
submitted to the Planning Commission under one or more of the provisions of
these regulations; and
      (4)   In review of a sketch plat, particular attention will be given to
the arrangement, location, width of streets and their relation to topography;
sewage disposal, drainage, lot arrangement, the future development of adjacent
land, and the provisions of the general plan and other ordinances and
resolutions affecting land development use.
   (E)   The administrative officer shall refer the sketch plat to the Planning
Commission when one or more of the following conditions exists:
      (1)   If a sketch plat accompanies a rezoning request;
      (2)   If subdivider requests arbitration of recommendation of the
administrative officer;
      (3)   If the sketch plat includes an area of greater than 20 acres which
is to be developed in phases, the sketch plat shall be presented prior to or in
conjunction with the preliminary plat for the initial phase;
      (4)   If the sketch plat is, in the opinion of the administrative
officer, significantly at variance with an adopted neighborhood plan;
      (5)   If the sketch plat proposes any variance from the standards
established in these regulations; and
      (6)   If for any reason, the administrative officer believes the Planning
Commission should review the sketch plat before consideration of the
preliminary plat.
   (F)   (1)   The sketch plat shall be deemed approved only after:
         (a)   The subdivider has been notified of the administrative officer’s
recommendations and has agreed to comply therewith; or
         (b)   The Planning Commission has reviewed the sketch plat and has
approved it as submitted, conditionally approved it or approved a revision
thereof.
      (2)   In reviewing a sketch plat, the Planning Commission may approve the
submission of a preliminary plat bearing required changes rather than requiring
a revised sketch plat.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-422 PRELIMINARY PLAT.
   (A)   Based upon the approval of the sketch plat, the landowner or his or
her representative, may file an application for approval of a preliminary plat.
The application shall:
      (1)   Be made on forms available at the office of the administrative
officer of the Planning Commission;
      (2)   Include all land which the applicant proposes to subdivide,
provided that the Planning Commission shall not require a preliminary plat for
an area in excess of 80 acres;
      (3)   Be accompanied by a minimum of four copies of the preliminary plat
as described in these regulations; and
      (4)   Comply in all respects with the sketch plat as approved.
   (B)   Upon receipt of an application for preliminary plat approval, the
administrative officer shall:
      (1)   Set a hearing date for Planning Commission’s review of the
preliminary plat; and
      (2)   Notify all adjacent property owners and the subdivider as required
for sketch plat approval.
   (C)   In order to minimize the duplication of platting work, the Planning
Commission may accept a development plan in lieu of a preliminary plat. Such
substitution shall be permitted only in those instances where the development
plan contains all information required on a preliminary plat.
   (D)   The Planning Commission shall consider the preliminary plat at the
scheduled hearing, and any adjourned date thereof, and shall approve,
conditionally approve or disapprove the preliminary plat within 60 days of the
official submission date, unless continuance is agreed upon by the subdivider.
If the preliminary plat is conditionally approved or disapproved, the reasons
for such action shall be stated in writing and signed by the Planning
Commission Chairperson and attached to a copy of the plat and transmitted to
the subdivider.
   (E)   The approval of a preliminary plat shall not be subject to any
termination date, provided that any plat undeveloped for a period of more than
three years from the date of preliminary plat approval shall be reviewed for
compliance with subsequent amendments to the ordinances and resolutions
governing the subdivision and use of land as specified in § 12-406.
   (F)   Prior to approval of a final plat, the Planning Commission may permit
the preliminary plat to be divided into two or more sections and may impose
such conditions upon filing of the final plat sections as it may deem necessary
to assure the orderly development of the plat.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-423 FINAL PLAT.
   (A)   Following approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider shall file
an application for final plat approval. The application shall:
      (1)   Be made on forms available at the office of the administrative
officer of the Planning Commission;
      (2)   Comply in all respects with the preliminary plat as approved by the
Planning Commission; and
      (3)   Be accompanied by a minimum of four paper copies and one original
cloth tracing or reproduction Mylar of the final plat as described in these
regulations.
   (B)   Upon receipt of a final plat, the administrative officer shall:
      (1)   Set a date for Planning Commissioner review of the final plat; and
      (2)   Review the final plat for conformance with Planning Commission
approval of the preliminary plat and prepare a report and recommendations for
the Planning Commission.
   (C)   The Planning Commission shall, within 45 days of the official
submission date, approve, modify and approve or disapprove the subdivision
application by resolution which shall set forth any conditions to which the
approval is subject, or reasons for disapproval. In the resolution, the
Planning Commission shall stipulate the period of time when the performance
bond shall be filed or the required improvements installed, whichever is
applicable. In no event shall a performance bond be submitted later than six
months from the date of the final resolution. In no case shall the period of
time for the completion of improvements exceed two years from the date of the
final resolution.
   (D)   Upon approval of the final plat by the Planning Commission, it shall
be submitted to the governing body for approval and acceptance of public ways
and service and utility easements and land dedicated to public use. This
approval of the plat shall be shown over the signature of the Mayor/Chairperson
and attested to by the City/County Clerk. The acceptance of dedications, as
evidenced by the signature of the Mayor/Chairperson shall not be executed prior
to the subdivider’s compliance of the provisions of these regulations.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-424 SIGNING AND RECORDING OF FINAL PLAT.
   (A)   Signing of plat.
      (1)   When a bond is required, the Chairperson of the Planning Commission
shall endorse approval on the final plat after the bond has been approved by
the governing body and all conditions of the resolution pertaining to the plat
have been satisfied; and
      (2)   When installation of improvements is required, the Chairperson of
the Planning Commission shall endorse approval on the plat after all conditions
of the resolution have been satisfied and all improvements satisfactorily
completed.
   (B)   Recording of the plat.
      (1)   Upon final approval of the plat and affixing of all required
signatures, the subdivider shall prepare two contact reproducibles which shall
be fully executed;
      (2)   The subdivider, accompanied by a representative of the Planning
Commission, shall file the original tracing and two contact reproducibles with
the County Clerk and shall be responsible for all filing fees; and
      (3)   The County Clerk shall enter the original tracing of record and
return one to the administrative officer of the Planning Commission.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
ARTICLE C. IMPROVEMENTS
§12-430 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   (A)   All improvements shall be designed and installed in accordance with
all of the elements of the general plan and shall meet the minimum standards
established by the ordinances, resolutions and regulations relating thereto.
   (B)   (1)   Plans for all improvements herein required shall be prepared by
a qualified engineer, registered in the state.
      (2)   Two sets of the proposed plans and specifications for all
improvements shall be filed with the Planning Commission and approved by the
governing body prior to approval of the final plat. One set of “as built” plans
certified by an engineer registered in the state shall be filed with the City
Clerk prior to the acceptance by the City Council of any improvement installed
by the subdivider and with the Board prior to the acceptance by the Board of
any improvement installed by the subdivider.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-431 ASSURANCE OF PROVISION OF IMPROVEMENTS.
   (A)   Prior to the signing of the final plat by the Planning Commission
Chairperson, all subdividers shall be required to complete, in accordance with
the Planning Commission’s resolution and to the satisfaction of the local
government engineer, all the street, sanitary and other improvements, including
lot improvements which are required in these regulations and specified in the
preliminary plat or improvement plans.
   (B)   The Planning Commission, at its discretion, may waive the requirement
that the subdivider complete all public improvements prior to the signing of
the final plat, and, as an alternative, the applicant post a bond, provide an
escrow deposit or provide a letter of credit in an amount estimated by the
Planning Commission as sufficient to secure to the local government the
satisfactory completion of required improvements; provided, that signing of the
final plat shall not be accomplished prior to compliance with this section.
   (C)   (1)   Such performance bond or approved alternate shall comply with
all statutory requirements and shall be satisfactory to the local government
attorney as to form, sufficiency and manner of execution as set forth in these
regulations.
      (2)   The period within which required improvements must be completed
shall be specified by the Planning Commission in the resolution approving the
final subdivision plat and shall be incorporated in the surety and shall not in
any event exceed two years from the date of final approval. Such surety shall
be approved by the local government as to amount and conditions satisfactory to
the governing body.
      (3)   The Planning Commission may, upon proof of difficulty, recommend to
the governing body extension of the completion date set forth in such surety
for the maximum period of one additional year. The governing body may at any
time during the period of such surety accept a substitution of principal
sureties upon recommendation of the Planning Commission.
   (D)   A performance bond may be reduced upon actual construction of required
improvements to a ratio that the improvement bears to the total public
improvements as determined by the local government engineer. In no event shall
a performance bond be reduced below 25% of the principal amount prior to
completion of all required improvements.
   (E)   The governing body shall not release a performance bond or approved
alternate until the local government engineer has certified satisfactory
completion of all required improvements. Concurrent with the release of
performance bonds, the subdivider shall furnish the governing body with
maintenance bond or other acceptable surety to comply with the provisions of §
12-432.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-432 MAINTENANCE BOND.
   (A)   Prior to release of the performance bond or approved alternate or
signing of the final plat, the subdivider shall furnish the local government
with a maintenance bond, or escrow deposit, satisfactory to the local
government attorney as to form, sufficiency and manner of execution, to assure
the quality of materials and workmanship and maintenance of required
improvements in an amount equal to 10% of the cost of public improvements.
   (B)   The bond or approved alternate shall run for a period of 12 months
from the date of release of the final plat or performance bond or approved
alternate.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-433 PERMANENT MARKERS.
   Each lot and block corner shall be marked with iron pipes or pins not less
than one-half inch in diameter and not less than 18 inches long set not less
than one inch below the finished grade. Each subdivision corner shall be marked
with a permanent concrete marker capped with a non-corrosive metal plate set
not less than one inch below the finished grade.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-434 STREET IMPROVEMENTS.
   The subdivider of any subdivision to be used for residential, commercial,
industrial or other purposes shall lay out, grade and pave all streets that are
designated on the approved plat or that directly serve the subdivision in
accordance with the standards and specifications of the local government except
where the governing bodies have policies of additional assistance to the owners
or developers and in accordance with the following provisions:
   (A)   The new design of an improvement of an intersection of any new street
with an existing state or federal highway shall be in accordance with the
specifications of the State Highway Department, but in no case shall the
standard be less than the applicable city or county specifications;
   (B)   Whenever a subdivision contains a major street that requires a street
facility that is more costly than is required to serve the future occupants of
the subdivision, the subdivider shall be required to pay only the portion of
the cost of the major street that would equal the cost of an improvement
required to serve only the subdivision, as determined by the Planning
Commission; and
   (C)   All driveways which connect with public streets shall be constructed
in accordance with driveway standards for the city. (See §
12-709.)
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
Cross-reference:
   See also
Part 14, Chapter 6
§12-435 SIDEWALKS.
   (A)   A plan for a system of sidewalks may be required to be included within
the improvement plans. The Planning Commission may require the construction of
sidewalks to connect with existing or future proposed sidewalks in areas
adjacent to the subdivision where such sidewalks are needed for pedestrian
circulation.
   (B)   Sidewalks and walkways where constructed in the subdivision shall be
in accordance with the sidewalks system plan approved by the Planning
Commission and in accordance with the specifications governing sidewalk and
walkway construction.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-436 WATER LINES.
   The subdivider shall install water lines and fire hydrants in accordance
with the policies and specifications governing water line construction except
where the governing bodies have policies of additional assistance to the owners
or developers.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-437 SANITARY SEWERS AND SEPTIC TANKS.
   (A)   Installation of sanitary sewers. The subdivider shall install sanitary
sewers whenever a sanitary sewer is reasonably accessible as determined by the
Planning Commission. Sanitary sewers shall be installed in accordance with the
specifications governing sanitary sewer construction and the regulations of the
State Department of Health.
   (B)   Sanitary sewers in subdivisions. When subdivisions contain five acres
or more, the Planning Commission may require the subdivider to install sanitary
sewers and a disposal system that is adequate to serve all of the lots within
the subdivision.
   (C)   Septic tanks. Whenever the installation of a sanitary sewer is not
required, septic tanks or other unit disposal systems may be used in accordance
with the following provisions:
      (1)   A lot for residential use on which a unit disposal system is
located shall not be less than 22,500 square feet in area;
      (2)   No portion of any unit disposal system shall be located closer than
20 feet to the lot line of the lot on which the system is located; and
      (3)   All unit disposal systems shall comply with the requirements of the
State and County Health Departments.
   (D)   Certificates for septic or unit disposal system. For any subdivision
where sanitary sewers are not to be installed, the final plat shall bear a
certificate attesting to the suitability of each lot for a septic or unit
disposal system. The certificate shall be executed by a registered engineer or
testing laboratory and approved by the County Health Department.
   (E)   Public sewage disposal systems in Stagestand Creek drainage basin Area
F.
      (1)   Purpose. To provide for public sewage disposal systems located in
the Stagestand Creek drainage basin Area F (hereinafter called Area F) to
connect to existing public sewage disposal systems in the Claridy Creek
drainage basin. Area F shall be as shown on the map titled “forcemain layout
and drainage basin locations,” dated June 1, 2009, as provided by Search, Inc.,
which is included herein by reference.
      (2)   When permitted; sanitation. Before approval of a final plat for
land subdivision or issuance of a building permit for any new building that is
to be served by a public sewage disposal system in Area F and that is to be
connected to the existing public sewer collection system, the applicant must
demonstrate to the city that the following requirements have been met:
         (a)   Availability of excess sewer capacity in the Claridy Creek
drainage basin for peak design flow(s) up to 85% of excess sewer capacity, as
defined in §
12-204;
         (b)   Such public sewage disposal system shall be designed,
constructed, maintained and operated at all times in a sanitary manner as
required by the State Department of Environmental Quality, County Department of
Health and the city;
         (c)   Applicant shall provide all necessary easements for all portions
of the public sewage disposal system;
         (d)   Applicant shall provide for all costs of and shall provide all
design, permitting and construction of the public sewage disposal system;
         (e)   Gravity portion of the system shall comply with provisions in
Chapter 5, Article C of this part; and
         (f)   The public sewage disposal system shall be designed, constructed
and maintained to serve only land lying in Area F, limited to the amount of
available excess sewer capacity.
      (3)   Existing developed properties. Existing developed properties at the
time of this chapter have the right to connect to the public sewage disposal
system upon application made and approved by the city. Applications made to
connect to the public sewage disposal system shall comply with all applicable
state and local codes and where excess sewer capacity is available to
accommodate such application.
      (4)   Appeals. An appeal from any action, decision, ruling, judgment of
an administrative official or board or commission may be taken by any person or
persons, jointly or severally, or any taxpayer, or any officer, department,
board or commission of the city to the district court.
      (5)   Rates. Outside city limits rate, as provided for in the current
fees schedule approved by City Council setting forth such rates, shall apply to
properties on private lift stations in the Stagestand Creek drainage basin
until such time as the property is connected to a public sewage disposal system
in the Stagestand Creek drainage basin.
      (6)   Public sewer disposal system maintenance fee.
         (a)   After completion and acceptance of the public sewer disposal
system, the DPUA will require any person, firm or corporation requesting a new
sanitary sewer service connection within the defined service area of the public
sewer disposal system to pay to the DPUA a pro rata portion of the maintenance
and operation costs of the public sewer disposal system, such pro rata portion
to be calculated on a square footage basis of the total defined service area of
the public sewer disposal system. The total service area of the public sewer
disposal system shall equal Area F.
         (b)   Each tract of property identified in division (E)(6)(a) above
shall be subject to the total maintenance and operation cost participation
expense equal to pro rata share of each tract. Calculation of the costs for
each individual tract shall be determined as follows:
            1.   Formula:
 
Pro rata share = (b x c)/a
a = Total service area in square feet
b = Total maintenance and operation costs
c = Individual benefiting tract in square feet
 
            2.   Maintenance and operation costs shall include, but shall not
be limited to: administrative costs, personnel costs, power consumption costs,
repair costs and replacement costs.
            3.   The total payments calculated in this division (E)(6)(b) shall
become a liability against the property immediately upon connection to the
public sewage disposal system. Said maintenance and operation costs and the pro
rata share of said costs shall be calculated annually by DPUA and shall be paid
in equal monthly installments by the owner of the individual tract.
      (7)   Penalty. Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this
division (E) shall be assessed a penalty as provided for by §
1-108 .
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977; Ord. 1682, passed 2-9-2010)
§12-438 STORM SEWERS AND DRAINAGE.
   Drainage and drainage improvements shall be provided in accordance with the
specifications contained in the ordinances and regulations relating thereto.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-439 MAINTENANCE AND SUPERVISION.
   Where the subdivision contains sewers, sewage treatment plants, water supply
systems or other physical facilities that are necessary or desirable for the
welfare of the area or that are of common use or benefit and which are not or
cannot be satisfactorily maintained by an existing public agency; provision
shall be made which is acceptable to the agency having jurisdiction over the
location and maintenance of such facilities for the proper and continuous
operation, maintenance and supervision of such facilities.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-440 PRIVATE ROADWAYS.
   A municipality which contains large areas of rural land not served by water
and sewer facilities by the municipality shall authorize the use of private
roadways in either platted or unplatted areas and shall issue building permits
to property owners whose property is abutting upon the private roadways without
complying with standards as provided for dedicated streets subject to the
following conditions.
   (A)   The private roadway easement shall be at least 50 feet in width.
   (B)   The property abutting upon the private roadway shall contain not less
than two acres; provided, however, if the covenants of the subdivision allow
for evapotranspiration absorption systems or an aerobic wastewater treatment
system, the property abutting upon the private roadway may contain not less
than one acre.
   (C)   The property shall be more than one-fourth mile from sewer and water
facilities furnished by the municipality.
   (D)   The private roadway shall not be dedicated to the public but reserved
for future dedication and, until such future dedication, shall be the private
roadway of the owners of the abutting property.
   (E)   The private roadway shall be maintained by the owners of the property
within the subdivision.
   (F)   The municipality shall have no responsibility for the maintenance or
repair of the private roadway.
   (G)   If the property is platted, there shall be emblematized on the face of
the plat, clearly conspicuous, a notice that the streets and drives have not
been dedicated to the public and that the streets shall be maintained by the
private property owners within the subdivision. The streets shall always be
open to police, fire and other official vehicles of all state, federal, county
and municipal agencies.
   (H)   Every deed shall clearly acknowledge that the roadway is private and
not maintained by the municipality.
   (I)   Prior to the sale of any parcel of land in the subdivision, a
conspicuous sign shall be posted at the entrance to the subdivision: “private
roadway not maintained by (the municipality).” At any time after the
municipality permits the use of the private roadway, a petition of the owners
of at least 60% of the owners in area of the land to improve and dedicate the
street shall bind all of the owners thereby to permanently improve the street
or roadway in compliance with the requirements of the municipality.
   (J)   The Planning Commission may require the developer of such property to
reserve appropriate utility easements for water, sewer and any other utility
installations as may be required for present and future development.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. § 45-104
§12-441 PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS.
   (A)   Purpose. To provide for private sewage disposal systems located in the
Stagestand Creek drainage basin to connect to existing public sewage disposal
systems in the Claridy, Willow and Cow Creek drainage basins.
   (B)   When permitted; sanitation. Where a public sanitary sewer is not
reasonably accessible within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of
the city per §
12-437 , the building sewer may be connected to a private sewage disposal
system that is connected to the existing public sewage collection system.
Before approval of a final plat for land subdivision or issuance of a building
permit for any new building that is to be served by a private sewage disposal
system that is to be connected to the existing public sewer collection system,
the applicant must demonstrate to the city that the following requirements have
been met:
      (1)   Availability of excess sewer capacity in the Cow Creek, Willow
Creek or Claridy Creek drainage basins for peak design flow(s) up to 85% of
excess sewer capacity, as defined herein;
      (2)   Such private sewage disposal system shall be designed, constructed,
maintained and operated at all times in a sanitary manner as required by the
State Department of Environmental Quality, County Department of Health and the
city;
      (3)   Applicant provision of private easements for all off-site portions
of the private sewage disposal system;
      (4)   Applicant shall provide operation and maintenance of the private
sewage disposal system, including establishing funding in a form acceptable to
the city based upon projected operating and maintenance costs of the private
sewage disposal system as identified by an engineer, until such time as the
private system can be dedicated and accepted by the city as a public system, as
defined herein;
      (5)   Gravity portion of the system shall comply with provisions in
Chapter 5, Article C of this part;
      (6)   Private sewage disposal system shall be designed, constructed and
maintained to serve all contiguous land owned by the applicant; and
      (7)   On-site private sewage disposal system constructed for eventual
connection to public system:
         (a)   The private sewage disposal system has been designed to ensure a
sanitary sewer service line stub is in a location sufficient to facilitate
future connection to a public sanitary sewer system, as determined by the City
Engineer;
         (b)   At such time that a public sanitary sewer line becomes
reasonably accessible to any property served by a private sewage disposal
system, the landowner(s) shall be required to discontinue use of the private
sewage disposal system and connect to the public sanitary sewer system in
accordance with the time frames for compliance specified below:
            1.   Within two years from the date that the public sanitary sewer
line became reasonably accessible to the property;
            2.   Immediately, or as soon as practicable thereafter as
determined by the City Engineer, upon evidence of failure of the existing
private sewage disposal system; or
            3.   Within 30 days of a change in ownership of the property.
         (c)   The property owner(s) shall sign and record with the County
Clerk’s office an affidavit of disclosure stating that they agree to suspend
use of the private sewage disposal system and connect to a public sanitary
sewer system when it is reasonably accessible to the property in accordance
with the time frames for compliance specified above, whichever one occurs first
with filing of final plat or issuance of building permit.
   (C)   Discontinuance standards. Whenever the use of a private sewage system
is discontinued due to a voluntary or mandatory connection to the public
sanitary sewer system in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, the
property owner shall fill any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private
sewage facilities shall be filled with suitable material in accordance with
state and county regulations within 90 days after discontinuance.
   (D)   Appeals. An appeal from any action, decision, ruling, judgment of an
administrative official or board or commission may be taken by any person or
persons, jointly or severally, or any taxpayer, or any officer, department,
board or commission of the city to the district court.
   (E)   Rates. Outside city limits rate, as provided for in the current fees
schedule approved by City Council setting forth such rates, shall apply to
properties on private lift stations in the Stagestand Creek drainage basin
until such time as the property is connected to a public sewage disposal system
in the Stagestand Creek drainage basin.
   (F)   Penalty. Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this
section shall be assessed a penalty as provided for by §
1-108 .
(Ord. 1680, passed 10-27-2009)
ARTICLE D. DESIGN
§12-450 MINIMUM STANDARDS AND GENERAL POLICIES.
   (A)   The standards and policies for development contained in these
regulations, the zoning regulations, the building code, the major street plan
and other regulations governing land development are established as minimum
standards. However, the general plan expresses policies which are intended to
achieve optimum quality of urban development. If only the minimum standards are
followed, as expressed by the various regulations affecting land development, a
standardization of development will occur. This will produce a monotonous urban
setting. Subdivision design should be of a quality to carry out the purpose and
spirit of the policies expressed in the general plan and in these regulations
rather than be limited to the minimum standards required herein.
   (B)   The minimum design standards established in these regulations shall
provide the basic criteria for the evaluation of proposed subdivision. The
Planning Commission may, however, establish reasonable design requirements in
excess of the established minimum standards where, by reason of exceptional
topographic, hydrologic or other physical feature, the strict adherence to
these standards will result in an inappropriate subdivision design.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-451 URBAN DESIGN PRINCIPLES.
   The quality of design of the urban area is dependent on the quality of
design of the individual subdivisions that compose it. Good community design
requires the coordination of the efforts of each subdivider and developer of
land within the urban area. Therefore, the design of each subdivision shall be
prepared in accordance with the principles established by the general plan for
land, circulation, community facilities and public utility services and in
accordance with the following general principles.
   (A)   (1)   It is intended that the urban area should be designed as a group
of integrated residential neighborhoods and appropriate commercial and
industrial and public facilities. The neighborhood as a planning unit is
intended as an area principally for residential use, and is of a size that can
be served by one elementary school.
      (2)   Space for religious, recreational, education and shopping
facilities to serve the residents of the neighborhood should be provided and
designed as an integral part of each neighborhood.
   (B)   The size of lots and blocks and other areas for residential,
commercial, industrial and public uses should be designed to provide adequate
light, air, open space, landscaping, off-street parking and loading facilities.
   (C)   The arrangement of lots and blocks and the street system should be
designed to make the most advantageous use of topography and natural physical
features. Tree masses and large individual trees should be preserved. The
system of sidewalks and roadways and the lot layout should be designed to take
advantage of the visual qualities of the area.
   (D)   Circulation within the urban area shall be provided in accordance with
the following design criteria.
      (1)   Each subdivision shall provide for the continuation of all arterial
streets and highways as shown on the major street plan. Arterial streets should
be located on the perimeter of the residential neighborhood.
      (2)   Minor streets should be designed to provide access to each parcel
of land within the residential neighborhood and within industrial areas, and in
a manner that will discourage use by through traffic. They should be planned so
that future urban expansion will not require the conversion of minor streets to
arterial routes.
      (3)   Collector streets should be designed to provide a direct route from
other minor streets to the major street system.
      (4)   Ingress and egress to residential properties should be provided
only on minor streets.
      (5)   Pedestrianways should be separated from roadways used by vehicular
traffic. Sidewalks should be designed to provide all residential building sites
with direct access to all neighborhood facilities, including the elementary
school, parks, playgrounds, churches and shopping centers.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-452 SUBDIVISION DESIGN STANDARDS.
   (A)   The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of
streets shall conform to all of the elements of the general plan and shall be
designed in accordance with the following provisions.
      (1)   Major streets shall be planned to conform with the major street
plan.
      (2)   Whenever a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed
major street, the Planning Commission may require service streets, reverse
frontage with screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation along the
rear property line, deep lots or such other treatment as may be necessary for
adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation of
arterial and local traffic.
      (3)   Minor streets shall be laid out so that their use by arterial
traffic will be discouraged.
      (4)   Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad right-of-way
or limited access highway right-of-way, the Planning Commission may require a
street approximately parallel to, and on each side of such right-of-way at a
distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land. Such
distances also shall be determined with due regard for the requirements of
approach grades and future grade separation structures.
      (5)   Reserve strips controlling access to streets shall be prohibited
except where their control is placed in the city or county under conditions
approved by the Planning Commission.
      (6)   When a tract is subdivided into larger than normal building lots or
parcels, such lots or parcels shall be arranged to permit the logical location
and opening of future streets and appropriate resubdivision with provision for
adequate utility easements.
      (7)   Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet should be
avoided.
      (8)   Street right-of-way widths shall be in accordance with the major
street plan and, where not designated therein, shall be not less than the
following.
Major streets
Primary with median              120 feet
Primary without median           100 feet
Secondary with or without median 80 feet
Minor streets
Collector                        60 feet
Cul-de-sac                       50 feet
Minor                            50 feet
 
      (9)   The grades of all streets shall not exceed the following, except
where unusual topographic conditions justify in the opinion of the Planning
Commission, a modification of these standards.
 
Major streets
Primary                            5%
Secondary                          7%
Minor streets                      10%
No street grade shall be less than 0.5%
 
      (10)   The paved width of all streets shall be adequate to serve the
existing and future terminated traffic load for the facility. Lane widths for
all streets shall be as follows.
         (a)   All major streets shall have lanes for traffic movement of not
less than 11 feet or more than 12 feet in width and lanes for parallel parking
or emergency stopping of not less than ten feet in width.
         (b)   All minor streets shall have lanes for traffic movement of not
less than ten feet or more than 12 feet in width and lanes for parallel parking
of not less than six feet in width.
         (c)   Streets shall conform to the standards illustrated by Figure 1,
design standards for urban streets.
      (11)   A cul-de-sac shall not exceed 500 feet in length, measured from
the nearest point providing two directional through traffic to the center of
the turnaround. If a cul-de-sac is more than 150 feet in length it shall be
provided with a turnaround having a radius of not less than 40 feet at the curb
line. There should be provided in the center of the turnaround an unpaved
island, which has a radius of not less than 12 feet nor more than 25 feet. Any
unpaved island shall be improved with grass and landscaping in such a manner
that it will not interfere with sight distance.
      (12)   Half streets shall be prohibited except where they are essential
to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other
requirements of these regulations, and provided that the Planning Commission
finds it will be practical to obtain the dedication of the other half of the
street easement when the adjoining property is subdivided. Whenever a half
street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other half of the street
shall be platted within such tract.
      (13)   The arrangement of streets shall be such as to cause no hardship
in the subdividing of adjacent properties. The Planning Commission may require
the dedication of street rights-of-way to facilitate the development of
adjoining properties.
      (14)   No street names shall be used which will duplicate or be confused
with the names of existing streets. Street names shall be subject to the
approval of the Planning Commission.
   (B)   Alleys shall be provided in commercial and industrial districts,
except that the Planning Commission may waive this requirement where other
definite and assured provision is made for service access, such as off-street
loading, unloading and parking consistent with that adequate for the uses
proposed.
      (1)   Alleys serving commercial and industrial areas shall not be less
than 30 feet in width.
      (2)   Alley intersections and sharp changes in alignment should be
avoided; but where necessary, corners shall be cut off sufficiently to permit
safe vehicular movement.
      (3)   Dead end alleys should be avoided; but where necessary, facilities
at the dead end may be permitted, as determined by the Planning Commission.
   (C)   (1)   Where alleys are not provided, easements for public and private
utilities shall be provided along rear lot lines and side lot lines where
necessary.
      (2)   Easements along rear and side lot lines shall be, wherever
possible, centered along the lot lines with a total width of 20 feet. Where
appropriate, the Planning Commission may allow easements with a minimum width
of 15 feet.
      (3)   The Planning Commission may require aerial easements and easements
of greater width for the extension of main storm and sanitary sewers and other
utilities where it is deemed necessary.
   (D)   (1)   Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainage
channel or stream, which drains 160 acres or more of land, there shall be
provided a right-of-way for drainage and public parks and public utility
purposes, adequate to contain all of the runoff from a 50-year maximum flood.
      (2)   The right-of-way shall include all of the land within the
subdivision that has an elevation that will remain below the 50-year maximum
flood elevation which shall be calculated in accordance with, and shall be
adequate to provide for, the drainage requirements of the ordinances and
regulations relating thereto.
   (E)   Public parks, playgrounds, school sites and other public areas and
open spaces shall be provided in accordance with the requirements and standards
set forth in the general plan and in the ordinances and regulations relating
thereto.
   (F)   Where a sketch plat contains an area reserved for public use, in
accordance with this section, the Planning Commission shall refer such sketch
plat, with recommendations, to the governing body for resolution of the
governing body’s intent to accept such dedication in accordance with the
ordinances and regulations relating thereto.
   (G)   Where the proposed public area or open space is rejected by the
governing body, the subdivider shall revise the sketch plat so as to
incorporate the area into the lots and blocks of the proposed subdivision and
submit the revised sketch plat to the Planning Commission.
   (H)   The lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due
regard for the following:
      (1)   The subdivision of lots so as to back onto the primary arterial and
front onto a parallel local street; no access shall be provided from the
arterial, and screening shall be provided in a strip of land along the rear
property line of such lots;
      (2)   A series of cul-de-sacs, U-shaped streets or short loops entered
from and designed generally at right angles to such a parallel street, with the
rear lines of their terminal lots backing onto the major arterial; and
      (3)   A marginal access or service road (separated from the primary
arterial by a planting or grass strip and having access thereto at suitable
points).
   (I)   Residential lots, with the exception of townhouses, shall not be less
than 50 feet in width at the front building line and shall abut a street a
distance of not less than 30 feet; except that a corner lot shall be not less
than 60 feet in width at the front building line.
   (J)   Side lot lines should be approximately at right angles or radial to
street lines.
   (K)   The depth of residential lots should be not less than 120 feet
exclusive of any drainage easement.
   (L)   The area of a residential lot, exclusive of townhouse development,
shall not be less than 6,000 square feet.
   (M)   (1)   In residential subdivisions where septic tank or individual
sewage disposal devices are to be installed, the area of the lot shall be not
less than 22,500 square feet if to be served by public water, or 35,000 square
feet if to be served by a private water source.
      (2)   In no case shall a lot served by an individual sewage disposal
system have a width of less than 120 feet at the front building line.
   (N)   Lots are not required for subdivisions for commercial and industrial
use but, when provided, they should be of appropriate size and arrangement to
provide for adequate off-street parking and loading facilities based on the
intended use.
   (O)   Double frontage and reverse frontage lots should be avoided except
where they are needed to provide for the separation of development from
arterial streets or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and
orientation. A planting screen easement of at least 20 feet in width shall be
provided along the portion of the lots abutting such a traffic artery or other
use where screening is required. There shall be no right of access across a
planting screen easement.
   (P)   Building lines shall be provided for all residential subdivisions as
follows.
      (1)   A front building line shall be located at least 25 feet back of the
street right-of-way line.
      (2)   A side yard building line on the side of a corner lot abutting the
street shall be located not less than 15 feet back of the street right-of-way
when such lot is back-to-back with another corner lot and not less than 20 feet
back of the street right-of-way line in every other case.
      (3)   A side yard building line shall be provided not less than five feet
back of a crosswalk right-of-way or easement line on the side of a lot abutting
a midblock crosswalk.
      (4)   Restrictions requiring buildings to be located within the building
lines shown on the plat shall be set forth on the plat or on a separate
recorded instrument.
   (Q)   (1)   Whenever a subdivision is developed as a planned unit
development under the provisions of the zoning regulations, wherein adequate
park or playground area is provided, through traffic is cared for adequately
and the majority of the minor streets are of the cul-de-sac or loop type, the
Planning Commission may vary the requirements of this article in order to allow
the subdivider more freedom in the arrangement of streets and lots, but at the
same time protect the convenience, health, safety and welfare of the entire
community.
      (2)   However, in no case shall the gross density, intensity of use or
land area coverage for the planned unit development exceed those minimums
established in the zoning regulations.
   (R)   For purposes of platting a planned unit development, the site
development plan as required by the zoning regulations, may at the Planning
Commission’s discretion, be considered as the sketch plat and shall substitute
for the preliminary plat when bearing all information required for a
preliminary plat.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
ARTICLE E. SPECIFICATIONS FOR DOCUMENTS
§12-460 SKETCH PLAT.
   Sketch plats submitted to the Planning Commission shall be prepared in pen
or pencil, neatly drawn at a convenient scale of not more than 100 feet to one
inch and shall bear the following information:
   (A)   Name and ownership;
   (B)   Name of the proposed subdivision;
   (C)   Name, address and telephone number of the legal owner or agent of
property owner and citation of last instrument conveying title to the owner;
   (D)   Citation of any rights-of-way or easements affecting the property;
   (E)   Name, address and telephone number of person(s) responsible for the
subdivision design;
   (F)   Full legal description of property by government lot, section,
township, range and county, graphic scale, north arrow and date; and
   (G)   Contents of sketch plat:
      (1)   The location of adjoining property lines, intersecting or adjacent
streets, alleys or easements; provided however, the actual measured distances
shall not be required;
      (2)   Land contours with vertical intervals not greater than five feet
referenced to a United States geological survey or coast and geodetic survey
benchmark or monument;
      (3)   The length of the boundaries of the tract, measured to the nearest
foot, the proposed location of streets, alleys, easements and approximate lot
dimensions;
      (4)   The location of all drainage channels and proposed drainage
structures and easements or rights-of-way; and
      (5)   The location and approximate size of any proposed open spaces
whether private or proposed public dedications.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-461 PRELIMINARY PLAT.
   (A)   Preliminary plats submitted to the Planning Commission shall be
prepared in pen or pencil, neatly drawn at a convenient scale of not more than
100 feet to one inch and shall bear or be accompanied by a statement signed by
a registered land surveyor in the state and a registered engineer in the state
certifying that he, she or they have (has), to the best of his, her or their
ability, designed the subdivision in accordance with the general plan and the
ordinances and regulations governing the subdivision of land and provision of
public improvements, except where an exception is requested in writing and the
reasons for which are clearly stated.
   (B)   Contents of preliminary plat shall be as follows:
      (1)   The proposed name of the subdivision;
      (2)   The name and address of the owner of record, of the subdivider, of
the registered surveyor responsible for subdivision design and of the
registered engineer responsible for improvement plans;
      (3)   A key map showing the location of the proposed subdivision
referenced to existing or proposed major streets and to government section
lines, and including the boundaries and number of acres of the drainage area of
which the proposed subdivision is a part;
      (4)   The scale, north point and date;
      (5)   The names, with location of intersecting boundary lines, or
adjoining subdivisions, and the location of city limits, if falling within or
immediately adjoining the tract;
      (6)   The land contours with vertical intervals not greater than two feet
referenced to a United States geological survey or coast and geodetic survey
benchmark or monument;
      (7)   The location of existing buildings, water, watercourses and the
location of dedicated streets at the point where they adjoin or are immediately
adjacent to the subdivision; provided, however, that actual measured distances
shall not be required;
      (8)   The length of the boundaries of the tract, measured to the nearest
foot, the proposed location and width of streets, alleys, easements and setback
lines and the approximate lot dimensions;
      (9)   The location, approximate size and type of sanitary and storm
sewers, water mains, culverts, power and natural gas lines and other surface
and subsurface structures and pipelines existing within or immediately adjacent
to the proposed subdivision; and the location, layout, type and proposed size
of the following structures and utilities:
         (a)   Water mains;
         (b)   Sanitary sewer mains, submains and laterals;
         (c)   Storm sewers, culverts and drainage structures; and
         (d)   Street improvements.
      (10)   The location of all drainage channels and subsurface drainage
structures, the proposed methods of disposing of all runoff from the proposed
subdivision and the location and size of all drainage easements relating
thereto whether they are located within or outside of the proposed plat; and
      (11)   The classification of every street within or adjacent to the
subdivision in accordance with the intended use of the street based on the
proposed design. This shall be done by placing the appropriate term,
expressway, primary thoroughfare, secondary thoroughfare, collector or minor
street in parentheses, directly on each street.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-462 FINAL PLAT.
   (A)   (1)   The final plat shall be neatly drawn in ink on tracing cloth or
reproducible Mylar at a scale of at least 100 feet to the inch from an accurate
survey and shall comply with the following format: The final plat shall be
prepared on sheets whose dimensions are 24 by 36 inches.
      (2)   The plat shall have a left side margin of two inches; right side
margin of not less than one inch; and top and bottom margins of not less than
one and one-half inches. On the first sheet of every plat there shall be a map
showing the location of the subdivision referenced to government survey section
lines and major streets. If more than two sheets are required for the plat, the
key map shall show the number of the sheet for each area.
   (B)   The final plat shall bear the following information:
      (1)   The location and description of all section corners and permanent
survey monuments in or near the tract, to at least one of which the subdivision
shall be referenced;
      (2)   The length of all required lines dimensioned in feet and decimals
thereof and the value of all required true bearings and angles dimensioned in
degrees and minutes as hereafter specified;
      (3)   The boundary lines of the land being subdivided fully dimensioned
by lengths and bearings, the location of boundary lines of adjoining lands and
adjacent subdivisions identified by official names. Material which is not a
part of the subdivision shall be shown in dashed or dotted lines;
      (4)   The lines of all proposed streets fully dimensioned by lengths and
bearings or angles;
      (5)   The lines of all proposed alleys. Where the length or direction of
an alley is not readily discernible from data given for lot and block lines,
the length or bearing shall be given;
      (6)   The widths, and names where appropriate, of all proposed streets
and alleys, and of all adjacent streets, alleys and easements which shall be
properly located;
      (7)   The lines of all proposed lots fully dimensioned by lengths and
bearings or angles; except where a lot line meets a street line at right
angles, the angle or bearing value be omitted;
      (8)   The outline of any property which is offered for dedication to
public use fully dimensioned by lengths and bearings, with the area marked
public;
      (9)   The blocks numbered consecutively throughout the entire
subdivision, the lots numbered consecutively throughout each block and with
areas to be excluded from platting marked “Reserved” or “Not a Part”;
      (10)   The location of all building lines, setback lines and easements
for public services or utilities with dimensions showing their locations;
      (11)   The radii, arcs, points of tangency, points of intersection and
central angles for curvilinear streets and radii for all property returns;
      (12)   The proper acknowledgments of owners and the consent of the
mortgagee to plat restrictions;
      (13)   The following, which shall be made and shown on the cloth tracing:
         (a)   Owner’s certificate and dedication, signed;
         (b)   Surveyor’s certificate of survey, signed and his or her seal;
         (c)   Certificate for release of mortgage for any portion dedicated to
the public, signed;
         (d)   Reference to any separate instruments, including restrictive
covenants, filed in the office of the county recorder of deeds which directly
affect the land being subdivided;
         (e)   Certificate of Planning Commission approval;
         (f)   Certificate of City Council or Board acceptance of ways,
easements and public land dedications;
         (g)   Treasurer’s certificate; and
         (h)   Certificate of Health Department approval where sanitary sewers
are not proposed, signed.
      (14)   A title which shall include:
         (a)   Name of the subdivision;
         (b)   Name of city, county and state; and
         (c)   Location and description of the subdivision referenced to
section, range and township.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-463 IMPROVEMENT PLANS.
   (A)   Construction plans as required in these regulations shall be prepared
for all required improvements. Plans shall be drawn at a scale of not more than
one inch equals 100 feet on sheets of 24 inches by 36 inches.
   (B)   Plans for required improvements shall comply with all standards and
specifications adopted by ordinance or resolution by the governing body.
   (C)   Improvement plans shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
      (1)   Plans and profiles showing the locations and typical cross-section
of proposed street improvements including curbs and gutters and sidewalks;
      (2)   The location, size, profile and invert elevations of proposed
sanitary sewers, including manholes;
      (3)   The location and size of proposed water mains, valves, fittings and
fire hydrants, including service taps underneath proposed streets;
      (4)   The location and design of drainage structures, easements or
rights-of-way dedicated to the public including typical cross-sections of all
channel improvements and a site grading plan. Improvement plans shall be
accompanied by drainage calculations in accordance with the adopted standards
and regulations for drainage improvements; and
      (5)   The location of all existing or proposed easements and rights-of-
way and a typical cross-section of the proposed utility installations with the
easements.
   (D)   Improvement plans shall be prepared by and bear the seal of a
registered engineer in the state.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)

ARTICLE A. GENERAL PROVISIONS
§12-501 APPLICATION.
   Any person who develops or subdivides any residential, multi-family
dwellings, commercial, industrial or institutional property within the scope of
the subdivision regulations of the City/County Planning Commission, as adopted
by the city, shall provide and install the required public improvements in
accordance with the standards and specifications enumerated herein.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-502 ADMINISTRATION.
   (A)   The standards and specifications contained herein shall be deemed an
addendum to and shall be administered in conjunction with the subdivision
regulations of the City/County Planning Commission. It is the duty and
responsibility of the City Engineer to review all improvement plans, as
required by the subdivision regulations, for compliance with the standards and
specifications contained herein.
   (B)   Improvement plans shall be approved by the governing body as specified
in
Chapter 4, Article C of this part.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-503 VARIANCES FROM STANDARDS.
   (A)   Where, by reasons of exceptional topographic, hydrologic or other
physical features, the strict compliance with the standards prescribed herein
shall be inappropriate, the developer may submit a written request for a
variance in these improvement standards.
   (B)   Any request for a variance in these improvement standards shall be
submitted to the City Engineer and shall specify the conditions necessitating
such request and the proposed alternative improvement.
   (C)   Upon adequate review, the City Engineer shall make a report and
recommendation on the requested variance. Such report shall be submitted to the
Planning Commission for recommendation to the City Council.
   (D)   The Planning Commission’s recommendation and the Engineer’s report
shall be transmitted to the City Council, for final action. Any Council action
to approve such a request shall specify the nature and extent of the variance
and the nature and type of improvements to be provided by the developer.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
ARTICLE B. STREET IMPROVEMENTS
§12-510 GENERAL.
   (A)   All street improvements shall be designed in conformance with the
provisions of the subdivision regulations.
   (B)   In addition, the design, layout and construction of all streets within
the city shall conform to the design and construction specifications herein.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-512 DESIGN.
   Streets shall conform in design and layout to the criteria established in §
12-520, Table 1, “Street Design Standards For The City of Duncan,” of this
chapter.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-513 TYPICAL SECTIONS.
   (A)   Concrete streets shall be constructed in accordance with the diagram
contained in §
12-520, Table 2, “Typical Section For Concrete Streets,” of this chapter.
   (B)   Asphalt streets shall be constructed in accordance with the diagram
contained in §
12-520, Table 3, “Typical Section For Asphalt Streets,” of this chapter.
   (C)   Residential estate streets shall be constructed in accordance with the
diagram contained in §
12-520, Table 4, “Typical Section For Residential Estate Streets,” of this
chapter.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-514 STREET INTERSECTIONS.
   (A)   Streets shall be laid out to intersect at right angles and may be
curved, if necessary, in order to make this possible. In no event shall a
street intersect any other street at any angle of less than 75 degrees.
   (B)   Street corners on local streets shall have a minimum radius of 25 feet
at the curb line. Street intersections involving major streets shall have a
minimum street corner radius of 30 feet at the curb line.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§12-515 COMPLIANCE WITH STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS.
   All street construction shall be in compliance with the standard street
construction specifications of the city. Contracts for such construction of
public streets shall include, in whole or by reference, the provisions of the
city’s standard street construction specifications. There shall be no variance
from these specifications unless approved in writing by the City Engineer.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
ARTICLE C. SANITARY SEWER IMPROVEMENTS
§12-520 GENERAL.
   Where sanitary sewage facilities are required in conjunction with the
development or subdivision of land, the subdivider shall install the facilities
in a manner prescribed by the standard specifications for sanitary sewers for
the city, which shall be incorporated, in whole or by reference, into all
contracts for such work. All improvements shall be designed in accordance with
the rules, regulations and standards of the local government, the local
government engineer, the State Department of Health and other appropriate
agencies. All sanitary sewer improvements shall be designed by an engineer
registered in the state.

   3.   Curbs shall be 6 inches in height and conform to the typical curb section
as approved by the local government engineer.
   4.   Street shall slope from the centerline to curb at 1/4 fall per foot.
   5.   Detailed specifications available from local government engineer.

(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977; Ord. 1354, passed 8-9-1994)
§ 12-521 COMPLIANCE WITH THE FACILITIES PLAN.
   A sanitary sewer main improvement shall correspond with the city’s sanitary
sewer facilities plan or other approved sanitary sewer report or document, and
the improvement shall be designed in accordance with the facilities plan or
approved report. Any sanitary sewer main extension shall extend the entire
frontage of the property proposed for development as identified in the
facilities plan or report. When the improvement required by the facilities plan
exceeds the capacity needed to serve the proposed development, the city may
participate in the excess cost of such facility in accordance with the
provisions of §§ 12-901 et seq.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977; Ord. 1354, passed 8-9-1994; Ord. 1610, passed 10-
25-2005)
§ 12-522 MINIMUM SIZE.
   The minimum size of a public sanitary sewer shall be eight inches in
diameter.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§ 12-523 DESIGN CRITERIA.
   (A)   All sewers shall be laid with straight alignment between manholes,
unless otherwise directed or approved by the local government engineer.
   (B)   Manholes shall be installed at all changes in grade, size or
alignment; at all intersections; and at distances not greater than 400 feet for
sanitary sewers of less than ten inches in diameter; and 500 feet for sanitary
sewers of ten inches in diameter and larger.
   (C)   Manhole construction shall conform to the standard specifications for
manhole construction as prepared by the local government engineer. Any
variation from this standard shall require the approval of the local government
engineer.
   (D)   (1)   Lampholes and cleanouts shall not be allowed on sanitary sewer
lines in excess of 200 feet in length, measured from the nearest manhole. Sewer
lines in excess of 200 feet shall be terminated with a manhole.
      (2)   Lampholes and cleanouts shall be constructed in conformance with
the standard plans and specifications as prepared by the local government
engineer.
   (E)   Sanitary sewers shall be located in street or alley rights-of-way or
utility easements:
      (1)   When located in utility easements, manholes shall be located at
each street or alley crossing;
      (2)   When located in a street or alley right-of-way containing a public
water supply, sanitary sewers shall be on the opposite side of the right-of-way
from the water supply whenever possible; and
      (3)   Sanitary sewers in street or alley rights-of-way shall have a
minimum cover of not less than six feet.
   (F)   A minimum horizontal distance of ten feet shall be maintained between
parallel water and sewer mains. At points where sewers cross water mains, the
sewer shall be constructed of cast iron pipe or encased in concrete for a
distance of ten feet in each direction from the crossing, measured
perpendicular to the water line. This will not be required when the water main
is at least two feet above the sewer.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§ 12-524 MATERIALS.
   Sanitary sewer improvements shall be constructed of approved materials
meeting the following specifications:
   (A)   Clay sewer pipe: ASTM C13, standard strength or C200, extra strength;
   (B)   Cast iron pipe: AWWA class 22;
   (C)   PVC: ASTM D3034, SDR 35;
   (D)   Cement: ASTM C150-52, class 1;
   (E)   Mortar sand: Section 703, standard specifications for highway
construction (Oklahoma, 1959); and
   (F)   Brick: ASTM C62-50.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977; Ord. 1311, passed 6-11-1991)
ARTICLE D. WATER MAIN IMPROVEMENTS
§ 12-530 GENERAL.
   Wherever the extension of public water mains is required or proposed in
conjunction with the development or subdivision of land, the developer shall
make provision for such extension in compliance with the standards contained
herein, and the standard specifications for water line construction of the
city. The standard specifications shall be made a part, in whole or by
reference, of any contract for the installation and construction of any water
main to be connected to the public water supply. In addition, all water main
extensions shall comply with the regulations of the State Department of Health
and other appropriate agencies.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§ 12-531 IMPROVEMENTS REQUIRED.
   The developer of land shall provide and install water mains, fire hydrants
and all necessary valves and fittings. The cost of these improvements shall be
borne by the developer except as provided in §
12-532.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§ 12-532 COMPLIANCE WITH WATER PLAN.
   (A)   A water main improvement shall correspond to improvements contained in
the latest water distribution system development plan or map, and the developer
shall provide water mains in compliance with the provisions of that plan or
map. Any water main extension shall extend the entire frontage of the property
proposed for development as identified in the latest water distribution system
plan or map.
   (B)   Whenever compliance with the water distribution system development
plan requires a water main in excess of that needed to serve the proposed
development, the city may participate in any excess costs imposed by such
compliance in accordance with the provisions of §§
12-909 et seq.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977; Ord. 1354, passed 8-9-1994; Ord. 1610, passed 10-
25-2005)
§ 12-533 WATER MAIN DESIGN CRITERIA.
   In order to facilitate the development of an adequate water distribution
system, the following standards will be applied to water main extensions.
   (A)   Major trunk lines (generally along section line roads) shall be
minimum of 12 inches in diameter unless otherwise specified in the water
distribution development plan.
   (B)   Secondary lines (generally along or approximate to quarter section
lines) shall be a minimum of eight inches in diameter.
   (C)   All other water mains shall be a minimum of six inches in diameter.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§ 12-534 FIRE HYDRANTS.
   Fire hydrants shall be required for all water main extensions. Fire hydrants
shall be located within 300 feet of any lot or structure, measured along the
shortest public roadway route from the nearest hydrant. Hydrants and
installation shall comply with the specifications in the standard
specifications for water line construction as prepared by the local government
engineer.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§ 12-535 TAPS.
   (A)   Minimum service tap shall be a three-fourths inch tap. Where to be
installed on the opposite side of a street from the water main, a single three-
fourths inch or larger tap shall be installed under the roadbed for each lot or
tract prior to surfacing the roadway.
   (B)   Where existing streets are to be crossed, taps shall be bored
underneath the street in all possible instances.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977)
§ 12-536 MATERIALS.
   (A)   All public water mains and all mains attached or proposed to be
attached to the public water supply shall be constructed of PVC pipe or ductile
iron pipe or both and shall be manufactured in accordance with the following
standards: Most current federal specifications published at the time building
permits are requested, at the time any federal, state, county or municipal
project plans and/or requests are provided to the City Engineer or engineer
retained by the city. Specifications referred to herein shall apply to both PVC
and ductile iron. If specifications shall change after the projects referred to
herein are approved, then the specifications used shall be those published at
the time of approval. This division (A) shall supersede all prior code
sections.
   (B)   Nominal wall thickness, joint types, valves, fittings and
appurtenances shall comply with the specifications in the city’s standard
specifications for water line construction as prepared by the local government
engineer.
(Res. 901, passed 5-10-1977; Ord. 1707, passed 2-28-2012)
