   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. §§ 29-101 et seq.
ARTICLE A. GENERAL PROVISIONS
§13-201 FIRE DEPARTMENT CREATED, CHIEF.
   (A)   There is hereby created a Fire Department, the head of which is the
Chief of the Fire Department or Fire Chief, appointed by the City Manager for
an indefinite term.
   (B)   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      CHIEF. The Chief of the Fire Department.
      DEPARTMENT. The Fire Department of the city.
§13-202 FIRE CHIEF.
   (A)   (1)   The Chief shall be at the head of the Department, subject to the
laws of the state, ordinances of this city and this chapter.
      (2)   The Chief shall be held responsible for the general condition and
efficient operation of the Department, the training of members and the
performance of all other duties imposed upon him or her.
   (B)   He or she shall have the following duties:
      (1)   To ensure that all Department members are trained in the latest and
updated technical aspects of firefighting;
      (2)   To inspect, or cause to be inspected by members of the Department,
the fire hydrants, cisterns and other sources of water supply at least once
each year and other establishments or premises in the city as determined;
      (3)   To maintain a library or file of publications on fire prevention
and fire protection and make use of it to the best advantage of all members of
the Department;
      (4)   To see that each fire is carefully investigated to determine its
cause, and in the case of suspicion of incendiarism, notify proper authorities
and secure and preserve all possible evidence for future use in the case;
      (5)   To direct firefighting operations and make every effort to attend
all major fires; and
      (6)   (a)   To file the appropriate activity report forms with the office
of the State Fire Marshal in Oklahoma City on an annual basis.
         (b)   The activity report forms shall be designed by the State Fire
Marshal and shall include, but not be limited to, the amount of property and
vehicle fire loss, types of fires, inspections and investigations.
         (c)   The report shall include notification of all fire-related
civilian deaths and injuries in the respective jurisdiction and of firefighter
deaths in the line of duty and of firefighter injuries in the line of duty
requiring the services of a hospital or physician or both.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 74 O.S. § 314
§13-203 ADDITIONAL DUTIES AND POWERS OF FIRE CHIEF.
   The Chief shall have full power and command over all persons at fires and
may adopt any measures that he or she shall deem most advisable to extinguish
fires, or for the care and protection of property endangered thereby, and shall
have power to summon any and all persons present to his or her aid in
extinguishing any fire or caring for personal property in case of fire.
§13-204 DUTIES.
   It is the duty of the Fire Department, among others, to extinguish fires; to
rescue persons endangered by fire; to resuscitate, and to administer first aid
to, persons injured in or about burning structures or elsewhere in case of an
emergency; to promote fire prevention; and, unless otherwise provided, to
enforce all ordinances relating to fires, fire prevention and safety of persons
from fire and explosions in theaters, stores and other public buildings.
§13-205 USE OF FIRE EQUIPMENT, INVENTORY.
   (A)   No person shall use any fire apparatus or equipment for any private
purpose, nor shall any person willfully and without proper authority take away
or conceal any article used in any way by the Department. No person shall
handle any apparatus or equipment belonging to the Department unless authorized
by the Chief.
   (B)   The Chief shall prepare and keep a complete inventory of all property
belonging to the Fire Department and shall at the expiration of his or her term
turn over such inventory and all such property to his or her successor,
together with all books, records, reports and data of the Department.
§13-206 INTERFERENCE WITH DEPARTMENT.
   It is unlawful for any person to interfere with the Fire Department or any
officer or employee thereof in the proper discharge of its or his or her
official duties.
ARTICLE B. SERVICE OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS
§13-221 AUTHORITY AND DUTY TO RENDER.
   (A)   The Fire Department is hereby authorized and empowered to render fire
protection, fire prevention and rescue operations for individuals, firms,
private corporations or associations or political subdivisions of the state
located outside the corporate limits of the city and to provide fire protection
jointly with other organizations and municipal subdivisions of the state.
   (B)   The Fire Department is authorized to answer calls outside the city
limits unless, in the discretion of the Fire Chief or his or her designees:
      (1)   The fire equipment is in use within the city limits to the extent
that it is unwise to send equipment or personnel to answer calls beyond the
city limits;
      (2)   It would be unwise to answer such calls because of broken
equipment, impassable or dangerous highways or other physical conditions or
city policies; or
      (3)   It would not be to the best interest of the city because of lack of
manpower.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. §§ 29-106 through 29-108
§13-222 CHARGES.
   (A)   Any contract for fire protection or prevention services to be rendered
by the Fire Department for an individual owner, firm, private corporation or
association outside the city limits shall provide for payment to the city at a
rate per hour as set by the Council by motion or resolution for time away from
the fire station per call.
   (B)   Such rate shall be charged for each piece of equipment, such as fire
truck, engine, hose wagon, ladder wagon or any other piece of equipment
furnished by the city.
   (C)   All monies received from such calls shall go into the General Fund of
the city, to be used for operation and maintenance of the city government.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. §§ 29-106 through 29-108
§13-223 RECALL OF APPARATUS.
   The Fire Department shall be empowered to recall any or all fire apparatus
which is outside the city limits pursuant to this provision at any time, if in
the judgment of the officer in charge, it is wise and expedient to do so for
the further protection of property within the city limits, regardless of
whether the outside fire is extinguished or not, and in such case, the city
shall not be responsible for failure of the Fire Department to completely
extinguish the fire.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. §§ 29-106 through 29-108
§13-224 FIREFIGHTERS CONSIDERED AS SERVING IN REGULAR LINE OF DUTY.
   (A)   All firefighters of the Fire Department attending and serving at fires
or doing fire prevention work or rescue work outside the corporate limits of
the city as provided for in this article shall be considered as serving in
their regular line of duty as fully as if they were serving within the
corporate limits of the city.
   (B)   Such firefighters shall be entitled to all the benefits of any pension
and relief fund in the same manner as if the firefighting or fire prevention or
rescue operation was being done within the corporate limits of the city.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. §§ 28-107 and 29-106 through 29-108
§13-225 DEPARTMENT CONSIDERED AGENT OF STATE ACTING IN GOVERNMENTAL CAPACITY.
   The Fire Department, when answering any fire alarm or call or performing any
fire prevention service or rescue operation outside the corporate limits of the
city pursuant to the provisions of this article, shall be considered an agent
of the state and acting solely and alone in a governmental capacity, and the
city shall not be liable in damages for any act of commission, omission or
negligence while answering or returning from any fire or reported fire, or
doing any fire prevention work or rescue operation under and by virtue of this
article.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. §§ 29-106 through 29-108
ARTICLE C. OPEN BURNING
§13-230 BURNING PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION, FEE.
   (A)   No person, firm or corporation shall set fire to or burn any trees,
brush, grass and other vegetable matter in the clearing of land for
agricultural crop management or land development without having obtained a
permit therefor from the Fire Chief or his or her designated representative.
Application for permit shall be made on such form as specified by the Fire
Chief upon payment to the office of the City Clerk of an application fee as set
by the City Council.
   (B)   Persons with ownership of property the size of which is an individual
lot of five acres or more desires to conduct and burn of vegetation may apply
for a two-week open burn permit. Application for permit shall be made on such
form as specified by the Fire Chief upon payment to the office of the City
Clerk of an application fee as established by the City Council and the
inspection of the burn site by the Fire Chief or his or her designee.
   (C)   Additional burn sites may be applied for, on the same tract of land
upon payment of application fee as established by the City Council for each
additional burning site, however only one burn site is allowable per five acres
and must be at least 500 feet from the nearest residence, business structure
and neighboring property other than the property on which the burning is to be
conducted. The burn sites must also be 500 feet from all other burn sites when
issued more than one permit for the purpose of more than five acres.
   (D)   If the applicant has a substantial amount of trees, brush or grass to
burn off then the city will send a brush truck for standby upon the applicant’s
request. However the applicant must pay a minimum of eight hours’ usage fee for
a brush truck and three personnel at the current rate. If the brush
accumulation is larger than the required dimensions of a burn fuel site a pit
will be required to burn the fuel in. The size or amount of the fuel at the
burn site will determine what can be burned at the discretion of the Fire Chief
or designee. Therefore, item 7 of the open burn permit can be the only item
excluded.
(Ord. 1712, passed 11-12-2012)
§13-231 CONDITIONS APPLICABLE TO BURNING PERMITS FOR DEVELOPMENT AND
AGRICULTURE.
   The burning of trees, brush, grass and other vegetable matter shall be
permitted only for the clearing of land for development and agricultural
management and in compliance with the following conditions.
   (A)   General written standards shall be established by the Fire Chief
providing for fire safety and site maintenance. The Fire Chief or his or her
designee may invalidate any permit if written fire safety and maintenance
standards are not met or if the Fire Department responds to an uncontrollable
fire due to burning at a permitted site on the property.
   (B)   Burning will not be allowed when wind is over ten mph.
   (C)   There must be 20 feet of protective clearance area around the burn
site.
   (D)   Burning time is from one hour after sunrise to three hours before
sunset and additional fuel may not be intentionally added to the fire at times
outside the limits stated above.
   (E)   Fire extinguishing equipment must be on the premises at each burning
site, during burning, i.e., extinguisher, buckets of water, water hose and the
like. Any open burning shall be constantly attended until the fire is
extinguished.
   (F)   The burning permit will be valid for 14 calendar days beginning the
day it was issued.
   (G)   (1)   Size of burn. Size of the burn site fuel shall not be larger
than ten feet wide by ten feet in length by ten feet high, from ground surface.
Upon request of a land developer and for good cause shown the burn permit may
allow a burn pit of 15 feet wide by 15 feet in length by ten feet high,
however, there must be at least two individuals present to monitor the burn.
      (2)   Subdivisions and land developers. Persons clearing and developing
land for residential or commercial purposes upon obtaining a burn permit shall
be allowed to have a burn site on every five acres consisting of three pits not
larger than 20 feet wide by 20 feet in length by 20 feet high, so long as the
following conditions are complied with.
         (a)   Each pit is 100 feet from other pits.
         (b)   There must be a minimum of 200 feet of clearance from any
structure, improvement or adjacent property lines.
         (c)   A bulldozer and tanker truck must be on site with two full-time
employees/workers monitoring the burn at all times.
         (d)   Subdivisions and land developers clearing property on 15 acres
or larger may utilize burn piles. However, the same restrictions will apply for
each five acre tracts with the exception that one bulldozer will be required
for each 15-acre tract.
   (H)   The location of burning must be at least 500 feet from all residences
or any business structures other than those located on the property on which
the burning is conducted.
   (I)   Any petroleum-based product or similar materials which produce
unreasonable amounts of air contaminants may not be burned. If the burning is
offensive or a nuisance due to smoke or odor emissions the permit holder must
extinguish immediately.
   (J)   The Fire Chief, or designated representative, shall inspect the site
of the proposed burning in the presence of the applicant and may make such
requirements as necessary and appropriate to prevent the spread of any
permitted burning, including, but not limited to, provision of firebreaks as a
condition of permit approval. In the event that such conditions are provided,
verification of compliance shall be a condition of approval to proceed as
required below.
   (K)   The holder of the burn permit must provide to the city with (at the
time the permit is issued) a $10,000 permit bond or verification of liability
insurance in an amount of not less than $100,000, with said bond or insurance
being subject to lien for any and all damages resulting from said open burning
permit.
   (L)   Any person that violates any provisions contained within this section
can be prosecuted in the municipal court within the city. Any person convicted
of violating any provision in this section may be fined as provided in §
1-108.
(Ord. 1713, passed 12-11-2012)
§13-232 NOTICE AND APPROVAL TO PROCEED.
   The holder of a burn permit(s) shall contact the communication center and
have them inform the shift commander on each and every day of proposed burning
and shall not proceed with said burning unless the shift commander verifies the
prevailing wind direction and speed as appropriate to any terms and conditions
set forth in the permit.
(Ord. 1675, passed 5-26-2009)
§13-233 SPECIAL EVENTS.
   When there is a special event that would involve outdoor burning such as a
bonfire or an outdoor recreational fire, the guidelines will be specifically
for the special event. Stipulations include a pit or small retaining wall that
will be used as the perimeter for the burn site. This will be for a one-time
burn event. The permit holder will be completely responsible for any and all
damage caused by the fire.
   (A)   Bonfires.
      (1)   Cannot be larger than eight feet wide, eight feet in length and
eight feet high.
      (2)   Must be at least 50 feet from a structure other than those located
on the property and five feet from combustible material.
   (B)   Recreational fires.
      (1)   Cannot be larger than three feet wide, three feet in length and two
feet high.
      (2)   Must be at least 15 feet from a structure other than those located
on the property and three feet from combustible material.
   (C)   Extinguishment.
      (1)   Fires shall be constantly attended until the fire is extinguished.
The minimum of one portable fire extinguisher, not less than a 4-A rating or
other approved extinguishment such as dirt, sand, water barrel, garden hose or
water truck, shall always be available at the site.
      (2)   If for any reason the smoke or odor emissions become a nuisance or
offensive the permit holder must extinguish immediately.
   (D)   Permit fee. No cost.
(Ord. 1675, passed 5-26-2009)
§13-234 PENALTY.
   Any person who violates any provision of this article, or terms of an
approved burn permit shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction
thereof, shall be punished by a fine of $750.
(Ord. 1675, passed 5-26-2009)
CHAPTER 3: POLICE DEPARTMENT
Section
   
13-301   Police Department created; Chief
   
13-302   Duties
   
13-303   Not to mistreat or interfere with police dogs
   
13-304   Mutual aid agreements
§13-301 POLICE DEPARTMENT CREATED; CHIEF.
   There is a Police Department, the head of which is the Chief of Police,
appointed by the City Manager for an indefinite term. The Chief of Police is an
officer of the city and has supervision and control of the Police Department.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. §§ 34-101 et seq.
§13-302 DUTIES.
   It is the duty of the Police Department to apprehend and arrest on view or
on warrant and bring to justice all violators of the ordinances of the city and
the charter; to suppress all riots, affrays and unlawful assemblies which may
come to their knowledge and generally to keep the peace; to serve all warrants,
writs, executions and other processes properly directed and delivered to them;
to apprehend and arrest persons violating federal or state law as provided by
law, and to turn them over to proper authorities; and in all respects to
perform all duties pertaining to the offices of police officers.
§13-303 NOT TO MISTREAT OR INTERFERE WITH POLICE DOGS.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously torture,
torment, beat, kick, strike, injure, disable or kill any dog used by the Police
Department of the city in the performance of the functions or duties of such
Department, or to interfere with or meddle with any such dog while being used
by the Department or any officer or member.
   (B)   Any person violating any provision of this section shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor.
§13-304 MUTUAL AID AGREEMENTS.
   Approval is given for service of members of the regular Police Department of
this city as police officers of any other city or town in an emergency
situation in the state, not more than 100 miles distant from this city, when
such service is requested by the Mayor or Chief of Police of the city or town.
Requests for service under this section shall be made in writing or by
telephone, or other means of communication, to the Mayor or City Manager, who,
if he or she determines that the request can be granted consistently with the
continuance of the proper police protection to the inhabitants of this city,
shall direct the Chief of Police to furnish the number of officers requested
and to arrange for their transportation to the requesting municipality.
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. § 34-103
CHAPTER 4: EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM
Section
   
13-401   Definitions
   
13-402   Plan development; agreement with county
   
13-403   City authority
   
13-404   Nonliability of city
   
13-405   Emergency interim successors
   
13-406   Enforcement of state executive orders and declarations of state of
local emergencies; penalties
§13-401 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   EMERGENCY. Any occasion or instance for which, in the determination of the
president of the United States or the Governor of Oklahoma, or the Mayor,
federal, state or county assistance is needed to supplement the city’s efforts
and capabilities to save lives and to protect property and public health and
safety, or to lessen or avert threat of a catastrophe within the city.
   EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT. The preparation for and the coordination of all
emergency functions by organized and trained persons, who will extend existent
governmental functions and provide other necessary nongovernmental functions,
to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from natural or
human-made disasters developing to such an extent to cause an extreme emergency
situation to arise which by declaration of the Mayor of the city jeopardizes
the welfare of the citizens of the city. These emergency functions include, but
are not limited to, firefighting, law enforcement, medical and health, search
and rescue, public works, warnings, communications, hazardous materials and
other special response functions, evacuations of persons from affected areas,
emergency assistance services, emergency transportation and other functions
related to preparedness, response, recovery and mitigation.
   EMERGENCY OPERATIONS PLAN. The plan which sets forth the organization,
administration and functions for emergency management by the city.
   HAZARD MITIGATION. Any cost-effective measure which will reduce or eliminate
the effects of a natural or human-made disaster.
   HUMAN-MADE DISASTER. A disaster caused by acts of humans, including, but not
limited to, an act of war, terrorism, chemical spill or release, or power
shortages that require assistance from outside the city.
   NATURAL DISASTER. Any natural catastrophe, including, but not limited to, a
tornado, severe storm, high water, floodwaters, wind driven water, earthquake,
landslide, mudslide, snowstorm or drought which causes damage of sufficient
severity and magnitude to warrant hazard mitigation or the use of resources
from outside the city to alleviate damage, loss, hardship or suffering caused
thereby.
   SIGNIFICANT EVENTS. All hazardous material releases of any size and type,
earthquakes, fires involving large buildings or facilities and large grass or
wild fires, explosions, bomb threats, terrorist/civil disturbance, aircraft
crash, natural disaster, utility disruption, dam breach, technological/human-
made incident, search and rescue, structural collapse and any other incident
that poses significant consequences to the city.
   UNAVAILABLE. Absent from the place of session, other than on official
business of the city, or unable, for physical, mental or legal reasons, to
exercise the powers and discharge the duties of Mayor, Vice Mayor or designated
employee.
(Ord. 1725, passed 7-22-2014)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 63 O.S. § 683.3
§13-402 PLAN DEVELOPMENT; AGREEMENT WITH COUNTY.
   (A)   (1)   The city shall develop an emergency management program in
accordance with the State Emergency Management Act, being 63 O.S. §§ 683.1 et
seq., as amended.
      (2)   The city is authorized to enter into an emergency management
services agreement with the Board of County Commissioners, for the county to
provide emergency management services, and an emergency operations plan.
   (B)   Further, that the County Emergency Management Director shall develop
an emergency operations plan in accordance with existing federal, state and
local statutes, including the State Emergency Management Act, as well as the
Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act, 42 U.S.C. §§
5121 through 5207. The plan shall be reviewed annually.
(Ord. 1725, passed 7-22-2014)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provision, see 63 O.S. § 683.11
§13-403 CITY AUTHORITY.
   In carrying out the provisions of this chapter, in which any disaster as
defined in §
13-401 occurs, the Mayor shall have the authority to declare an emergency and
the power to enter into contracts and incur obligations necessary to combat
such disaster, protecting the health and safety of persons and property, and
providing emergency assistance to the victims of such disaster. The city is
authorized to exercise the powers vested under this section in the light of the
exigencies of the extreme emergency situation without regard to time consuming
procedures and formalities prescribed by law, excepting mandatory
constitutional requirements, pertaining to the performance of public work,
entering into contracts, the incurring of obligations, the employment of
temporary workers, the rental of equipment, the purchase of supplies and
materials and the appropriation and expenditure of public funds.
(Ord. 1725, passed 7-22-2014)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provision, see 63 O.S. §§ 683.1 et seq.
§13-404 NONLIABILITY OF CITY.
   Neither the city, nor any officer or employee of the city, nor a volunteer
whose services have been accepted and utilized by an officer or employee of the
city for carrying out the functions of this chapter, shall be civilly liable
for any loss or injury resulting to any person’s company, corporation or other
legal entity as a result of any decision, determination, order or action of
such employee or volunteer in the performance of assigned duties and
responsibilities under this chapter during a stated emergency unless such loss
or injury was caused by the gross negligence, or willfully and unnecessarily or
by the wanton act of such officer or employee or volunteer. Nothing in this
chapter shall be construed to waive the sovereignty or immunity of the city
from being sued.
(Ord. 1725, passed 7-22-2014)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provision, see 63 O.S. § 683.17
§13-405 EMERGENCY INTERIM SUCCESSORS.
   (A)   In carrying out the provisions of this chapter, in which any disaster,
as defined in §
13-401, occurs, in the event the Mayor is unavailable, as defined in §
13-401, then his or her emergency interim successor shall be the Vice Mayor and
he or she shall exercise all powers and duties of the Mayor’s office. In the
event both the Mayor and Vice Mayor are unavailable, as defined in §
13-401, the next emergency interim successor shall be the Director of the
Department of Public Safety, and he or she shall exercise all powers and duties
of the Mayor’s office. In the event the Mayor, Vice Mayor and Director of the
Department of Public Safety are unavailable, as defined in §
13-401, the next emergency interim successor shall be the Chief of Police, and
he or she shall exercise all powers and duties of the Mayor’s office.
   (B)   An emergency interim successor shall exercise these powers and
discharge these duties only until such time as the lawful incumbent officer or
an emergency interim successor higher in rank in order of succession exercises,
or resumes the exercise of, the powers and discharge of the duties of the
office, or until, where an actual vacancy exists, a successor is appointed to
fill such vacancy or is elected and qualified as provided by law.
(Ord. 1725, passed 7-22-2014)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 63 O.S. § 686.3
§13-406 ENFORCEMENT OF STATE EXECUTIVE ORDERS AND DECLARATIONS OF STATE OF
LOCAL EMERGENCIES: PENALTIES.
   (A)   Any person violating any provisions, by action or inaction, of any
restrictions set forth in a state executive order or a declaration of a state
of local emergency, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be prosecuted by
the issuance and filing of a citation in Municipal Court.
   (B)   The provisions of this chapter will be enforced by city police
officers, the City Attorney, Code Enforcement Officials or any other officer or
employee designated by the City Manager.
   (C)   (1)   Any person, business owner or employee, upon the first violation
of a state executive order or a declaration of state of local emergency, will
receive a written warning of the violation. The warning shall include a copy of
the executive order and/or the declaration of state of local emergency, so that
the person can become familiar with the restrictions contained in the order or
proclamation.
      (2)   Any person, business owner or employee charged with a second
violation of a state executive order or a declaration of state of local
emergency, within six months of receiving a written warning, upon a finding of
guilt or the entering of a guilty or no contest plea, shall be punished by a
fine of not more than $200.
      (3)   Any person, business owner or employee, charged with a third or
subsequent violation of a state executive order or a declaration of state of
local emergency, within six months of receiving a written warning, upon a
finding of guilt or the entering of a guilty or no contest plea, shall be
punished by a fine of not more than $500, or by imprisonment for a period not
to exceed 60 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment.
(Ord. 1806, passed 4-2-2020)
CHAPTER 5: UNCLAIMED PROPERTY
Section
   
13-501   Complete record required
   
13-502   Disposition of unclaimed property
   
13-503   Exchange of unclaimed or confiscated weapons
   
13-504   Property of deceased persons
   
13-505   Property found by a private person
   
13-506   Recovery by owner
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 15 O.S. §§ 511 et seq. and 22 O.S. §§ 1321 et seq.
and 1261 et seq.
§13-501 COMPLETE RECORD REQUIRED.
   All personal property which comes into the possession of any police officer,
which has been found or stolen or taken off the person or out of the possession
of any prisoner or person suspected of, or charged with, being a criminal, and
which is not known to belong to some person laying claim thereto, shall be, by
the officer securing possession thereof, delivered into the charge of the Chief
of Police. The Chief shall, in a permanent record book kept for that purpose,
make a record sufficient to identify the property, with the date and
circumstances of the receipt thereof, the name of the person from whom it was
taken and the place where it was found; and the record shall also disclose the
subsequent disposal thereof, giving the date of sale, name and address of the
purchaser, and the amount for which it was sold.
§13-502 DISPOSITION OF UNCLAIMED PROPERTY.
   Any unclaimed personal property, other than animals or weapons, which
remains in the possession of the Chief of Police, unclaimed, or the ownership
of which is not to him or her satisfactorily established, for a period of 90
days, shall be sold, and the proceeds of the sale shall be paid over to the
City Treasurer, who shall issue his or her receipt therefor, and deposit the
same to the credit of the General Fund of the city, except such personal
property as in the opinion of the City Manager can be more advantageously used
by some department or office of the city government. Ten days before a sale of
such unclaimed property, the Chief of Police shall sign and have posted in a
conspicuous place in the City Treasurer’s office, where it will be plainly
visible to persons who visit that office, notice of the time, place and manner
of such sale and general description of the property to be sold. However, if in
the opinion of the City Manager, all or any portion of the personal property
may be more advantageously used in any city department or office, he or she
shall so instruct the Chief of Police in writing, and the Chief shall thereupon
deliver the personal property designated to that department or office of city
government and make a permanent record of its disposition.
§13-503 EXCHANGE OF UNCLAIMED OR CONFISCATED WEAPONS.
   (A)   Unclaimed or confiscated weapons which have been in the possession of
the Police Department for 120 days or more may be traded by the Chief of
Police, with the approval of the City Manager or his or her designee, for new
weapons for use by the Police Department. The unclaimed or confiscated weapons
may only be traded to such gun dealers who have complied with applicable state
and federal regulations concerning firearms and, in the opinion of the Chief of
Police and the City Manager or his or her designee, are reputable.
   (B)   In trading such unclaimed or confiscated weapons, the Chief of Police
shall, with the approval of the City Manager or his or her designee, advertise
for bids for such trade. Such advertisement for bids shall be done in
accordance with prevailing and established bid procedure as formulated by the
purchasing entity of the city; however, in no case may the fair market value of
the weapons received in such trade exceed $2,500, unless such trade is
accomplished pursuant to formal bid procedure.
   (C)   The value of such unclaimed and confiscated weapons as hereinabove
discussed shall in all cases be determined by their fair market value of the
new weapons received in such trade.
§13-504 PROPERTY OF DECEASED PERSONS.
   (A)   The personal property of a deceased person shall be delivered only to
the next of kin of such person or to the legally appointed representative of
his or her estate. If the personal property is claimed by the legally appointed
representative of the estate of the deceased, a certified copy of the order of
the district court appointing such person shall be deemed sufficient authority
to support the claim. If the personal property is claimed by the next of kin,
the claimant shall furnish an affidavit to the effect that he or she is the
person entitled to possession of the property. The affidavit shall be deemed
sufficient authority to support the claim.
   (B)   If personal property of the deceased person remains unclaimed for a
period of 90 days, it shall be disposed of in the appropriate manner provided
in this chapter.
§13-505 PROPERTY FOUND BY A PRIVATE PERSON.
   Any personal property found by a person other than a public official or
employee, which is delivered to any police officer for identification, if not
claimed or identified within 30 days, shall, within ten additional days
thereafter, if requested by the finder, be returned to him or her, and a record
of such disposal made thereof. If the finder does not request return of the
property to him or her within such additional ten days, then the Chief of
Police shall sell the property as if it had been found by a public official or
employee, or on instruction by the City Manager deliver it to some department
or office of the city government for its use.
§13-506 RECOVERY BY OWNER.
   If any property is sold as herein provided, and the owner thereof takes and
recovers possession of same from the purchaser, the amount paid therefor shall
be returned to the purchaser, upon verified claim being submitted and approved
by the City Council.
CHAPTER 6: UNIFORM SYSTEM FOR ADDRESS NAMING AND NUMBERING
Section
   
13-601   Purpose and intent
   
13-602   Jurisdiction
   
13-603   Numbering system
   
13-604   Street name signs
   
13-605   Definitions
   
13-606   Naming city streets
   
13-607   Renaming existing streets
   
13-608   Addressing
   
13-609   Display of address numbers
   
13-610   New address assignment
   
13-611   Administrator
   
13-612   Amendments
   
13-613   Mayor and Council’s review
   
13-614   Variances and exceptions
   
13-615   Appeals
   
13-616   Enforcement
   
13-617   Limitation of liability
   
13-618   Separability
§13-601 PURPOSE AND INTENT.
   The purpose and intent of this chapter is to provide a uniform system of
addresses for all properties and buildings throughout the city’s jurisdiction
in order to facilitate adequate public safety and decrease emergency response
time.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-602 JURISDICTION.
   The jurisdiction of this chapter includes the entire geographic area of the
city limits. The City of Duncan Lakes is included in this chapter.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-603 NUMBERING SYSTEM.
   (A)   Frontage unit (standard interval) shall be assigned for every 5.28
feet of ground whether improved property or vacant lot on every street within
the entire geographical area of the city.
   (B)   Even numbers shall always be on the south and east side of the street
and odd numbers shall always be on the north and west side of the street.
   (C)   There should be no use of fractional addresses, alphanumeric address
numbers, nor hyphenated address numbers.
   (D)   Diagonal streets should be treated as either north-south or east-west
streets.
   (E)   When assigning numbers to corner lots, use the driveway.
   (F)   Apartments and other multi-tenant structures should be numbered with
the main building and then assigned apartment numbers as secondary location
indicators (e.g., 202 W. Main St., Apt. 303, this indicates the apartment is on
the third floor). If a building has a separate entrance for each unit, then
each entrance will receive an address.
   (G)   Businesses and business districts should be numbered just as
apartments, with the middle of the building determining the number and the
offices or businesses in the building being numbered as suites. Office parks
may also have one primary address number along with a building number and/or
suite number.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-604 STREET NAME SIGNS.
   Street name signs shall be assigned and installed for all streets, whether
public or private and at all intersections throughout the city.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-605 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BASE LINE. The lines which divide the city into identifiable sectors and
which follow prominent major thoroughfares. In each case, one BASE LINE runs
east/west and the other one, north/south. BASE LINES intersect at a reference
point.
   DRIVEWAYS. A private way, beginning at the property line of a lot abutting a
public street, private street, easement or private right-of-way, given access
from that public street, private street or private right-of-way leading to a
building, use or structure on that lot.
   FRONTAGE UNIT. A standard interval in feet used to assign consecutive
property numbers on a street. The standard front unit adopted for use
throughout the city is 5.28 feet.
   OFFICIAL STREET NAMES. The street list name and the street map name on file
with the city’s 911 Addressing Office is hereby declared the official street
names and map for the city streets, unless changed by action of the Mayor and
Council.
   PRIVATE STREET. Any street, which is not maintained by the city through the
use of public funds.
   REFERENCE POINT. The reference point for the city’s addressing system is
hereby designated at the point of the intersection of Main Street (north and
south) and 1st Street (east and west).
   STREET. A public or private one-way or two-way street for ingress and/or
egress. Such street may be of various types, including streets, rear access
streets, streets with culs-de-sac and dead-end streets. The definition includes
secondary streets, but does not include driveways.
   STREET ADDRESS. The combination of numbers and street names assigned to a
particular location by the city’s 911 Addressing Office, according to this
chapter, which uniquely identifies a particular location.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-606 NAMING CITY STREETS.
   (A)   Names tending to be confused as homonyms, having the same or similar
pronunciation but with different spellings are discouraged.
   (B)   Avoid sound alike names (e.g., Bay View and Bayview).
   (C)   Do not use special characters in road names, such as hyphens,
apostrophes or dashes.
   (D)   Avoid the use of standard suffixes or directional suffixes or prefixes
as road names (e.g., North Blvd., Court St.)
   (E)   Avoid duplication of street names.
   (F)   If two or more streets have duplicate or confusing names the policy
for renaming existing streets must be considered.
   (G)   A street name combination (prefix, primary name and suffix) should be
used only once, and may not be used in any other alignment (e.g., Jones Drive,
Jones Circle, Jones Court and Jones Street).
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-607 RENAMING EXISTING STREETS.
   (A)   In the case of two or more conflicting street names the city will take
into consideration the older recognized name, number of addresses on each
street, arterial street, historical relevance, existing street signs,
relatedness to the city.
   (B)   The City Address Coordinator will notify the residents of a street
name conflict. Those residents will then have 30 days to provide street name
requests. The Address Coordinator shall determine the new street name and
notify the residents and the United States Postal Service.
   (C)   Request for new names and name changes must include a completed
petition signed by at least 50% plus one of the residents along the affected
street. If there are not two addressable structures on the road the address
will be assigned off the main road. The only exception is in subdevelopments.
   (D)   The city’s 911 Addressing Office must approve petitions to name
unnamed streets or to change a street name.
   (E)   Petition to change a street name must include a fee of $50 per sign
blade to cover cost of replacing signs in addition to $150 to advertise public
hearings. If the City Community Development Director does not approve the
request, only the sign cost will be refunded.
   (F)   The Community Development Director shall consider petitions for street
name changes annually during the first quarter. However, once a street has been
named, the street cannot be repetitioned again until the second calendar year
after the name has been approved.
   (G)   There is no fee for requesting names for unnamed public or private
streets; however the procedure is the same.
   (H)   Petition applications may be obtained from the city’s 911 Addressing
Office, 18 S. 7th Street Duncan, Oklahoma.
   (I)   The City 911 Addressing Coordinator will review requests to determine
if all procedures are met, and to ascertain that the proposed names do not
duplicate an existing name and also to ensure that the petition meets all other
requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-608 ADDRESSING.
   (A)   All streets both public and private shall be named and addressed if it
is greater than 800 feet in length and/or has two or more addressable
structures, including mobile homes, located on and accessed by them, or if the
structure is not visible from the public road.
   (B)   When each house or building has been assigned its respective address,
the city, in cooperation with the U.S. Postal Service shall notify the owners
or occupant’s agents of affected house or building by letter, or by telephone
advising of their new address.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-609 DISPLAY OF ADDRESS NUMBERS.
   (A)   The official address number must be displayed on the front of a
building or at the entrance of the building, which is most clearly visible from
the street or road during both day and night.
   (B)   If a building is more than 100 feet from any street, the address
number shall be displayed at the end of the driveway or easement nearest the
street, which provides access to the building.
   (C)   Numerals indicating the address number of a single-family dwelling
shall be at least four inches in height and shall be posted and maintained so
as to be legible from the road.
   (D)   Numerals for multiple dwelling units and nonresidential buildings
shall be at least six inches in height and shall be placed on the front of the
building facing the street or on the end of the building nearest the street.
   (E)   Numerals must be of contrasting color to the background.
   (F)   (1)   Mobile home lots shall have sequential address numbers
throughout the park. Each lot will have a separate address number assigned.
      (2)   The address number of each lot must be clearly displayed on the lot
by being attached to a post on the lot or to the mobile home consistent with
division (A) above.
      (3)   No unit designator shall be allowed in the address of mobile homes.
   (G)   The address shall be placed on existing buildings within 30 days from
the date of the letter of notification.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-610 NEW ADDRESS ASSIGNMENT.
   (A)   The owner or occupant or person in charge of any house, trailer or
building in need of an address in the city shall apply through the city’s 911
Addressing Office.
   (B)   The application for a 911 address shall be obtained at such time that
the owner, builder or mobile home company applies for a permit from the City
Planning Department. The applicant must mark the driveway with a flag until the
address is obtained. If the driveway is already cut, then no flag will be
needed. This applies to all address locations.
   (C)   Final approval for a certificate of occupancy of any principal
building erected or repaired after the effective date of this chapter shall be
withheld until a permanent and proper address has been displayed in accordance
with the requirements outlined in this chapter. This will be strictly enforced.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-611 ADMINISTRATOR.
   (A)   The Addressing Coordinator is hereby designated Administrator of this
chapter and shall have authority to verify, modify or assign addresses and to
enforce the requirements of this chapter.
   (B)   The Administrator shall assign and maintain a record of all addresses
for the city.
   (C)   The Administrator shall maintain a database of existing street names,
such that duplication and sound-alike street names are neither assigned nor
approved.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-612 AMENDMENTS.
   Petitions for amendment of this chapter may be filed with the City Manager
by any citizen of the city.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-613 MAYOR AND COUNCIL’S REVIEW.
   (A)   The Mayor and City Council, according to the following procedure, may
amend the provisions and requirements of this chapter.
   (B)   (1)   No amendment shall become effective unless it has been proposed
by or shall have been reviewed by the City Addressing Coordinator.
      (2)   The City 911 Addressing Coordinator shall have 45 days in which to
review the proposed amendment and to make the recommendations to Mayor and
Council.
      (3)   If the Mayor and Council fail to report within 45 days, it shall be
deemed to have approved the proposed amendment.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-614 VARIANCES AND EXCEPTIONS.
   The City Community Development Director may issue variances and exceptions
from the requirements of this chapter such that would not be contrary to the
public interest, or the spirit and intent of this chapter, and where due to
special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of this chapter
would result in unnecessary hardship. In granting a variance, the Community
Development Director may prescribe appropriate solutions, as it deems necessary
to preserve the intent of this chapter. In granting a variance or exception to
this chapter, Community Development Director may determine the following:
   (A)   Special conditions and circumstances exist which are peculiar to the
street naming or addressing involved and which are not applicable to other
streets or addresses;
   (B)   The literal interpretation of the provisions of this chapter would
deprive the applicant of rights commonly enjoyed by other citizens;
   (C)   Special conditions and circumstances do not result from the actions of
the applicant; and
   (D)   Granting the variance requested will not confer on the applicant any
special privilege that is denied by this chapter to other citizens.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-615 APPEALS.
   (A)   The provisions of this chapter shall be held to be minimum
requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety and general
welfare. Wherever the requirements of this chapter differ with the requirements
of any other adopted city, state or federal regulations, the most restrictive
or that imposing the highest standard shall govern.
   (B)   Any and all appeals shall be heard by the City Attorney or Assistant
City Attorney. The City Attorney or Assistant City Attorney shall have the
discretion to administratively adjust the requirements consistent with the
purpose of equity. Any appeal or variance determination of the City Attorney or
Assistant City Attorney shall be considered administratively final.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-616 ENFORCEMENT.
   After the effective date of this chapter, any person, firm or agent thereof
that intentionally violates this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, for
the conviction of which, the maximum penalty by law may be imposed. Each day’s
continuing violation is a separate and distinct offense.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-617 LIMITATION OF LIABILITY.
   The city, directors, officers and agents are not liable for any damages in a
civil action for injuries, death or loss to persons or property incurred by any
person as a result of any act or omission of any of its employees, directors,
officers or agents, except for willful or wanton misconduct, in connection with
developing, adopting, implementing, maintaining or operating any 911 system.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
§13-618 SEPARABILITY.
   Should any section or provision of this chapter be declared by the courts to
be invalid for any reason, such declaration shall not affect this chapter as a
whole, or any part thereof other than the part so declared to be invalid.
(Ord. 1766, passed 3-14-2017)
PART 14: STREETS AND PUBLIC WORKS

1.    USE AND OBSTRUCTION OF STREETS
